Comment: The basic idea is just what I have been looking for. I did not need the scientific reasoning behind everything and could have used a little more specifics on method

This book will fulfill its promise if you put in the work the author suggests. It's not easy. It's not a quick fix. But if you put in the time and effort to follow David Allen's program, you will find that stress-free productivity is indeed achievable. (Writing this from my now clean and well-organized desktop!)A number of negative reviews down the book for its lack of digital-use specifics. Some mock it for referring to file folders and paper in this digital age. There is a large and enthusiastic community of GTD users who use Allen's techniques electronically. Google search Evernote + GTG to see one example for yourself.Allen explains why he does not go into detail about electronics. With so many digital options and personal preferences, and with digital options changing every day, it makes sense to provide the general concepts and let individual users sort the details into their devices, software and cloud resources of choice.Whether your GTD system is all paper, all digital or a combination of both, a good amount of thought and effort is required to make GTD your own and make it work. That said, this thought and effort is very much worth it if stress-free productivity is what you truly seek.

Comment: The content of this book is great. I have two very serious criticisms though.First: the layout is incredibly annoying. This may not hold true for the actual print version (I have the Kindle version), but there are inspirational quotes about productivity every 4-5 paragraphs. What is the point of that??? All it does is interrupt the flow of the book and distract the reader. I can understand including a quote at the BEGINNING of a chapter or section, but a quote every few paragraphs is just plain ridiculous.Second: the author takes an inordinate amount of time getting to the actual content. There is a ton of fluff. And he appears to be aware of this, as he asks "...in the past few minutes, has your mind wandered off into some area that doesn't have anything to do with what you're reading here?" YES IT HAS, because of the constant interruption of quotes and summaries and the superfluous buildup, three forwards, etc.I will follow up with this once I finish the book.As a disclaimer, I must state that I am only 12% through the book now. But these quotes make it very, very slow reading.

He's observed and described the human condition as well as Dale Carnegie--I'm tempted to say William James or Bertrand Russell!  And he's developed the Linux of the modern mind: a bit of work to implement, but by far the most powerful, flexible and complete operating system out there, with infinite potential. All that's left to do is to strip down the method to only its mechanics (i.e. minus the supporting and illustrative points) for quick delivery and deployment by those of us willing to try it after chapter 1. Either way, you'll want the full treatment once you've wrested the free time for it.  Read this man's message before you lose another week.I read the Kindle version and have reread it using the Audible edition (which Allen reads himself, and which really added to my sense of him as a genuine, inspiring person).  The text is indispensable as texts often are (especially for the many supporting quotations, and the inset key ideas from Allen, not in the Audible edition), but the audio enables more rapid review and rediscovery. I actually bought a previous Kindle edition a year or two ago, but 'didn't have the time' (he's skeptical of this phrase, as are many others) to read it, and forgot about it.  And to be honest, since the book has no genre it's lumped in with self-help, a not-so-great category I try to avoid.  But it's not self-help; it's an operating system for the most advanced known computer, on which most of us are still running some home-brew nonsense we probably can't defend or even explain.  I only wish someone had forced this book on me in my twenties, when I first realised the need for it.

Comment: I had read and partially implemented GTD based on the original version of this book. The 2015 edition - as the author himself acknowledges - pretty much repeats the original core concepts with topical updates to refer to interim changes in technology and the greatly increased volume of things the typical person can expect to flow into "in" in the course of an ordinary day. Reading this book was good review. I've been using Cultured Code's "Things" application for many years now to support my use of the GTD methodology, but not employing Things or GTD to their fullest potential, e.g. through regular use of "Projects" or the Weekly Review. Re-reading Allen's advice in this new volume has inspired me to make fuller use of all aspects of the system and I am already seeing the benefits in terms of greater clarity, organization, and control of my "Next Actions."

David Allen enters this book deciding to maintain exactly the same filosofy as was generated a decade ago.But in this rewriting we can see a bit more of expertise behind the scenes, a bit more high altitude thinking and some the book changes regarding the different versions without ever going off course.This is a must read for everyone entering gtd and if you planning to reanalyse the book then it is also a good value

I think there are some merits to the GTD philosophy, but it could have been summarized more crisply.  As this is a reboot of the original version, I don't expect Mr. Allen to have shortened the book much, but I do think additional flow charts would have helped for visually oriented readers.  In addition, a lot of quotes are given from authors ranging from Mark Twain to the Brahma Kumaris spiritual organization to Oliver Wendell Holmes.  However, there are several quotes from authors not known to the average non-business background reader (I count myself as the average reader, well-informed on some topics and generally up to date on popular business/self-help/decision-making).  This made the pace a little plodding.To all who have benefited from GTD, I wish you well, but I think the message here could be delivered more effectively.  In addition, and this is my criticism of this genre of books in general, there is an assumption that the people to whom we Delegate tasks will follow through effectively and promptly.  The shifting tides and personalities of a large creative company/group/employer are not taken into account.

Summary:  For anyone new to GTD, go ahead and buy this 2015 version, or save some money and buy the paperback original for $1.50. For anyone who already has a GTD book, just reread it and take a pass on this one, there's really nothing new.I purchased the original in March 2001 for use with my Palm Pilot. I subsequently purchased the Outlook add-in around 2007; and my company had a GTD consultant onsite and provided us access to GTD Connect in 2008. I've found the workflow and methodology useful. The underlying original strength of GTD is that the book not only states "what" has to happen, but through a specific methodology also "how" to make it happen.I was so excited about this 2015 update, with my expectations of entry to the digital age that I pre-purchased in Nov 2014. Just received the book today and I'm sorry to say that David is essentially punting on digital-age specifics in favor of generalities. Further, David admits that this is not a rewrite (though he did "retype the original manuscript").I'm actually fine with the retype vs rewrite though - as he states, the core ideas and methodology of GTD remain the same. But the reason I went to GTD in the first place was that it provided specific workflows incorporating paper and pencil and Outlook and PDAs - he had done the work to figure out what works and I was happy to adopt his recommendations.Since the original release there has been a profound shift in the use of technology - hardware, software, mobile and cloud. 2015 finds us in much more diversified and integrated data input/output environment than what the Palm and MSOffice suite offered in 2000, and so there is a very good reason to update the "how" part of the equation to manage this new information capture and task-list ecosystem.In the new edition, the author provides some digital guideline feature specifics (software outline program should allow for sub-headings, expand/collapse ability), even more generalities, but mostly just derails the digital conversation of any 'how' by sweeping particulars under the carpet with a few ambiguities of "what" needs to be done, not "how" to do it, "Make sure you create comfort with the [computer] applications ["used for developing and capturing project plans and collateral"]. It will behoove you to do regular reviews and updating of this content and keep it current with consistent purging and reorganizing."Punting on digital specifics of today's workflow world because, in his words, “the rate of innovation in this area means that any specific software program can easily be outdated, upgraded, or undermined by the next new thing", and that he has admittedly "hopped out of the fray, opting instead to provide a general model for how to evaluate the usefulness of any tool" is, for me, not useful. I *know* there is a plethora of digital tool options, and I wanted him to do the work and figure out what works. Fine, publish a revision when the tools change, I'll buy it. That's why he and his team get paid the big bucks. But if I wanted to spend my time figuring the complexity of tools out myself I'd have done that from day one. To me, this would be like Lonely Planets back-peddling on restaurant and hotel reviews. "Oh, there are just sooo many these days, let us tell you what to look for instead,,,, try to find a restaurant with lots of people in it, and look for a hotel with clean sheets." Uh, yea.The original methodology and task-driven workflow remains true in the 2015 book as in the original. The "psycap" and other psychological drivers and underpinnings are interesting in the new book. But whereas I was confident that I had a pretty holistic system set-up as a result of the original book (and actually, as much a result of a smaller digital footprint, and I know I'm not the exception), I now feel, with this "completely updated" edition, that I have half a system with a digital divide, a "black hole" as the author even alludes.I understand all the high reviews, the methodology is still very good as described, and yes, freshened. My rating of this book is as a version updated for what we would all agree is an increasingly digital world and unfortunately, whereas the "what" might be explained, I find the book lacking on the "how". I agree  that it has helped me refine my thinking about how to use GTD in the digital age,,, i.e., I now think that I cannot rely just on this one book as a holistic model of how to get it all done ;)For anyone new to GTD, go ahead and buy this 2015 version, or save some money and buy the paperback original for a $1.50 and you'll learn the essentials that have not changed. For anyone versed in GTD, I offer David's statement from this new book: "...whenever anyone loops back through the material, they invariably have a response like, "Oh my God, this is totally different information and perspective" than what they had remembered from earlier, "it was a totally different book each time!" So if you have an earlier GTD book? Just reread it and you'll likely get the same "new" experience and fresh perspective as from this 2015 book, particularly given that there really are no digital age specifics that many of us were hoping for.
Comment_Title: A retype not a rewrite, punts on digital tool specifics in favor of generalities, still a good methodology

I wish I'd read this when it first came out.  I read the 7 Habits of Highly Effective People when it first came out decades ago, and I still follow the approach today.  HOWEVER...the daily execution was always missing.  7 Habits addresses "what" and "why", but Getting Things Done addresses the "how".  Ideas, planning, and priorities are important factors to manage, and GTD addresses the daily "how".  I have never been so organized, so tidy (well, at least less messy -- parts of the surface of my desk are visible at all times!) and felt so "tidy in the mind".  With thoughts, lists, ideas, next steps, etc. all out of my brain and into an organizing system (Outlook, an organizer, and file folder), my mind is less cluttered with "stuff" (as David Allen says), and free to deal with important things.  I have never thought of myself as particularly organized, so when my boss told me "You're really well organized" (as I whipped open my organizer and referred to my meeting agenda that was a printout of my Agenda folder in Outlook -- all suggestions from GTD), I know I was onto something.  Buy, read, do!

Comment: Hi everyone,I used to be super disorganized, and would constantly strive to find new ways of being production without being messy.  Papers would scatter my desk, post-it notes would be placed everywhere--I was getting really tired and frustrated with doing everything by hand.  My friends at work told me to read David Allen's book: "Getting Things Done."  The concept of GTD has completely changed my life, and it is super, super EASY to adopt.  GTD has become something of a movement lately, and many apps and developers have started to copy and incorporate GTD concepts into their systems.  At first, I was frustrated that an app didn't exist for GTD.  Since I am glued to my iPhone and Mac now, I tried to use Evernote (yes I know it's popular) but it just didn't do it for me...luckily I found a cool new app called Taskorami.  It used to only be available on Windows 8, but has since been adapted to be available on many different devices including the iPhone.  I couldn't recommend Taskorami enough, as I use it for EVERYTHING now!Hope this helps!

David Allen’s Getting Things Done describes a very powerful system for controlling the long list of to-do items we all carry around in our heads. I have been using parts of this system since 1985.The basic principle is straightforward – write down everything you want to do – or might want to do – and keep those lists orderly and accessible. Get everything out of your mind and into this system and clear your mind, which, in theory, should make you more peaceful and consequently more effective. Your increased effectiveness, in theory, should make you more peaceful. And so on.Also, to become more peaceful and clear, get EVERYTHING off your desk. Unclutter your office, too.You might wonder why an entire book would be necessary to learn how to do this. You would be right to wonder, as most of the book is, in fact, an explanation of why it is better to not be anxious and what happens when your office and life are messy. Then much of that is restated in different words.Nonetheless, I encourage you to buy the book, because it will increase your commitment to using a system, perhaps this one. After all, you have known since you were 14 years old that is it better to be organized, and it may be possible that you haven’t lived that way.Here are the basics from the book:Get every possible item off of your desk and out of the pile on your windowsill and from the top of the filing cabinet. Everything.Write down every single possible thing you might ever want to do, see, look up, accomplish, plant, complete, give away, or build. Here is the key principle of the entire book and the entire system (it may actually be the key to life, the thing the guru on the top of the mountain should tell you): FOR EVERY SINGLE THING YOU THINK YOU NEED TO DO, DEFINE THE NEXT SPECIFIC, SINGLE ACTION STEP NEEDED TO ACCOMPLISH IT.Not “buy a car.” Not “look at Consumer Reports for car reviews.” Not “keep your eyes open for good looking cars.” Instead, “go online to Consumer Reports to learn which issue has the latest car reviews.” That’s it. If you can do that, everything else is easy.Write each of these next action steps on one of these lists: next action, projects, calendar, waiting for, someday/maybe. Except, if the item would take less than two minutes, do it right now.Put everything in an accessible and obvious place. (Rule of Jenny: Everything has a place, and it’s not “out.”) Buy a label maker and label your files at the moment you create them. On your desk, you are free to keep only these things: supplies, equipment, decoration, and reference. That’s it.Go through your lists regularly. Weekly reviews work for most people. Monthly may be better for you.To recap, for every single thing you think you need to do, define the next specific, single action step needed to accomplish it. The rest is icing on the cake.Buy the book. But feel free to skip over any sentence, paragraph, or chapter that seems to be explaining the benefits of getting organized. There are many such paragraphs.If you want to save some time, here are the most valuable sections (page numbers from the Penguin paperback edition of 2001):The Principle: Dealing Effectively with Internal Commitments (p. 12-18)The Major Change: Getting It All Out of Your Head (p. 21-23)Getting Control of Your Life: The Five Stages of Mastering Workflow (p. 24-53)Brainstorming (p. 70-74)Getting Started: Setting Up the Time, Space, and Tools (p. 85-103)Processing: Getting "In" to Empty (p. 119-137)Organizing: Setting Up the Right Buckets (p. 138-180)As I noted, I have been using some of these tools since 1985, when I attended a David Allen time management seminar. The tools have been helpful. I am committed to getting the rest of my time organized, thanks, in large part, to this book. I hope it helps you.

I was unable to finish reading this book. Made it about 1/3 of the way through, before I:a) Got incredibly boredb) Got incredibly annoyed at the author's presumptuousnessIt may seem implausible that one could simultaneously be both bored and annoyed, yet I managed to.Let's face it, time management is not a very sexy topic to begin with, so I wasn't expecting to be wowed. Yet I found myself very anxious for the author to pick up the pace. The book is hundreds of pages long, but if I'm going to follow any system of organization the latter had best be able to be boiled down to a dozen pages - otherwise it will be too complex to comprehend and adhere to. So in my mind, the author was taking 20 pages of explanation and supporting text per one page of condensed principals. I might accept a 10:1 ratio, but not 20:1.The other major problem is that this book seems aimed at wealthy corporate executives and not the everyday person. As recent research has shown, those with lower income levels find it difficult to make good decisions in areas like financial management, likely due to the tremendous day-to-day pressures they endure simply trying to make ends meet. At the very least, the book should be inclusive enough so that those in unfortunate financial shape will feel like the content applies to them.Instead, page after page of the book comes across as elitist, reading more like an article you'd find in the New York Times' Business or Wealth sections. For example, relatively few of us are concerned with starting a new division or business. And when the author had a sample "to-do" list that included "building a koi pond," I nearly lost it. If you have enough property and money to consider building a koi pond, I say just hire a full-time concierge to take care of all the items on your list, so you can go play golf.I must also say that I found the author's recommended strategy (or as much as I managed to read) a challenge to understand. I found myself going back and re-reading portions of it to try to fully internalize it. I think clearer graphics would have helped.It is always possible that the first third of the book (which I read) was not representative of the latter portion. If so, I apologize, but I gave it a fair shot before I wrote this review.

I have already been doing 80% of what he suggests for most of my 20+ year professional career. The extra 20% which I picked up from this book made all the difference. The key items which I gained from this book were to make my to-do lists context specific, to add my someday-maybe and all my personal/around the house/family to-do items to their own lists to get them out of my head, and to ensure I have next action items for everything not just nebulous goals. These additional insights have helped me get much more done every day. The book is longer than it should be, but it is still a quick read. It could probably be 30-50 pages, but then people might balk at paying for such a short book. The examples and stories may be needed to convince some, but the plain truth and efficacy of his suggestions really does speak for itself. If you never seem to get to the bottom of your to-do lists and constantly have things which fall through the cracks, you will benefit immensely from this book. If you are pretty organized, but sometimes forget things or ever have down time, but aren't sure what to do at that moment to be productive, this book will help you too. I have found that Microsoft OneNote is the perfect tool to keep these lists on my work computer, laptop, tablet, and phone.

Comment: This is a really good book on organization. I only have a few complaints. The first is that this book seems dated. It assumes that we still live in a paper age. His thoughts and ideas are able to be used with email. I would recommend maybe a second book entitled "Getting things done in the information age".The second compliant is like most management books this one is read and pass on. It doesn't stay in your library to be re-read over the years. There's nothing wrong with that. A lot of management books are like that, but the ones that have the deepest impact never leave your book shelf.Overall, I would recommend this book. It will help you become better organized. People will notice a difference and start asking you what you're doing differently. I'm amused at all the questions I get about why I have no emails in my inbox. The promotional material was a bit of a stretch - but, I suppose that's what it takes to sell a product that is definitely in the commodity stage of its existence. Mr. Allen's approach is pretty straightforward - get organized, use a "to do" system that you will really use - check it daily, then have the discipline to do what you said you would do.Doing what it said it would do is exactly what this book does. It is a system for organization of "to do" reminders, resources and filing systems.There is ample psychological coaching and human nature background material (8th grade level stuff, so don't look for great insights) to put the suggestions in perspective.All in all a worthy and useful mechanical approach to behavior management and organization (aka "time management").

Comment: Great book with many great ideas!

A top book in anyone's arsenal who is struggling with time management, productivity, and overall sanity in their personal or professional lives!This book helped me to realize that all time management isn't really time management; it's actually TASK management!  "Getting Things Done" by David Allen is a LIFESAVER when it comes to helping you get out of the piles & piles of "work"—whether personal or professional—that needs to get done or is just scraping at the back of your mind like nails on a chalkboard.But if you're looking for a quick fix method move on because this process, if you want it to really work and do it right, takes a little time to implement.  The good news about this, though, is that I was able to first look up a couple videos on YouTube with David Allen interviews/workshops and implement some of the simplest tips in the book into my everyday life as a "trial" before purchasing the book.  As a result, just these few tips made a HUGE difference!For example, when you realize that your brain is wired to create new ideas but not to store them, just by the act of writing everything down that's in your head on separate sheets of paper and placing those notes into your current or soon-to-be-created Inbox, you'll feel the immense relief of having your mind free to do what it's meant to do—think!  Just this one tip alone allowed me to realize that, yes, I could in fact get back control of my completely overwhelmed life and STAY in control!If you're still reading this and wondering whether to purchase it or not, do what I did:1. Check out a couple of YouTube vids by David Allen on "Getting Things Done".2. Implement the simplest strategies from the videos into your own life.3. Buy the book and—most importantly—refer to it over and over again throughout the course of your year.4. Take back control of your LIFE!!!If you've tried Stephen Covey's "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People" quadrant method of time management and you're still finding it hard to manage your time and your life, give "Getting Things Done" a chance; not as a replacement, but a complimentary book by two authors on the same path to creating more FREEDOM in your life.

The Getting Things Done system is a good system. It has helped me organize my life and feel a lot less stressed out. The Getting Things Done book, on the other hand, is just okay.The system is essentially all about managing a massive to-do list that contains every "open loop" (a term the author uses to describe anything in your life that isn't the way that you want it to be). The goal is to get it all recorded in a way that is reliable as a source of useful reminders so that you don't feel the subconscious urge to keep reminding yourself of things that you can't currently act on (like remembering to buy milk when you're not at the store). The book goes into great detail about this and it goes to great lengths to provide relevant examples for every step of how to tackle your huge pile of "stuff" so that it is all accounted for in your system.The book could have been much shorter. Especially toward the end, I felt as though it had become a bit of a slog to get through it all because I had gotten the idea already and had a working system but felt the need to read page after page of what seemed like filler text to pick out useful tidbits I might otherwise have missed. I understand that repetition is useful for memorization, but even having broken the reading of the book up over several months, I felt it repeated too much, too often.I read the book using the Kindle format. For the most part, the Kindle format was fine. There was one section of one chapter that had incorrect formatting (it was entirely formatted as one very long header), but no glaring problems beyond that which were specific to it being in the Kindle format.

The world is a very different place than it used to be.  Things were much quieter, slower, and simpler back then.  The world is advancing at such a rapid pace that the only way to keep up is to do many, many different things.  Naturally what someone considers a priority in their life varies person from person.  I don't care whether you are a farmer, head CEO, average joe who works at starbucks, or an electrician... There is ALWAYS something more to do.  There never seems to be enough time in the day to do what we need.  That's a pretty well known, and well understood phrase.  Unfortunately, it's completely WRONG and we all buy into it.This book can help anyone realize that.  The problem with us humans is that we are incredibly inefficient and waste a lot more time than we think we do.  We think we are being busy when really we aren't doing anything.  David Allen lays out a methodology for anyone to organize their lives in such a way that they can quite literally double their productivity.  I think that's what separates the successful from the unsuccessful.  The successful people in this world naturally do these things.There are already several reviews on here detailing everything out so I won't bother doing that but it boils down to cleaning your mess up 100% so you can start with a clean head (because the brain is for creating ideas not storing ideas) and take new and incoming challenges on one at a time.  I won't lie and say that its an easy read.  Some of it is but some of it isn't. When he tells stories it can be quite the page flipper.  However, once he gets into the nitty gritty of how the system needs to operate it can be real easy to stall.  Consider it like an instruction manual for your life.  Every instruction manual has parts that are just plain boring but need to be in there.  It really takes the chaotic, jumble of life and organizes everything into an easy to maintain system of clarity and purpose.That being said, applying all of these principles may make one seem robotic in nature and very precise in function but lets be honest... computers are VERY good at what they do.  So why shouldn't we?  I'm not advocating for an IRobot kind of society where everyone is perfect and exact but implementing even a portion of his advice will improve productivity output and reduce stress.  He's not kidding when he says "the art of stress free productivity".  Belongs on every person's library who wants to get ahead in the game we call life.
Great solutions for every day problems!

"Getting Things Done" is probably the most popular time management book ever written, yet it took me quite a while to read. It wasn't the size as the book is only 250 pages (and it should be less), but I guess I had read too much time management books in the past and figured it would be similar. GTD is similar, yet also different. It feels simpler, more concrete and more bottom-up (the last one raises some worries for me).The book consists of 3 parts. They are roughly: 1) Overview of GTD, 2) Same more detailed, 3) Same explained from principles. And this also shows my key comment on the book (and I believe other reviewers pointed this out many times also), the book is quite repetitive.The first part contains 3 chapters. Of these, basically chapter 2 is the overview of the GTD method and is the most important chapter to read. The latest chapters will be mostly a repetition of chapter 2. Chapter 3 discusses project planning and the "natural way of planning" which I found myself a bit less interesting (plus a gross misuse of the term brainstorming).The second part elaborates on the GTD method and has a chapter of each of the GTD steps: 0) preparing 1) collecting, 2) processing, 3) organizing, 4) reviewing, 5) doing. Each repeats the steps from chapter 2 and then elaborates on them. As the GTD method is fairly simple, most of the elaboration doesn't add very much. The last chapter again makes the side-track to projects (which I think could have been removed from the book).The last part introduces 3 principles behind GTD 1) Power of Collecting, 2) Power of Next-Action Thinking, 3) Power of Outcome Focusing. Each repeat the same information as earlier chapters, but add a bit more conceptual thinking to it.Overall, I enjoyed the book despite the repetition. I felt GTD has a lot of good things in it and it definitively tries to keep things simple. I've been at times worried with the bottom-up approach but on the other hand feel the author has a fair point that you can't concentrate on purposes when you are constantly swamped with things. Anyways, I think GTD can help a lot of people gain more control of their life and time, thus a useful book. 4 stars for its repetitiveness though. Recommended to people looking for getting their time a bit better under control.
Comment_Title: Good ideas but book is repetitive

Comment: Two best ideas are time-boxing tasks and holding yourself accountable to them, and dumping all your thoughts on paper in one place to get the "swirl" out of your head. I had bought this book a few years ago for my dad, and had leafed through that copy. When I got my kindle and saw the price, I decided to buy a copy for myself as well.This book is a classic for a reason. It gives a straightforward method for getting yourself organized. Sure, it takes some effort to keep up with all of the tips that Mr. Allen recommends, but it is definitely worth it. I have figured out ways to use my email / calendar / to do functions, along with a Google Doc list of "big projects." And like I said, I spend probably 10-30 minutes each day on the organization, depending on what the day holds, but the results are worth it. I am able to stay on top of things, and I find that having all the "to dos" spelled out in one place is very motivating; I like crossing things off of my list.Probably my favorite technique that I learned from this book is to keep a "tickler," which is the method of reminding yourself of tasks to begin in the future. Like, on July 8th I need to write a letter to someone congratulating them on an award he's set to receive on July 7th. Without my "tickler," I would not be able to remember to do this task on July 8th.Highly recommended!

Comment: Considering that this book was written before the first iPhone was release, there is a definite disconnect between then and now.  There are still sound principles you can take away from the book, but you'll spend a little too much time talking about how to shuffle paper around when most things exist digitally now.  Interestingly, I found that I was doing many of the same things digitally that are recommended in the book.  Trello is my tool of choice right now.  Still, the datedness of the book is distracting at times and pulls value away from the book.

Reality - If you have two things in your head to do, then both of them have equal priority. Everything in your consciousness is a "right now", your brain does not distinguish based on a timeline or importance.  Buying bread and finishing a proposal are the same thing in terms of urgency.  Parking one in a trusted system clears your brain to focus on what you are doing "right now".

Admittedly I was late to the GTD party. After leaving the corporate world more than a decade ago and forging ahead with my own business I fell behind on the personal development initiatives that were a regular part of my previous cooperate culture. Lately, I had come to grips with the reality that my personal bandwidth had been at max levels for far to long and the ramifications were way too many dropped balls, an uncomfortable stress level, and a far less than balanced lifestyle.This book is one of the most important books I have ever read. It gave me a usable system to dig out of overwhelmed and to stay out of overwhelmed. And even more importantly, I feel like I'm thinking more clearly than I have in quite some time as this wonderful GTD system facilitates more higher level thinking and much better quality creative idea generation. Yep, I had to change some habits and many of processes, but the payoff was HUGE.While there were certainly more ah-ha moments in the earlier chapters and the fundamentals of the system were unveiled. I felt the later chapters were extremely helpful in cementing the ideas and giving me more practical examples of how they are best implemented.Granted, the book is a tad dated and could use an update that would incorporate some of the newer technology and software tools that can help you to more efficiently implement the GTD system. But after reading the book and understanding the necessary components of the system, anyone with a internet browser can certainly search out the apps/software tools that best fit their needs. I'm Apple based (MacBook Pro, iPad,&  iPhone) ended up with a combination of OmniFocus 2 (Task Management) and Evernote (additional inbox and comprehensive reference system) and Magical Pad (outlining and mind mapping) to have everything i need to fully implement the GTD system for me across all platforms I regularly use.The value of this book to me in incalculable. If you are super stressed with everything you have to do and everything that's still undone, overwhelmed with keeping up with your various responsibilities, retreating from your life rather than engaging it, then get this book and read it RIGHT NOW. However, be clear it is not a panacea in and of itself. You have to implement the ideas and it will take some time to fully integrate. You are most definitely going to have to be willing to give up some habits and processes that are not serving you in favor of some that will. But the uncomfortableness of the new learning curve and the different organizational system will subside soon enough and the immense benefits will be so worth the effort.
Comment_Title: Tremendously helpful philosophy and methodology allowing you to more consciously engage and more fully participate in your life

Comment: Good ideas to teach your children and to apply to your life.  But like everything else you have to want it to get it.
Highly recommend, would suggest it needs to be updated and think about an app! The book helped me create a new start.
Changed the way I process my workflow and incoming tasks. I am much more efficient at handling the many different tasks I juggle in my business, family, church, etc.
This may not be for everyone, but I found it very helpful.  If you're not already a semi-organized person, this will probably be too much. I found it great for fine-tuning my systems.

1. Misleading Title:This book is to literally organize your things not necessarily to get things done. Seems like the Getting Things Done system is a way to file things rather than truly getting things done like prioritizing, multitasking, how to handle things that come out of the blue and you have a ton of things on your plate.2. Same content over and over again:Seems like they had to stretch the content of this Getting Things Done system in order to make the book. Their answer to stretching the content was repeating the same thing by saying it in different ways. I took detailed notes of the book because it's really wordy and confusing. By chapter 6, I found myself going back to the notes I had already taken and only adding a thing or two because they were repeating the exact same thing with a sentence of new information.3. Painful to read:The way this book is written is just painful to read. Not only am I reading the same thing over and over again, but if I had never seen a document or a book that uses the word ad hoc so many times.The fact that they use the word ad hoc at every chance they get, tells you how painful it is to read this book.
I needed to get organized and this book was the catalyst for doing so.  Easily understandable process and well written book overall.
Comment_Title: Excellent Process for Getting Things Organized and Done

Comment: It's a wonderful inspirational book David Allen has written. I'm already applying a great deal of the methods he suggests and I'm beginning to sense this release of energy. Energy that was formerly tied to my remembering "stuff" in order to get it done, instead og organizing and taking steps toward the next action involved in GETTING my THINGS DONE.Thank you David Allen.Best regardsCatalina Sommer
If you work your to do list out of your inbox, then thus book will certainly help you a lot!
Comment_Title: This is a must have book.

Comment: It’s certainly not the sexiest book in the world. But in Getting Things Done, David Allen presents a valuable and important set of organizational tools to help clean up the clutter from your life. GTD is considered by many entrepreneurs and executives to be one of the most effective and indispensable methods for getting your life in order. I’ve always been a list maker, but this book is a guide on how to make the right lists. Ever since I read this book, and deployed its principals in my workflow (both at work, school, and home), my coworkers have remarked on how clean my inbox always is, and how organized my work has become. If you feel like your to-do list is too unwieldy and cumbersome, this book is a great introduction to the art of streamlined productivity. There is something to be learned by everyone from a high school student to a CEO.Some say the book is better skimmed than read, and I'd agree - it's slow otherwise.
Comment_Title: There is something to be learned by everyone from a high school student to a CEO.

Comment: Totally recommended to everyone who wants to get your life organised. If you have many ideais, many projects, many things you'd like to be doing, and feel you can't handle them, that's the book you're looking for.
Comment_Title: Excellent, really helped me to start to get things done

Comment: I'm a busy person. Aren't we all? My day begins at 5:45 AM and ends at 11:30. From the moment I wake up to the moment I go to bed, I'm constantly doing. I do not like that about myself, nor the community that I'm a part of. Still, that's my reality and I need to manage it.I was talking with a colleague at an out-of-town conference one day, and mentioned how exasperated I was. He reached into his bag and pulled out a copy of "Getting Things Done." He urged me to take his copy and to read it on the train back home. Reading, and then employing the GTD system, has changed my way of thinking, and my way of being in my relationship, in my work, and in my community. I am a calmer person because of it.I have always been a lists person. Each morning, I would come in and make a list of all the things I needed to get done, but was constantly overwhelmed by it all. GTD gave me a way to break it down, and process the stuff that was coming at me. The system gave me a way to prioritize, organize, and then get the tasks accomplished so that I wasn't constantly drowning in work.I still need to be better about the amount of work I take on. I need to practice saying "no" more. Nonetheless, GTD has given me a way to take the rock-pile of work that sits on top of my desk and in my computer, and allowed me to say to myself, "You do not have to feel like Sisyphus all the time."Since I implemented the GTD system, I have bought copies for my staff. Each have found his or her own way to implement the system. I have noticed a considerable drop in stress in our office, and a certain boost in morale.Finally, because GTD has freed my mind from much of what worries me, I have found myself more present for others. I am able to focus in meetings better. And I am able to be fully present in personal interactions, more. For me, GTD has become a spiritual practice. The system provides me a process by which I can get rid of the stuff and junk that fills my heart and mind, and fill that newfound space with the things that really matter in life.
Wonderful to have this in Kindle form. Now i can read the most inspiring parts where ever I go. Fantastic.

I highly recommend this book to anyone who feels their world is spinning out of control from all the "STUFF" in their Life, personal or professional!!I also highly recommend using Mr. Allen's GTD approach with Evernote software ... You'll never be overwhelmed again!!
Comment_Title: Nailed it .... GTD will change your Life

Comment: This book was a mixture of poor writing and poor execution. Aside from the philosophical problems I have with the author and his methodology the structure of how the book was written left me scratching my head. It was hard to read and the content flow was disastrous. Too many poorly placed quotes, lists about lists, organizational models within models, enough headers to make Microsoft blush and an overall convoluted mess of an organizational model. To sum it up, I did not like the book. Despite how often I hear about how useful some people claim the methodology to be I could not recommend this book.
Comment_Title: Should be titled "The Art Of Further Muddling Your Life"

Comment: I read it twice and am still incorporating the method.  It's still weird to organize my life in one A-Z file system, but it makes sense.  I'm on top of my stuff.

Used to work with David and know the information and tools well, but always good to refresh the old memory and reinspire myself occasionally.  Have the book, but the audio version is great for road trips.....or just long days in LA traffic.

Great information here to improve the way you work, knowledge work, and make a quantum leap in productivity. I started to implement the suggestions and saw immediate results as I was reading the book. A true breakthrough for me in improving productivity, reducing stress, freeing up valuable time, and working happier. This has to be in my top ten self-improvement books.
Comment_Title: Excellent book to improve the "Art" of GTD

Comment: this book doesn't really apply to me, but I read the whole thing. I feel like this book would be excellent for the people who could get more out of it. good book for what it is
Comment_Title: Good book for what it is.

Comment: Fantastic book with usefull examples! Gives you a roadmap towards a more efficient life both in work and in your private life.
Great, but feels a bit dated from today's smartphone, ipad, and tech innovations. But, the principles are solid and able to get you on track to a healthier and more productive self.
great
There is a lot of good information here that will transform my day-to-day.  Looking forward to implementing the pus system.
There are so many good tips and techniques in this book.  Everyone can learn something from this classic and enjoy more time spent productively.
Comment_Title: Will change your life for the better

Comment: I would recommend this book to anyone trying to become more productive in their personal or professional lives.  It is especially important for people who process a lot of information, requests, and emails, and for whom responsiveness is a key trait.  I used the methodology outlined in this book together with Evernote.  I expected it to organize me and help with my productivity, but with full buy in to David Allen's GTD methods, my life was really changed for the better.  After years of feeling like I was swimming through muddy water I could finally see exactly where I am going and what is next.This book is very different from most self-help business books because it offers extremely concrete advice, literally steps to take to complete his system.  If you do it, and put thought into what you are doing, and stick with it for a few weeks, you will see incredible results.
Comment_Title: One of the few truly life changing self help books out there

Comment: This book is indeed a life changing. I also bought it in Greek, as soon as it was published in my mother tongue,  to make sure that I didnt missed anything important. I read 2 other well known systems and I must say that this one is the best by far. I dont think that somebody else will come up with a better system. However, this book is a brutal reading ( I am talking about the English version). It is suppose to be a book for busy people and as such our time is limited.The writer could have wrote the book in 100 pages instead of 300! I just suffered reading it. In many pages he was just repeating himself something that really frustrated me. For this reason I give 4 stars instead of 5. But now, after reading it, I am leading a better life both personal and professional.  I haven't suggested it to anyone at my work (hihihihhi...) as I do not want to give away my tricks which i learned in this book and lose my competitive advantage but here I would say it. Its a MUST read.

I've read over 100 books on business practice, sales and management. Of these I would say that 80% have been very useful and pleasant to read. 19% have been useful with select nuggets of wisdom. This book falls in the 1% garbage pile. It is by far the most convoluted and poorly written I've come across. The author writes in a cryptic and circular way, often repeating the same concepts in different ways from page to page or even chapter to chapter. For someone who enjoys crossword puzzle logic and business-speak there may be some satisfaction in unearthing the few useful practices here. Or, if you are completely without any ability to organize beyond dressing yourself, I suppose you could submit to his 100 steps of precise organizational system and perchance it would help you. I particularly liked the diagram of how one should arrange his/her file folders. Truly one size fits all!For those of you who have serious businesses to run and are looking for straight forward golden advice, look elsewhere. The only point I found of worth in the author's system is almost a truism: To get things done, think of the next immediate action and do it."
Comment_Title: An overly dense, poorly written and outdated tome

Comment: the book has good tips and practices to organise ones activities.Could do with some graphics and flowcharts to make it more readable.
Awesome book that cam change your life.  If you need help with focusing your life and getting under control, this is the book for you.

First of all, I have to admit that as a chronically disorganized procrastinator, I didn’t really believe that this book could actually help me and this purchase was more or less a shot in the dark.  That said, I ended up mentally exclaiming stuff like, “YES! THAT’S TOTALLY HOW I FEEL!” and “Wow! This guy really does get it!” as I read the first section of the book.  The system proposed by Allen as detailed in the pages that followed basically included a lot of common sense things that I have already tried to keep up with doing (i.e., keeping track of your ‘to do’ items in writing, setting reminders for yourself, use Outlook calendar to store things that must be done at a specific time on a specific date), but I would describe it as “common sense in HD and on steroids.”What I loved the most about this book is that Allen focuses not just on a plan to get rid of your “to do” list for that day (and in fact, tells you to stop using a daily to do list, period!), but actually provides a way to organize your entire life – including both professional and personal aspects.  This is important for me because I can’t really segment my life into “personal” and “professional.”  There is a lot of spillover both ways.  This system helps with keeping “the big picture” in mind at all times, but not in an interfering, stress-causing kind of way.  Up until reading this book and starting to adopt the system, my future goals never factored into my day-to-day life.  It has been a constant rotation of too many things to do and not enough time to do them.  I will say that just after taking the first steps of ‘setting up the space’ and clearing out the clutter in my office at home, I felt a tremendous sense of satisfaction and really felt motivated to continue adopting the system.  Prior to taking the first step, I was well aware that my office clutter was probably contributing to the stress, but always felt “I don’t have the time to take care of it” and would put it off, thinking “There’s too much to do right now.  Maybe later.”  Well, to all of you who are thinking you just don’t have the time… I took this first step and the world did not end!Now for the cons… As several other reviewers state, this book is laden with “corporate buzzword” speak.  Towards the late middle and end of book, the “system” gets to be a little too efficient (for me, anyway), with sub-classifications for sub-classifications for sub-classifications (which maybe this will make sense to me later down the line… I’m just not completely organized yet).  It’s still a great book, though  - and adopting some of these practices has helped me to become more decisive, thereby decreasing my level of stress a little bit.I am not anywhere near the “mind like water” state and have only just recently started to use the methods described in the book; however, the more I adopt these seemingly simple but oh-so-difficult-to-change-current-behavior-and-employ principles, the closer I feel myself move towards it.  I would recommend this book to anyone who just wants to get organized and experience a little peace in life – professionals, housewives, students… anyone.
It has quite a few good ideas and I implemented a few at home that really paid off.  I read the book for a work book review and enjoyed it.

I like his tactics.  I'm only on page 353 (on my ipad) out of 4445, read it while I was on a 3 hr trip in the car (because I am so stressed that each second I feel I should be working on something, so it was hard to get to it).  But then figured might as well as a passenger on a trip and all I had was my ipad.  Time well spent anyways, it's already helped make me realize my issues.  Also take the time and read it because I've read other places that if you are stressed you are less productive, so it's only hurting you to read it.  I've heard some of these things before in the book, but some not, anyways it helped, you mainly just have to do it.  I'm sure there's much more to come in the 91% of the book I still have to finish, but great already.  How many books can you say that, that are already helping straight off the bat.  JUST APPLY THINGS THOUGH.  You can read all you want, and it will make you feel better, but immediately put each into practice as you read (best way to read anything, like in school, you imagine it applying to a real life situation, well in this book, it is real, ha, so put it into practice as you go, don't procrastinate and just read.  You will never get anywhere if you don't make changes.  <3  GL & onto stress-free productivity!

The author is articulate and precise in what he recommends and this book is actionable. Everything is explained clearly and with examples and reasoning for why the system is designed a certain way.The book suffers heavily from corporate buzzword speak. When I first began reading it, I hardly understood anything because my brain automatically filters out words and phrases like "paradigm shift" "10000 feet view" "synergy" "leverage" "vertical integration" etc. as bull (which is what it's usually used as in the corporate world). I have been using some form of the systems prescribed in this book for a few months now, and it has helped me reach a much better understanding of what I want and how to get it.If you're serious about getting your life together, this is a handy system for you. HOWEVER, if you are presently unmotivated or uninspired or are just generally dejected, pass on this book for now, it will just gather dust on your shelf. It takes an initial burst of motivation to get the systems set up. Once you do and once you stick to them, the rest is more or less autopilot.
I really enjoyed the book providing how and what to do to "get things done."A I purchase the Book on line I use it as a reference when I reach a point of impass...

I can honestly say that IF you FULLY implement the Getting Things Done system it will change your life for the better.  This is the third time I have read the book, which I did in response to changing from a paper based GTD system to an electronic - cloud based system.  I now have Evernote serve as my in-basket.  With the Evernote Android widget on my cell phone I can literally "capture everything", get it out of my head and into the system. I have Evernote's Reminder functionality send my Next Actions Tasks, Projects Lists, and Tickler Files to the Android Program "Remember the Milk"  where I can tag and sort them by multiple contexts. The system described in the book was great on paper.  It is flat out amazing in the cloud.  The hardest part using it in my current setup was working through the nuances of getting the "capture" part (evernote) feeding information smoothly in to the "tasks and contexts" part (remember the milk), but that is an issue with technology, not the information in the book.David Allen's metaphors may be the subject of debate, as noted in other reviews, but in simple "change the world to be more like you want it to be" terms I don't think you will find a better system.Feel free to leave comments if you need more info of how I set up my cloud services...

However, it is important to empahsise, that this will not get stuff done for for you, it will guide you to DO STUFF. In the end, only you can do or not do.

This book outlines the practical steps David Allen developed over the decades he spent coaching corporate executives. He includes enough examples from his own experience to illustrate the barriers to getting things done and the principles of his uncomplicated but incredibly effective system for overcoming those barriers. Business eventually creates yet another "Program" to ensure Compliance with the New Regulation.What is needed is for Business to Dissect ALL REGULATIONS,STANDARDS,  POLICIES, AND PROCEDURES; Align The Tasks each Individual is to perform and then, incorporate it within Each Individuals GTD Environment :)I'm looking forward to discovering which iApps have such concepts integrated?
Comment_Title: Even though the book is "old" by today's standards, the concepts are very much needed

Comment: This book is 'worth the price.' It's a good place to start time budgeting for those who don't know where to start.

I've heard a lot about this method from various places, so I thought I would read the whole book. I've been pegged as a "creative" and "right-brained," and my organization methods show it. I recently found myself getting very overwhelmed by all the different projects I have going at once and needed something to help me get moving on some of them. The book is definitely more oriented toward business-types, but I still thought I could get something out of it.The book has helped me see my projects and tasks at the different levels described. Most useful to me was getting everything possible that needed to be done in one location (for me this was on paper), identifying projects vs. actions, the next actions list (more detailed than a To Do list), and the popular two-minute rule. I have incorporated much of this into a Bullet Journal system, and I do find myself much less stressed, because I'm no longer using sticky notes and scraps of paper to remind myself of things. If I do, I put them in an inbox, which I also use to some extent.The inbox is where I got lost for a while and put the book down for a few weeks. Maybe if I were paying someone to come in and help me get organized, I would have been able to plow through the towering mountain of work this entailed. Since I recently started a business, I found it near impossible to set aside days, which is what I would need, to attempt this process. I opted to use my Bullet Journal as a type of inbox where I wrote things down instead of gathering them into a physical inbox.I will admit I was also put off by the corporate attitude of the whole book. While I might run my own company, I didn't feel like the book was speaking to me much of the time. The whole method also seems very dependent on checking each and every day, reviewing your lists, keeping on top of it all. And maybe this is the real key to organization, but it's not appealing to someone like me who likes to go hide away in a corner with her typewriter and forget the world exists for hours. After 45 years of existence, I've realized I am not the kind of person who is going to be the model of corporate efficiency.With that said, I am using some of the methods, and it has helped ease my mind. I no longer have random lists and notes everywhere (except the strays I haven't caught yet) but one central location where I keep projects, future projects, and next actions. I also quit putting things off so much by using the two-minute rule. So I got some useful information from the book, but it took me a while and required me to let go of the idea I was going to be able to follow all the rules as written.
Comment_Title: Creative People Can Adapt The Methods To Be Useful

Comment: Read this book a few weeks ago. I took time to implement it at home and leveraged EverNote. I have lots to learn but the basic system has made a huge impact in my ability to manage my time. I don't worry that I am forgetting something!
Comment_Title: Incredible New Way to Organize Your Life

Comment: “Which do you think is the more efficient way to move through life – deciding next actions on your projects as soon as they appear on your radar screen and then efficiently grouping them into categories of actions that you get done in certain uniform contexts, or avoiding thinking about what exactly needs to be done until it has to be done, then nickel-and-diming your activities as you try to catch up and put out the fires?” (pp. 244)This statement represents what I feel to be the crux of David Allen’s semi-infamous Getting Things Done , a book that, I have discovered, has its fair share of faithful adherents and passionate detractors online. As I read the quote above, I personally think to myself, “Both sound like unpleasant scenarios, but if I had the self-discipline the former would clearly be the preferable choice.” Whether the system advocated in Getting Things Done works for you will largely depend on just that: how far you are willing to go to plan and organize your life – in areas of macro and micro importance –, and how much self-discipline you can muster.To be honest, I was quite skeptical about reading yet another self-help book. There was a time when I ate this kind of literature up, but I have, in recent years, grown rather tired of it. Perhaps it’s an indication of my laziness, or an indication of how trite the genre becomes once you’ve read and familiarized yourself with several of the “core” concepts (and experienced the disappointment of not being able to implement the advice as easily as the author(s) purport you can). Was David Allen going to offer me yet another panacea for my personal and professional problems?Yes and no. In truth, I have only just finished the book and have not had time to put his practices to the test yet. But on a purely abstract level (i.e., having only read and considered the material), I am actually quite impressed with Allen’s methodology. There is nothing simple about it, but it is thorough and consistent. The writing and explanations are clear. Compared with most self-help literature, the material is actually quite fresh and stimulating. While reading I felt a mixture of excitement and dread: excitement about the potential of this productivity methodology, and dread about attempting to implement it, because I could envision how difficult it would be. Make no mistake about it: unless you have extraordinary self-discipline, I cannot imagine this system being the least bit functional. But with the proper self-discipline in action, I don’t doubt Allen’s system could do wonders to one’s productivity.Most of the complaints I have read against this book have seemed rather shallow. “There’s too much planning involved”; “The system is too complex to implement very easily”; “The author is a cultist”; etc. Even if you don’t attempt to incorporate the system into your life in full, there is plenty of material here to pick and choose from, adapting to your personal tastes and needs. For me, personally, the idea of assigning an action item to every actionable task and/or project in my life sounds like a very compelling strategy against procrastination. As a precursor to that, developing a habit of getting all of my tasks and projects on paper, so I don’t forget about them, also seems to be a very attractive (albeit intimidating) practice. Using the book’s advice, I was able to quite easily rearrange my email inbox in a way that allows me to sort between actionable tasks, reference material, and in-process emails.My biggest gripe with the book is probably the fact that it feels somewhat dated. By that I mean, Allen talks about using PDA’s and word processors like they’re hot new technology. In the digital age, the core of Allen’s system seems to require, or at least recommend, using mounds of paper and folders. If you are trying to go for a paper-free office, Allen’s system will probably be of limited use to you. The sheer amount of physical material needed to pull the system off was somewhat disconcerting to me, because I generally hate to haul around and clutter my home and office with paper. However, in the final analysis, if Allen’s system actually works, I feel like the physical investment is a relatively minor thing compared with the enhanced productivity output that is possible.As an experiment, I am going to try implementing some of the system into my professional life, see how it goes, then funnel it into my personal life if I find it successful. Perhaps then I will have more insight into the usefulness of the system, and be able to provide a more practical, rather than merely abstract, review of the book. In conclusion, as someone quite cynical about self-help literature, I can honestly say I am grateful I read this book (thanks boss!).
Comment_Title: From a Self-Help Cynic: Robust Methodology, Difficult Application

Comment: This book has seriously changed my life. I am productive and I feel much more in control. You DO need to take the time to read the book and put his recommendations into practice (it can be a little daunting at first), but once you initiate the process, everything just sort of falls into place. It feels so good to scratch things off of that old "to-do" list of mine that have been there for months!

This book and the simple steps it provides for maintains a productive, effective, and balanced life is simply amazing. I've spent the past two weeks putting my processes and practices together and I have already seen the benefits. I am applying this to all aspects of my life. Thank you Mr. Allen!

I think it was Einstein who said to make things a simple as possible and no simpler. most productivity methods get the simple part, but not the second part. GTD is just complicated enough to work. it's also a great way to sort your junk drawer and live a simpler life.
Very practical in application.  Not a bunch of fluff.  If you apply the concepts in the book you will find a welcome peace of mind with your commitments.
Getting things done is a must for everyone. It helps you take all of the clutter and things to do in our life and gets them out of your head.
Sometimes it seems a bit complicated, but it really helps...In my opinion David's tips can essentially improve everyone's productivity
Comment_Title: I will attend his seminar in live

Comment: Michael Hyatt's application of Getting Things Done to email changed my life. I had no idea how much psychological pressure I was feeling as a result of my full inbox. This system is very helpful.I picked up Getting Things Done because I was curious about applying David Allen's principles to other areas in my life. I found the book to be very clear, overwhelmingly detailed and extremely practical. I barely made it through the center section of the book where Allen walks you step-by-step through every corner of setting up a Getting Things Done system. This material would be better communicated in person or via video.I'm glad I read the book to the end. Chapters 11-13 were worth the price of the book. The Collection Habit (11), The Next-Action Decision (12) and Outcome Focusing (13) communicate the theoretical core of the book. This is the section I would give someone else to read if they are trying to improve their time management and mental organization.
Comment_Title: Chapters 11 through 13 make this book worth buying

Comment: This book is fantastic.  I was recommending it to others before I even finished.  I will be reading it again soon!  So much info to garner from it!!
Comment_Title: Great read, and its already changed how much I can accomplish

Comment: I read a lot of books on organization and methodology. This book was right place, right time with a technique that might just be life changing for me. I juggle a lot of different projects and keeping them 'in my head' even thought I had a tracking method... was making me exhausted. I'm over the moon to learn this new process and to learn to 'trust' my system.  buy it!

David Allen has updated and modernized the "real time" work schedule...I don't know if I'll be free of stress altogether but the bad stress is becoming lighter.Thanks David, nice job guiding us to better work.

I loved the book and the concepts presented in it. I have already started using GTD and now I feel much "lighter". The only flaw I could spot was that the book requires a significant update - lots of new software has been released since the creation of GTD and the book lacks referencing it.Absolutely recommended to anyone overwhelmed by their duties. It helps a lot even if you are not a businessman or CEO.

The only thing I've really gotten out of this book is if you have something to finish in 2 minutes, do it.  I keep this in mind all the time and it's made me much more productive.  That being said, the audio book (that I purchased separately) confirmed my thoughts while I read the book.  It seems to go on and on and on and on.....wish I could get a condensed version of this or just know what I really need to read to get something out of it.  Not a bad book but if you don't have time to really study this, just wait until you do then buy this book.
Comment_Title: Less then expected but not bad

Comment: The concepts are good, however it needs to be made current with today's technologies.  When was this last time you used a Palm Pilot?
Comment_Title: Good book, but needs to be update

Comment: I always had to-do lists. And the most organizing I'd done was to decide what was going on the list today. I used post it notes and if it didn't fit on the note, it wasn't going to get done. This book has changed the way I look at the 'stuff' in my life that needs doing. I love the 'mind like water' analogy and have strived to keep everything in my system and off my mind now. Great book, highly recommend if you're tired of being stressed out and feeling buried!

I found this book to be very instructive, very insightful and very helpful!  I would certainly recommend it to anyone who wants to get ahead of their game in the area of organization and accomplishment.

his book is one you cannot afford not read, Is one of that books that change your life for good, Applying the method David shares will Improve your life in a way you can not imagine, It should be a mandatory Reading at all schools.
Productivity is great but productivity without stress is better. Love this book and can't imagine how I survived before I began implementing the plan.
Don't really remember ordering this one??  Where did it come from and where did it go??  Maybe I ought to order it again and read it!
Comment_Title: Got the Productivity thing, still working on the Stress thing!

Comment: Everyone at work loves David's approach.  I'm new to it, but can already feel the load off my shoulders by just trying a few techniques.

The best book out there on productivity. I was getting over 100 e-mails a day and loosing the e-mail war.  After reading David Allens book I'm finally wining.  I have actually read it twice because there are so many good ideas I did not capture them all the first time.

Good ideas but a but wordy and always trying to sell you the concept. It gets a bit tiresome and you want to get on with setting up your system and learning how to use it. A more concise version without the stories and guff would be better if you can find it.... However the system is worth trying and adapting for your own needs.
Comment_Title: Good ideas but a bit wordy and always trying to sell you the concept

Comment: Allen breaks down the challenge of being stressed out succinctly.  I have implemented his tips and have improved my ability to "get things done" significantly.
Life changing. Really thought provoking and very simple. Not too strict and very flexible system for organizing personal and work life

If you feel like you might be losing control of your work or life, this book will save you. Timeless tips on how to manage everything but so very modern in that it accepts that we are all bombarded with information and tasks like never before. Great for women because it doesn't expect you to separate your work and home life.In a few short weeks this book has taught me how to stop thinking about home while at work and work while at home. Thank you, David Allen!
Comment_Title: most practical book for any professional

Comment: A classic. I have read this mulitple times, have given it as gifts, have recommended it to others, and I own the other two books in the series.
This book is easy to read and easy to implement. It shows you how to use skills you already have more effectively and adds to them to better sort and organize the demands on your life.

I've bought that book long time ago. It struck me with the simplicity of the GTD ideas. It is sooo simple, why I didn't invented that. This book showed me how to deal with a load of tasks, ideas, projects  etc. It changed the way I live - in that way that my mind is not that cluttered any more and I forget less things.One thing I don't like about it, its the style of sort of a manual for dummies. On the other hand this way its easier to dig into the concepts so its not that bad.anyways, Good job David :)

I truly loved this book! My favorite thing about this book is how he gets right into it!! I was getting things done from the very beginning of this book all the way to the end. I was able to start on a project (I've been trying to do for over two years) and be over half way done by the time I finished this book (only about 2 weeks) Thank You David Allen! You have changed (Saved) my life!! I recommend this to anyone who wants a more enjoyable, productive, stress free life!

GTD is an ABSOLUTE MUST READ for anyone who feels that their life needs a bit more order and/or structure.  Everyone who recommended this book to me claimed it was a life changing book, and I agree.  I could write on and on about how incredible this book is in every way, but I think all the other reviews speak for me.  If you're even considering buying this book, that likely means that you'll benefit from the book.

This book has really helped me get focused and accomplish more in 2 days than I did the previous 7 days!  It is out of my head and broken down into action steps. I have even started talking this way in meetings to guide the conversation towards action.  This book will create a new way of thinking.  I am a Life Coach and will be using the method with my clients. Thank you David!!
Comment_Title: A must read for those who want to get things done!

Comment: Ok... the idea of "Getting Things Done" did, anyway.  This book itself is a little longer than it needs to be, at least for me.This book helped me realize that the main problem with my previous to-do lists was that I wasn't being specific enough about what constitutes "done".  As such, I couldn't ever cross anything off because my list items were evergreen things like "improve training materials" rather than specific ones like "add module variables to presentation on kernel modules".On that basis alone, the book easily returned its investment.  If you really want to employ GTD in a hyper-mobile lifestyle, however, then use an app called "Remember The Milk" on your phone and computer.  It's the best way I've found to put GTD into practice if your "files" are all electronic.

Purchased this book after hearing a talk about the method proposed in this book.  Still can't get a handle on the method and how it will actually organize me and/or help me get things done in a more organized manner.  Need to do a bit more studying on it.
Comment_Title: Still having trouble getting a handle on this method

Comment: I haven't yet finished reading this book, but it appears to me to represent genuine, hard-won practical wisdom. It is a work of insight, and it stands head and shoulders above any other book on the subject that I have seen.

When you have a lot on your plate, this will help you to focus you attention on the now, without the interruptions and worry of the things you have forgotten. This makes a great pair with the Pomodoro technique. I recommend them both enthusiastically.
Comment_Title: Follow this and get it done - don't and stress out

Comment: GTD is a good productivity manual. I think the two-minute rule is very smart, and the workflow methods are great advice.But I also feel that too much of the book is taken up in fluff- personal stories, or advice that only applies to managerial types. I am a biology graduate student, and while I did get some useful tips and techniques from the book, I feel its essence could have been boiled down to little more than a pamphlet and that would have been just as effective, if not more so.Short version: It's useful, but over-hyped and a lot of extraneous info.
Comment_Title: Some good points, but some fluff

Comment: This process is Getting me on the right path to more Productivity.  YEA!  Looking at other resources to help setup the technology side.
Comment_Title: Getting me on the right path to Productivity

Comment: I'm overwhelmed at work, and this brought some order to my life, but I think you almost need to read it every six months to stay on top of everything.  Good organizational tools, not sure if it really de-stresses your life.

Before reading this book my Todo list was a discouraging reminder of all the things I should be doing.  And I often didn't get much done because I was so preoccupied worrying about what I needed to do.After reading this book my Todo list has become an encouraging list of challenges.  My mind is clear.  I know what I can do next.  And I no longer worry about what I should be doing.This new found productivity has had one odd result.  I add things to my Todo list as fast as I take them off.  Regardless, it does feel good to actually get things done.

I consider myself a very organized person.  This book reassured me of some habits I already have but, more importantly, helped me discover some blind spots and areas for growing my vision and higher level ambitions.  I feel better equipped to embrace life's challenges with calm and with purpose.Highly recommend, especially for those looking to improve on your current organization system.

I have started using the GTD methodology and finding it really very useful with respect to getting all the tasks in front of me, keeping projects on point and taking control of email overload. Have also adopted workflowy which pairs well with this system.
only useful if you already think in corporate buzzwords. Most of it was redundant, and the rest were common sense solutions touted as great wisdom.

I am extremely impressed with David's thoughtful approach to getting things done.  The psychology of why we find organization so difficult makes so much more sense when he goes through our mental process - both the good process and the counter-productive process.  Fortunately, David illustrates how anyone who applies a small amount of well thought-out mental effort can attain a much much more comfortable method of organizing the things that we need to keep track of and get done.  Awesome book.
Comment_Title: Excellent, thoughtful approach to taking care of just about anything

Comment: Of course, I purchased this book in order to get better organized. I found, though, that the author is an extremist. He is an efficiency expert. He applies his time-management system to his family even allowing a child five minutes of his structured time. If the child begins to cry at four minutes is there only one minute left to resolve the issue?Every item on your agenda which can be done in under two minutes, he writes, should be done immediately.
