There are files to keep in his own style.What I found most off-putting about the system was he recommends that you whole life be put into prioritized time-containers. He wants everything and everyone put into a box.This, then, is a very left-brained book which will suit such types who are extremely busy and regimented. This not at all suited for a casually interested buyer as his system is pervasive, comprehensive (and regarding family time, IMHO), invasive.
Comment_Title: This Book is Heavy-Duty and Not for Casual Users

Comment: I am not finished with the book yet but what I have read is very good! It is a no nonsense approach to increase  your productivity in every area of life.

Why did I choose this rating?I gave this book 4 stars because of it's difficulty to read. I've read the other comments and they are correct in saying that the book is not an easy read. At first, I thought it was difficult because it really rehabilitates your thought process and your unreliable personal management system. That still may be true but I thought that there were some areas that could have been explained easier.If you don't mind a book that isn't "easy cheesy" then this is the book for you. I wouldn't say that this book is difficult, it's just not easy. It's dry in some areas but it's well worth the purchase.This book has changed my life. I've had it for about 5 days, read the entire thing, and can really feel the changes. My productivity has increased dramatically and it feels good knowing that I am very reliable and will have the kind of personality that people can rely on. The only frustrating thing is once you change your way of thinking like the book suggest, other people that still tries to manage information on their "failed systems" will piss you off. For example, I've been waiting for someone to call me back with a contractor's contact info. There is no way I've would've forgot to call someone but relying on this person and their flawed management system is frustrating. No worries though, it is in on my "next action-call's list" to remind him tomorrow.I'd recommend this book for anyone that is serious about changing their life to being a more productive human being. It really does allow me to be stress free. When I'm living in the now, I can do just that. Since everything is in my system, it doesn't cloud my mind. My wife is even shocked about my change and will start reading it soon.Summary of my reviewIf you got the coin, buy the book, read it, apply it, never forsake it, be productive and stress free
Comment_Title: If you got the coin, buy the book, read it, apply it, never forsake it, be productive and stress free

Comment: I found this book to be a great help in getting organized and more in control as the amount of information that I have to sift thru has greatly increased- work email, personal email, managing more complex projects.
Comment_Title: clear plan for a not naturally organized person

Comment: This book was actually difficult to read. It needs more "summary/rollup" text at the end of each chapter. I started getting lost and bored.
Comment_Title: Good info, but the book needs better editing and organization

Comment: A touch outdated with respect to computer/cloud solutions that are available. There is an emphasis on paper management that is irrelevant for today's executive.
Comment_Title: Quick read about GTD, but a touch outdated

Comment: The author shows that all levels of our lives (from our life purpose all the way down to adding milk to our grocery list) can be managed using the same techniques. This creates a flow and a consistency in our day to day lives, resulting in maximum productivity, and at the same time, minimizes our worry and stress. A great book by a very knowledgeable author!

This is the single best productivity book I've ever seen. I can't recommend it highly enough. This book takes you step by step and tells you in great detail how to take everything you want to do in life from organizing your desk drawer, to organizing a big move, to becoming president of the United States and put it to paper and map out a path to accomplishing it. My productivity has skyrocketed since reading it.

Most importantly gives easy, yet specific steps on how to get it started, and maintain the GTD system.  This is so simple and effective that it can be used in many areas from work, hobbies, appts, etc.  I read it in 2009 and still use in many areas of my life-  and believe me "ORGANIZATION IS NOT MY, MIDDLE NAME."
Comment_Title: Best Admin/Business/ and or life management book ever

Comment: I got this when I heard about it on the Stern show. I've always been organized, but never hurts to seek some improvements.  I did find a few helpful hints, but nothing life-changing for me.  Would be a good book to lend to some less organized friends!  Plus it does provide some motivation to get stuff done.
Could never get around to finishing it; didn't get practical enough fast enough to grab action and attention for me.

I am passionate about productivity and efficiency in both my professional and personal life, and this book succinctly defines a framework that can help anyone improve their ability to get things done.

Just read David's book for the second time.  I implemented many of his ideas after the first read and then "drifted away" from a lot of the things he suggested to implement.  Now I am re-implementing many of his tactical suggestions and all is well with the world.  For me, it's the little things that helped so much.  Using a label maker and manila folders to reduce clutter and make it much easier to find documents is one of the best ideas.  And David's two minute rule is his very best.  This book has given me an extra hour in each work day and obviously made me more productive.  Thanks so much!  Kip Marlow, author ofThe Entrepreneurs: Success and Sacrifice
While we feel motivated as we travel, one can always use a reinforcement boost. This book was among those most recommended.
Comment_Title: Needed a new perspective on staying motivated as we trave around America.

Comment: I was totally gung ho after I read this to get my stuff organized!  It does work - but I have already fallen out of the habit a little bit (that is my fault - not the book's!).  I think the information is helpful and works - you just have to make the commitment to follow it and not cheat yourself.  I'm still working on that last part!

I have purchased this book for three coworkers since reading it and love it. I thought I was organized before this book, now, I'm even more organized. It is excellent. He gives you a lot of tips, if you just apply a few of them, you will be the one in the office who is on top of things, follows through, completes tasks and .... gets the promotion! Thank you David Allen. I love this book.
Comment_Title: My CEO asked all directors to read this book - so glad she did!

Comment: I felt overwhelmed by my homelife and work duties. This book helped me focus on the context of my situation, i.e. If I'm at work I can't worry about what's not being done at home.The concepts are powerful and applicable/adaptable to many lifestyles. This book is not just for 9-5ers or corporate types.It's worth reading if for no other reason than that you'll get a much clearer picture of all your responsibilities and on going projects/commitments, what really matters to you, and the next step to make things happen.

This book has helped me to free up my time and clear my head. I'm not a pro at it yet and still struggle with the "review" function, which is mandatory for success. But it's excellent and has shown big results already. Thanks to my company and H. Stern for recommending...
I found so many tips and tricks to improve my organization. Howard Stern was right. This book will change the way you operate not only in work but in life. Strongly recommended.
Comment_Title: good even if you are organized

Comment: If you don't already know how to make a list or a file folder label, then this book is for you. Its also out of date...there is nothing in here about using mobile tools which are a big part of anyone's time management systems today.

This is my second purchase of this book since I lost my first copy. The content is undoubtedly so far the best time management book on the market, but Amazon sold me this one used at a "new" price! There was some gentle writing in quite a few pages in the later chapters. It was lightly used, but NOT NEW.
Comment_Title: Bought the USED version at the new version price

Comment: So far implementing this system has been great!  Really improved the way I look at work and manage my projects.

I took away several good tips for getting more productive from this book. First off he talks about the need to write ideas down before they pop out of your head. Now I don't hesitate to set a reminder or make a note before it all falls down the cracks. The other point that I liked was that you have to nail down your "open loops" which are to dos that you keep remembering but never have time for.A good book but if you have ADD or find yourself unable to organize, focus or are constantly in crisis mode I would recommend ADD friendly ways to organize your life. Then once you've got that all down maybe you could also read this one. Just my two cents.
Comment_Title: Ok but if you have ADD I found a better one

Comment: I've read plenty of books on "how to get organized" so I was eager to find out with Dave Allen could tell me that I didn't know.  In fact, I put his plan to use in my annual effort to clean out and reorganize my home office. I read it once all the way through, marking the pages with advice I could use. Then I read it a second time, putting the advice into practice.  Allen's book proved to be an excellent guide in that It told me not only how to sort and file paperwork (which I already knew) but also how to establish action items on unfinished projects and how to close open loops in my organizing.  I especially liked the "next step" approach to major, time-consuming progress.  As a result of reading this book, I know have a central file on my computer desktop with a master list of all my current, pending, and future projects. This is helpful because I no longer keep all this information in different places (including my head) and I am more confident that nothing falls through the cracks.  This is a book I plan to use on an annual basis each time I clean out old paperwork and reorganize according to my changing career needs and interests.
Comment_Title: I Used this Book as a Guide for Reorganizing My Home Office

Comment: It represents helpful tips and techniques, and help reconsidering the file/task/time management. I would prefer it to be less pages for the amount of data it gives!
Comment_Title: Very helpful, could be shorter though!

Comment: I thought this book was pretty good. It's all about taking action and a system to do it. I'm trying to implement it as best I can and do find that it is a better way to do things than I am used to doing

I rated it three because it was okay, but not exactly what I was looking for.I would recommend it to business oriented folks that have a lot of phone calls to take or make, files that need organizing,people to see, places to go, etc.  But the whole system recommended here would take quite a bit of time to accomplish.Once set up, it may work for some and not for others. If interested or you don't have a lot of time to read,or if you just want to know what the set up is, then get the shortened version. It explains the system in  a nutshell without so much detail...wish I did.

He had a lot of helpful tips....one notch above "touch it once"it is very dated though because it does not talk about digital storage very much.Evernote, zendone, scansnap wifi scanning, etc.He uses a paper filing systemBut conceptually very helpful
Comment_Title: Helpful for getting things done idea

Comment: Amazing read. If you are reading these reviews than you are looking for a solution, this book may be the answer
Christmas present for my son & he loved it.  It was just what he ask for, for Christmas  later Gator

This books helped me to organize my tasks properly. I am able to balance personnel and work related lot of pending tasks properly.I strongly recommend to the people who are not organize the tasks properly as myself in the life. The methods suggested are simple and gives a hand to control the daily tasks.
Comment_Title: Good book. Helps to organize yourself

Comment: I purchased the audio version of getting things done and have heard it serval times and it wasn't until I actually read his material that everything began to click. The methods, strategies, and tips I find very useful, David tells you exactly what you need to do and how to do it. If you already have a system for processing information or your looking for a way to be more productive and organized; I would recommend this book, you might find an idea here that can make a big deference.
Really needs to be updated to reflect new technology. He goes on at length about things like how to create physical files with labels, etc. Not reflective of modern organizational systems.
As a second, similar gift, my daughter asked me to get this for her as a "stocking-stuffer" this past Christmas.She likes it a lot!
Comment_Title: A Christmas gift for my daughter.

Comment: Although I have not yet finished reading this book, it is clear that the method presented in this book is very useful.I would recommend it to anyone who wants to get organized.The book explains in detail the method and the tools.What I dislike about the book is that sometimes it appears to be too lengthy, it could have been more concise.In order to take full advantage of this book, you need to have patience and invest time to buy the material and set up the system.

I'm afraid that very busy people won't read this, since it's a book with 200 pages. Example videos would be even better.But it's a great book which I've read 2-3 times during a couple of years already. And I will read it again.
Comment_Title: Great book, but could be shorter

Comment: This book makes organizing and getting productive just like common sense.  I have recommended this to all my friends in business.

I am very disappointed with this book.  It is very repetitive, several times, I through had accidentally gone back on my kindle.I found buying the GTD (Getting things Guide to Evernote) 1000 Times better. It explained how to use a 21st century method with his ideas. GTD was written in 2002. It also explained the principles much clearer.
Comment_Title: This book is the most over rated book I have ever read

Comment: A very common sense approach to organization and more importantly, decision making. This allows you to clear the clutter and leave room for innovation. An easy read. This book will help anyone whether they are a busy 'stay at home' parent or a CEO.
I'm already on the road to "a mind like water" and I've only just begin practicing some of the tenets if this book!
Comment_Title: an excellent source for improving your professional and personal productivity

Comment: This book can not only teach you great ideas about how to get things done, it can also show you ways to break out of ruts and change behaviors that are self-defeating.  Highly recommended reading.
I bought this book because I was starting to get overwhelmed at work. I started following the instructions and so far my life at work they work great.

I found that the actions steps were somewhat difficult to follow (maybe the fault is mine) and I though the terms got too technical and jargonistic at times which makes it very 'dry' and inaccessible at times. While I did have some important takeaways, I felt that I did not get as much as I would like out of this book and I found it hard to complete reading it as well.

I just finished the book and was at least inspired to spend the day cleaning off my desk, credenza, and table in my office. I setup a preliminary in-box and started on making lists. It will still take some time I know to continue developing this system and making it my own, but at least I'm energized and excited about the prospects of not just having cleaned a desk or shifted around some piles but working through this system to more efficiently and effectively get things done.

There are books that you want to read again. This will probably not be that book. It does cover the basics of time and life management. A lot of concepts in the book are repeated multiple times.The first half of the book is much more interesting than the rest half. The concept of organizing life into several layers is very interesting. He differentiates very nicely between tasks and projects and long term objectives. The parallel that he draws using feet (altitude) above the ground is very helpful. David also stresses again and again about the collection habit. Other than these concepts the book is pretty much an affirmation of general life philosophies that we experience every day.

Purchasing this book in 2013 and it having references to old technology was a bit disappointing.  Would have been much better if content was updated to reflect the current state of technology.  Implementation ideas were presented as using pieces of paper with filing folders / cabinets or as using obsolete technology of Palm Pilot (an obsolete device almost no-one uses any longer).
Comment_Title: Good ideas, but very dated material - felt like a decade ago

Comment: Some how this is a very good book. It has been around a while so some of the ideas may seem old hat...
I have found Allen's approach very practical and I use it daily.  Get the book and start getting things done!
Love this book. REAL, specific actions you can take to get more organized and keep your mind free of mental clutter.
what else can I say?  I am so much less stressed and more productive, more organized..  get the book, USE the system and you will be amazed!

Not all the stuff in here will be exactly relevant to everybody - for me, I "cherry picked" the stuff I could make best use of.  It is the overall perspective of the book and it acting as a catalyst to get control of my situation that I liked best.  I have a couple of comments for the author about "getting things out of your head" and written down somewhere else - if he is interested . .

I don't like writing reviews, but I did want to rate the book. This book is very useful, even for a non professional. Between home projects,  homeschooling, and helping with my husband's business, I have a lot of stuff to get through my in basket.

This is a good read for anyone who needs to get task/projects/commitments more organized. A number of good nuggets on how to prioritize and setup your systems to keep you on track. I'm still halfway (or less) into using everything he proposes... can take some investment of time up front to catch up. But I see the light at the end of the tunnel of being able to at least have a process to document every personal or work committment - and keep reviewing updating. Also includes tips on filing, archiving, and keeping references that meld with the project management approach. Worthwhile read.

I am sure this is a good system, but taking two weeks to implement is something most of us "too busy people" are not going to make time to do. It may be worth it, but it is a complex system and not something you will implement or maintain easily. Back to Outlook and the Franklin Planner plug in.

This book has helped me more than any other book (and I've read a lot) on organization I've seen. It talks about to do lists being inefficient. Instead each project of my life has the "next action". I have been overwhelmed lately and have been dropping a lot of the plates that I used to keep spinning. This has gotten me to stretch my mind and get things done.
read this book to help getting things done in your life. It has worked a little for me, but it needs great conscious effort to practice this.
Comment_Title: good if you can practice it

Comment: The Getting Things Done (GTD) philosophy is superior to the Franklin system for day-to-day work. I used Franklin philosophy until I read this book. I realized I wasted too much time on day-to-day planning. GTD seems to work well with day-to-day planning, while I still thing Franklin is relevant for the long-term big picture planning. David Allen's book is very readable.
Comment_Title: GTD is superior to Franklin for Day-to-Day

Comment: Great book and way of thinking. It really helps to handle all the stuff we all deal with daily while still moving towards our goals. The webinars are great too!
Comment_Title: Definitely worth your time and energy to read and implement the GTD principles!

Comment: This book changed my life!  Whenever I get stressed about everything going on in my life, I pull this book out and take a look - there's always some section that rings true with me about how to improve the situation.  It's the foundation for the whole "GTD" movement, and lays it out in a clear, concise way, unrelated to the intricacies of tools, apps, etc.  I've probably read this book three times, and still there is more there to help me get things done.  I've been successful enough at it to have people ask me what the trick is, and I always send them to this book.

i am a smart guy- a visionary and big picture thinker... but also pretty scattered and ADD when it comes to excecution because my attention span is too short for organization... this book changed my life... if you live with constantly shifting focus and that causes you to miss things, forget things, and stress out about what you just now remembered, what you may forget later, and what you may have already forgotten, then this book will probably change your life. Take the time to adopt this very intuitive system.  One year later, i am so dialed in on all my projects.
Comment_Title: if you have any amount of "ADD", or are a creative type of person-

Comment: Because it has actually change my life. I'm more organized and productive and in the process of achieving a "flow" style of living. I still have a lot of work to do but I know how to do it . Thank you
Comment_Title: Enjoy your life by keeping stress out

Comment: Needs to be updated; it talks about Palm Pilots as new tech.He explains some things as if to a 5 year old, and his real world examples of "executives" sound contrived.Needs a cliffs notes chapter. He spaces all the steps over many chapters, so there's no quick way to just start the process and jump in. If your hoping to get yourself together quickly, forget about it. And if you don't care to read his mumbo jumbo about how your brain is supposed to work and how your life will become magical with efficiency, you're out if luck; it's everywhere.He doesn't use consistent terminology. which many times leads you to rifle back through pages to see if you missed a step. Lots of time wasted there.
Comment_Title: Could be useful but frustrating to read through

Comment: Classic book. I recommend to anyone that want to be more efficient.  This book has helped me be more productive at work and home.
this book has soooooo many tips you can learn form, but you must read it and study it...  you also have to apply the principles
Comment_Title: this book has soooooo many tips you can learn form, but you must read it and study it...  you also have to apply the principles

Comment: As a creative person (writer, actress, women's minister) I often struggle with a organizing.  The very thought produces longing in the midst of feeling defeated before I begin.  What I have already begun to implement from David Allen's techniques has made me a stronger, more capable leader, freeing me up to create without neglecting ongoing projects.  Eternally grateful that my husband encouraged me to read and work through this!
Comment_Title: Efficient productivity makes room for creativity

Comment: easy read, effective organization strategy, easy to implement as you read this book if you aren't in a complete bind when you start...otherwise you will need to block off a good chunk of time to get started but definitely worth the time investment.

I love this book. I found his way on sorting things under a few seconds is invaluable and I base every kind of work activity I do with this. This is one of those books which I'm not ashamed to talk about and say, yeah, this is one of the systems I use to organise my life.Great book and will be a keeper.Here's a tip: Print off the flowchart he gives and put it in your sight when you work. This is what I do and I find myself sorting things at the speed of light. Figuring out when or what is the next step to the smallest or biggest projects.
Comment_Title: Put this in your list to read. Tick it off

Comment: Love the novel idea of creating a time management plan aimed at "Peace of mind" as the primary goal rather than more dollars.
Okay, this is pretty damn good.I wish it was shorter, so I didn't put off reading it for years.  :-)
Comment_Title: Good; wish it was more condensed.

Comment: Some great concepts, but I felt like it was too much fluff. It would be one great page, then 10 fluff, then one great useful page. I wich it was 30 pages and all great content.
Comment_Title: Great content but should only be a 20 page book.

Comment: A classic in the "Getting Things Done" category.Just think of it - it spawned its own category of software - just search for "GTD"Best value book of my life - spent under $20, have been reaping benefits for years!
Comment_Title: Excellent book - shows you explicitly how to get your busy/hectic life on track

Comment: David Allen spells things out clearly, and with easy-to-understand examples. I found myself able to visualize myself executing the strategies while listening to the audiobook, which really helped me get excited to put them into practice when I got back to my office. Once I got comfortable with the basics, I now find myself trying to implement GTD with all aspects of life.
Great info, semi okay read. It is practical and very useful. Writing style is a little dry and not quite upto 7 habits.

Great introduction and how to for GTD.  If you've never learned the concept, this is the place to start.  The only thing keeping me from giving it 5 stars is that tended to ramble on in spots, but otherwise a great book.
Comment_Title: The place to start for GTD

Comment: The reader is the author, and he is a poor orator. Quite Boring.  Might have done better buying the book.

Great material if you need a cure for insomnia.  I picked this up after watching an interview with David Allen on TWIT.  The pace is slow and the material somewhat disorganized.  It's a full time job just to try to use his system.
Comment_Title: Just another self help book for workaholics

Comment: It was a good book with a lot of practical principles on how to get more stuff done that I try to apply daily
I enjoyed the book and the concept of open loops and getting them on paper helped me enjoy my vacation a ton more. We all carry a bunch of crap every day this system offers place to put it down.
GTD is a very useful, a great methodology! David Allen a master, the only thing is that the read is not so easy.

I have implemented several of David’s methods at work and at home and I am happy to report they are working.  There is a wealth of great information in this easy to read book and lots of tips to help you make it through your life with less stress.  I need to go back and read this book again to see what I might have missed the first time around!  Great self-help book!
Comment_Title: Great book to help reduce the stress in your life

Comment: This book, of course, has become a classic in its field. And if you're interested in time management, you should get it and read it. The ideas and theory presented are great. Where it is lacking is in actually implementing the ideas in a practical way. I tried it, and like many others, got frustrated. It takes a long time to learn, and I felt like I was spending more time on the time management system than on actually working!Another author, Michael Linenberger, has taken the best of the ideas from this book and from others and built a very practical system. For an introduction, check out The One Minute To-Do List: Quickly Get Your Chaos Completely Under Control. You can get a free PDF of that book at the author's website (Google "Michael Linenberger"). But his Magnum Opus is Total Workday Control Using Microsoft®  Outlook. If you use Microsoft Outlook, this book is a must. He shows you the nitty gritty of actually using the system. If you don't use Outlook, check out the author's website for other ideas.Again, David Allen's book is good, and I recommend it. But Michael Linenberger distills these and other time management principles into a simple, practical system that you can actually use starting today.
Comment_Title: Great Ideas, Weak on Practical Implementation

Comment: This book is exactly what I needed and am looking forward to fully implementing the system and seeing a change in stress level.
Comment_Title: Should have read this book 10 years ago. It takes time management to a whole new level!

Comment: Full of very practical advice that completely changes how I relate to work and organization.  I'm implementing his processes (may take a little while to get the right habits in place) and already notice a big difference in a reduction of that vague sense that I'm forgetting something.  Too bad this isn't a required course in school.
Comment_Title: Read the book.  Take his advice.  Do it.

Comment: The method introduced in the book just works. It is simple and intuitive and made me so much better organized that it is hard to fully describe it with words. I honestly recommend the book.
Comment_Title: Awesome intuitive and simple method to get organized

Comment: This is a very good book for getting helpful and useful best practices on getting things done.  It is not just time management, but a practical and tested method to organize tasks to be done or put aside.

I tried to slog my way through this, but honestly it seemed much more complicated and time consuming to follow his advice than to do what I am already doing. I see lots of reviews that are in essence "just starting this...love it", but have not seen any of someone who has been using this system faithfully over an extended period of time. Would love to hear from someone who is actually sticking with it to know if it is worth my time to adopt the methodology.
Comment_Title: Has anyone actually been using this system for 6 months or more?

Comment: I read this book as I was juggling one of the busiest years of my life. It was definitely worth my energy; i learned a few very valuable tips for handling the constant stream of incoming tasks that can cause a lot of stress!

Really? This book talks about concepts and actions that any secretary would be aware of.  BTW, What's a secretary?  Lot's of basic common sense stuff with no ground breaking "Ah Ha" moments. Mentions the use of technology including a three level in-basket, VCRs, and Lotus Notes.  Lotus Notes??!!  Oh yes, and the Palm PDA.  Able to skip through much of it.  Wouldn't really recommend unless you've never had to work with more than one task. Two stars because I could download it on Kindle.

I'm half way thru the book and I'm already using the suggestions and techniques to GET THINGS DONE. The first chapter paid for the book as far as I am concerned. Easy read. Easy to implement. Highly recommended.
Comment_Title: Now I can really get things done!

Comment: Instead of being motivated, being scheduled, organized and then with time, habitual is a much better option.  This book that I read years ago has now become a cornerstone of my life and business.  I've bought this book for over a half dozen friends.
Wish I had read this years ago.  After several weeks, I can see a sustainable difference and look forward to continued relief from anxiety and keeping more of my commitments.
It is a very Easy to read book with easy to follow tips and techniques to organize your complete life.

With growing responsibility the ability to shuffle it all and keep track of it in my head was no longer enough.  I am surprised how well this works when applied.  The low stress, the productivity and the clearer mind are all great
Great ideas and solutions.  Just takes personal discipline to apply and stick with it.  I really like the 2 min. rule.

Nowadays lots of new management slogans arises such as scrum, kanban, lean..... Bu if you look inside, they don't give you real, useful help. I feel they are about just role playing games. However they are giving more accurate control for a running project perspective, but are not helping to YOU. GTD is just for the person, just for YOU, helping YOU.
Like all time management concepts, it's the actual "doing" that makes a difference. It takes some discipline to follow Allen's advice.

Getting Things Done is a fantastic read. I highly recommend it!The most important lesson I took from this book is that everything belongs on a list.Once you get tasks out of your head and onto paper you can stop worrying about them and start doing them.The author calls this clearing your mental RAM and having a mind like water.Another important skill is creating a single In basket for all tasks.Sure, some things are more important than others. But how can you achieve world peace when you haven't done the grocery shopping or changed the oil in your car?Finally, it's important to do what you can when you're surrounded by the materials you need. It doesn't do you any good to remember you need tuna packed in water when you're at the car wash.And if you're experiencing low energy, do something simple like replying to a couple of quick emails.This book has revolutionized my workflow and brought me a level of peace I didn't know was possible when balancing so many different roles.I give GTD my highest recommendation!
They are many unresolved issues both large and small that drain your mental energy and make you less effective.Clearing out junk and taking immediate action has helped me be more effective.

An excellent foundation for organizing your life, using simple, elegant ideas and eschewing elaborate tools. You can buy tools from David Allen's company if you want, but all you really need are an in-box, some file folders, a pen and paper. If you prefer a digital solution, GTD is system agnostic: it's the ideas and habits that create productivity, not the device or software. Highly recommended.
Comment_Title: Don't Think About Something More than Once. Capture the idea, consider the next action and complete it.

Comment: There are a few books that I read and then want to share.  Since I'm a highlighter, note taking type of reader, I have to buy a fresh copy if I like it enough to pass around.  So, I bought another copy of this book because I was speaking to a coworker who was having recurring dreams...dreams which pointed to being overwhelmed with work.  So, I was able to give her a gift of the book.Yup, it's that good.

I was used to use to do lists etc but itdid nit really work. The book helped me a lot to get it organised and I have things under control now for several months. It relaxes me and it is getting things done!Thanks for the input!Why not five stars? I see some point of possible improvement. Some more info on tools that can be used, the book is till to much in the paper age while I work almost complete paperless.

I have always been a busy person.  I keep my schedule full and had lists of things to do.  Getting Things Done gave me some of the best organizational and common sense ideas I have ever used.  I am so much more efficient now.  I can't recommend this for people enough.  I have bought several copies and given them to friends and neighbors.
this book is paradigm shift but a needed resource for anyone who wants to stay sane in this technology filled world!

I just recommended this book to my boss.  It's not just the common sense organizational system, it's the creation of a system to maintain control and if not eliminate, then alleviate a great deal of stress.  I really like the audio book - it's just better when you hear David speaking - it's nice that the audio syncs with the print book on my Kindle. I'm just getting started with the system and I'm loving it already - feels great!!
I hear this is a great book and a good way to get things done.  One of these days I might find the time to read it.
Comment_Title: Haven't had the  time to read it...

Comment: yup, and it has.  I have not even finished reading halfway through. I leave the rest a mystery. See and read it for yourself..

I heard David Allen interviewed on NPR and ordered the book right away. What a useful set of tools! And he offers the psychology behind it.I have a 3 month old and felt that things were getting beyond my control. This technique not only helped to regain control but it made the process fun.

Being a procrastinating, disorganized piler in a job full of interruptions, I needed help.  I encountered this book at a professional seminar at which a colleague presented the contents of this book.  It was just the thing I needed.  A simple system to externalize everything you are thinking about and find it again.  It's like recovering free space on your hard drive - suddenly the old processor is working smoothly again.  I honestly thought I was losing my mind until I started putting this book into practice and realized that it was not my mind but my clutter that was causing the confusion.  I'm not big on self-help and self-improvement, but I am giving copies of this book to busy friends and colleagues.  This book will teach you the value of two minutes, of a relaxed mind, of maintaining meaningful lists, of externalizing your thoughts, and of nudging projects to completion one "next thing" at a time.  Get this book and learn to work smarter.
Comment_Title: Get This Book, Get Things Done

Comment: The Getting Things Done method has absolutely increased my productivity and freed my mind to focus on more important things than remembering.To summarize this book, he suggests writing down everything that your brain is focusing on that "requires" next action.  He suggests a great workflow that has been refined over many years that works great for him.  Of course, you are free to adapt things to work best for you.Definitely going to give this book to all of my new hires at work.

David Allen gets the complexity of my world. I'm already implementing some if his strategies and seeing great results.. Easy to read and very motivating. Part II takes you through the implementation of the theories. I have already recommended it to friends and family.
Comment_Title: Straight forward, good, timely advice and strategies

Comment: I liked it. It was good. It met my expectations and provided some very good advice based on years of experience in this particular field. I would recommend.
I am currently using a variation of the system and so far I love it. Definitely recommend for managers at any level
Seller was quick, and item was in good shape.  This is a wonderful book for getting your stuff together.  I highly recommend it to anyone drowning in disorganization.

I give this 5 stars because of the simplicity of the system and the author's avoidance of pushing additional "stuff" that one "needs" in order to use this system. Too many books like this are trying to sell you their other stuff too. One just needs to read this book and maybe some paper and folders or Evernote or free native iPhone apps like calendar and reminders. The genius of getting all those things that constantly pop into one's head out and onto paper or an app to free up creativity and the headspace to think big is extremely valuable. He had a great TED Talk too.
Comment_Title: An inexpensive and simple system that works without costly "extras"

Comment: No doubt the best practical book to get started. Contains much outdated practices including rolodexes and manilla folders, but the smart reader will translate that to Evernote and Google Contacts. Great set-up approach to get started. I suggest the Time Trap to follow up with further advise.
This is a great book if you have a lot to do and want to live a free strees life
I love productivity books and have read many.  This one is my all-time favorite.  Kudos to David Allen for getting this book done.

I've read lots of time management articles and books but this one made it all start working.Very practical. Focused on "doing".I love the simplicity of his definition of a "project". I love the simplicity of his approach to doing them. Lots of smaller projects shouldn't be run with any more overheads than this. Lots of bigger projects could do with being split into smaller projects.
Comment_Title: What I've been looking for, for years

Comment: If you really need to be organized, this is your book. I was looking for this book for many years, without successful. This method is really easy to adapt your reality.
Comment_Title: The best book I ever read

Comment: I like this book as it is very informative and gives easy to follow instructions.Wish I had this a long time ago!The book was delivered swiftly and makes very good reading!
Comment_Title: very good and easy to follow instructions

Comment: The method and tips in the book are practical and very useful.  They seem simple but do take practice and discipline.  The examples are dated (e.g. references to the Palm) but remain applicable.  It would be nice to see it updated to reflect today's connected and high tech world.
I have not ffinished it yet but already applying aspects of it. Will usevit for a presentation at wok next month.
Comment_Title: very nice read and to the point

Comment: It's really one of the most useful books i've ever read on time management! And which makes me willing to apply what i learned from it!
And every time a find new gems of wisdom. Essential reading to feel in control and bring to the next stage of your personal and professional life.

I generally fall into the trap of purchasing these types of books and don't end up implementing them: I am too disorganised to follow most systems and my work has too much urgent stuff to handle.I have found this book different. It is easy to implement: it takes a big chuck of time but I felt that I was on top of things by the time I had finished. The methods given are also forgiving in that when I have been overwhelmed I have been able to take back control. I feel more productive. My staff have also noticed the difference; my office is clean and I deal with their stuff in a much more timely manner.I don't think if I could have implemented the system using a paper based approach. I have used a program called Nirvana (but there are other similar programs out there)I have been going for about two months; usually I last two days.I would recommend this book to anyone.
Comment_Title: it really helped a very disorganised guy

Comment: I bought this as I started an MFA program. It is extremely useful. Kindof a lifelong challenge to keep the practice going. But I do like how it focuses one to think of 'actions' rather than outcomes. It's been extremely helpful to me in the past several years. I use this method in combination with OmniFocus, which allows me to sync tasks from desktop to iphone seamlessly.
Comment_Title: Love the idea, the practice is hard

Comment: The idea is great but he could have said it in less than 30 pages. Repeats himself endlessly. In the end I just skimmed through in 30 minutes and got the gist.

A friend recommended this book so I took the plunge. It did inspire me to start using my legal pad lists again, but beyond that I found it impossible to finish the book because of the corporate audience its aimed at. Its full of talk about "meetings with your investment lawyer," "buying that speed boat," "planning your vacation tour" and "your frequent trips to Japan" etc. etc. etc. etc. If your world involves wearing a suit and tie and going to constant meetings you might like this book, but I don't live in that world and the small part of my life that dealt with that world left a really bad taste in my mouth, just being honest here. I agree with one reviewer that the book could have been 50 pages long or less and you would get the point. I got the feeling his publisher told him to write to fill up a certain amount of pages, so its alot of repetition. I'm self employed and I build things for musicians so the book didn't relate to my world at all. The final result? I now use 3 legal pads to keep track of what I need to. His organizational system is too complex for what I need so it at least made me think about doing a better job, but if you need this kind of inspiration and aren't a corporate clone living in a cubicle you might want to look for a different book, if you find one let me know.....

I *can* be organized, but often find myself very unorganized.  I was afraid I was getting adult onset ADD or something, but a friend suggested I get this book and see if it helped.  Oh my gosh!  Now, I won't use words like "miraculous" and "life-changing" but it is an amazing system, described with clarity, wit and compassion.  Very hands-on and doable, this is a system you can begin to implement at once, although it takes a lot of time and effort to get it fully going.  However, the time and effort pays off big time with increased efficiency and peace of mind.  And frankly, just reading a book that acknowledges and explains the problems I've been having with organization and getting things done has been worth the cost.  Now I know that it isn't *just me* who avoids tasks that are anxiety producing or who feels worse with piles of to-do lists.  I definitely would give this book and his system a try.
Comment_Title: Very Useful, will probably read again

Comment: This book has fundamentally changed the way I approach work and life for the better. I'm still learning and implementing some of the processes as well as developing my own but I can already feel the effects from reading the book twice. If you've ever felt overwhelmed with school, work, or life in general, try this book out.
Comment_Title: Should be required reading in the work place

Comment: Here you learn the essentials of GTD. If you knew it all before and did it by instinct: this is the compendium putting all into context.
The book is good and gives great tips on better organizing and pushing work forward. So far, its not much different that what I am already doing.
Comment_Title: Good principles, but not much new from what I do today

Comment: I am very happy that I worked my way through GTD and have a system that's vastly superior to my previous one.  I think Mr. Allen's advice is excellent.I would've given the book five stars, but I dislike the organization and bloat.  It's critical to optimize the amount of information packed into a document.  GTD could've been about 150 pages without losing any information.  The writing is "in laps."  Mr. Allen touches upon a subject for several pages, but that subject is _really_ treated later in the book.  That's OK if the preview sections are very short.  However, they're not in GTD.  They contain almost enough to implement the method.  To be honest, I was already implementing the system after no more than 80-100 pages.  As I read the later sections, I only found a few things that needed small adjustments.  Also, there are too many asides and plugs for previous success.  Just state in the intro that the system has been very successfully used hundreds (thousands?) of times, and then save words by not repeating such info again.GTD is a pretty laborious read.  It's simple, but the reader gets the idea that his time is being wasted, which is pretty ironic!

This is a must read for all entrepreneurs. This has definitely helped me to be more organized both in my personal life and business. I use David's techniques everyday when managing my companies' tasks.
Comment_Title: This has changed my life since the 1st time I read it!

Comment: Software tools can be helpful in time management, but if you want to be skilled at it, you have to have the strategy behind the use of those tools. This book is the source of learning the skill of time management.
...but Ben would have said only a few things, and left the rest for people to work out themselves.Good, solid, practical advice for getting things under control and done.
Comment_Title: As practical and common sense as Ben Franklin.

Comment: I like a lot of the principles in this book for getting organized. But it goes just a little too far in the obsessive nature of the tasks, and there's not really a lot about how to keep yourself organized and calm when your boss, your colleagues and your reports are all insane (not to mention your clients!) and doing everything they can to destroy your well laid plans.

My BS meter is highly trained, and this book isn't BS. Just solid advice that can be applied not just to CEOs but working artists, students, or pretty much anyone who feels overwhelmed by their to do list. Highly recommended.
In this fast paced world we really must learn to reduce stress and this book is  my beginning to a life with much less stress and way more productivity!

Mr. Allen must have been unusually well organized without focus, attention, or concentration issues before he wrote Getting Things Done. I have no doubt if one follows the advice methodically, it leads to a mind like still water.  Anyone who can follow a system like this without deviating from it very often doesn't have trouble getting things done in the first place. if paying attention and creating systems are problems to begin with, a workable system might be ten pages, or ten lines, not ten chapters. I really tried to follow the system and still do use individual parts of it from time to time, but its way too hard for people with "issues".  If you get things done now, this system will likely make it easier to get things done. If you aren't productive, i would suggest a much simpler plan.
Comment_Title: if you can implement the system, you don't need it

Comment: On the good side - it seems to be a great system, I started to implement it myself and already feel myself much better organized and relaxed aftewards.On the worse side - I found it really difficult to get through its jungle of pages. One could probably condense it to like 30% of its size, making it much easier to read. It seems like 70% of the book is sort of motivational part where the author is persuading readers how great the system is and why it should be implemented. I personally felt a bit like - Ok, I got it already, what's the next thing! So the bits of true wisdom are spread very thinly across the pages.
It is a Must To Read book, for the first chapter i feel the change,specialy the tust buket concept.
This book was a gift and he has not read it yet. It was recommended by an ADD website. I hope he gets the motivation to read it sometime.
What a great book if you are feeling overwhelmed and unorganized.  A step-by-step approach in getting things done and feeling less stress!
Comment_Title: Got too much in your head? Feeling overwhelmed?  Read this.

Comment: I searched the web for some books on productivity. I was desperate. I could not find an easily readable and affordable book. I searched again. This time one book on Amazon attracted me. It is the book I was in search of. It is 'How to Get Things Done' by David Allen. I went through some pages and ordered the book before the expected arrival date. Thank you Amazon.This is a book which you can read and implement 5S system in your home/office/company. I am new to Kaizen but I learnt many things after reading the book. The contents are very applicable if you want to achieve higher productivity. You can eliminate waste and systematize your work. Allen talks about stress free productivity in his book. His argument is that anyone can get his/her work done. Further, he believes that much of our work is complicated for we do not pay attention to such things as ergonomics and work place cleanliness. Anything that may result in waste or redundancy may be prevented if careful planning is done. Major topics in the Part 1 include:1. A New Practice for a New Reality2. Getting Control of Your Life: The Five Stages of Mastering Workflow3. Getting Projects Creatively Underway: The Five Phases of Project PlanningThese are the initial lessons you may read and get ready for the rest of the lessons. In the Part 1, you see the possibilities while in the other chapters you can taste some of the simplest things you can do to achieve higher productivity. You can easily digest the ideas as Allen's language is simple and easy to understand.The lessons, though they look simple make you reorganize your schedules and help better your understanding in areas where waste is likely to occur. I began applying simple ideas from the book and am in control of my work. He asks us to practice a little at a time and see the difference it makes. I am getting much free time now.The book is truly amazing. The book is truly thought provoking. The book is simply the best if you are into reorganizing schedules to have more free time. He says that time is money and that everyone should save time for greater enjoyment of life. He takes us to Japanese life. He gives examples from Japanese lives and advises us to practice ideas from the land of Kaizen. Kaizen ideas in this book are easy to comprehend, the language used is simple and ideas are worth practicing.`Your home is the paradise of the book worm.' said one of my students. I was puzzled to understand what the student said. It is a negative comment on how I had placed my books in my home. They were everywhere. On the dining table, in the bedroom, on chairs and even under my mattress. I was ashamed and immediately looked for a way to be organized. I am getting organized. True. I like practicing what Allen says. He changed my habits of being disorganized, not sorting things into useful and useless, and my dear friends, my home is spacious and livable now.The writer is a productivity specialist and he is a guru as well. I really like the ideas in it. Some ideas are so strong that you may implement them soon. They are eye openers and they help you better your life.Read the book. The book does not waste your time instead it helps you organize your work and save time and gives a greater sense of achievement once you begin to apply the ideas in the book. I truly enjoy organizing and making my home a place where there is less waste, things are nicely arranged, useless things are thrown away. Your friends will be amazed too.Susil Manchanayaka, B. A., PGDE, PGC T&HRD

There are some good ideas in this book and some that go too far and seem a bit too over the top and anal for me. I took the ones that I found useful and incorporated them into my life and I discarded the ones that didn't work for me. I think that's really the only way to use these types of books. I know some people who feel like they have to incorporate everything in a book and then end up being even more stressed out and disorganized because they're trying to so hard to make their life fit the "system", instead of taking parts of the system and making them fit your life.
very out of date for todays world.  You can apply some principles but many will not apply in today tech world

I would recommend this book to anyone who has more than just a few obligations, whether those obligations are personnel or professional, to ones self or to others.  I do not have this fully implemented yet but I have already noticed results.  I have many more days that end with feelings of accomplishments. Even though my lists are still long I have far fewer last minute emergencies due to forgetting a commitment I made to someone or myself. Wish I had read this book years ago.

The book requires attention and understanding to heed real action. It's great source for small ideas even if you're not implementing the full idea of GTD.  I personally failed GTD after the first reading - after the second reading I started from the simple things after learning the philosophy underneath - the important message is the mind play.  A strong recommend for this book :-)
Comment_Title: Managing to survive has never been this organized.

Comment: One of the best books on self-organization. I'm still using some adapted version of the techniques described here, and have offloaded lots of information from my head to a digital task list.
Comment_Title: Helped me to structurize my life

Comment: Fantastic and practical guide to really improving productivity. I have learnt some really great tips and I am now Getting it Done!
Set a aside a day or two to read this book and begin to act on its concepts. If you have areas in your life that are not organized like me, this book will help.
Comment_Title: Great book on organizing work and life

Comment: Between This, 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, 4 Hour Work Week, and The Art of War I've found one of the best combinations of (actually useful) time management as well as a kind of life advice. David Allen's book "Getting Things Done" has some great ideas in it about how to get organized and become a more effective worker. I won't go into all of the reasons why this is true; there are hundreds of other reviews that explain it. The main problem with this book is that so much of it is fluff and unnecessary. Allen most likely couldn't get his book published at under 100 pages, so he stuffed it with unneeded fluff so that it would fill out an entire book. My advice is to focus on a few sections, rather than the whole book.Read:Ch. 2 (p. 24-53) - An overview of his systemCh. 4 (p. 85-103) - What you'll needCh. 5 (p. 103-118) - The "Collection" phaseCh. 6 (p. 119-137) - The "Processing" phaseCh. 7 (p. 138-180) - The "Organizing" phaseCh. 8 (p. 181-190) - The "Reviewing" phaseThe above 135 pages are what you should read.  The sections I recommend skipping are: Ch. 1, which explains why organization is important, Ch. 3, which explains the basics of brainstorming, Ch. 9, which explains the self-explanatory "Doing" phase, and Ch. 10-13, which just reiterates everything again.If you know which parts are useful and which are not, reading this book is a lot more enjoyable.
I am liking so much this book. I recomed it for everyone that wants to improve your productivity. Great book!
I bought 2 copies to pass around the office. There is a waiting line for them! Practical, useful and sensible.

I first read the book several years ago, and I implemented some of the recommendations - but didn't really stick with it.  Fast forward to 2012 and I found myself drowning in projects with no end in sight.  I had loaned the book to a friend and decided that it was just the fix I needed.  I re-read it and this time I implemented the recommendations with determination!  The gathering and purging section gave me hope - and the organization and implementation sections gave me back (most of) my sanity!My ability to stay focused and get things done has increased substantially!  The ideas behind the projects and next action items keep me focused and aware of what I need to do far better than any other system I've seen!
This is a great book. The book has got me starfted on clreasring up things at work & home.I got the Kindle edition. I like this version because I can look for specific topics easily.

Comment_Title: Good ideas, but basically common sense.

I find that it's a little outdated, especially since the iPad does so many of the things that used to be done on paper.

When thinking about it, methods to organize and structure your work are about as important as domain knowledge, or even intelligence for that matter. And this topic is completely ignored in schools or companies. The book helped me tremendously, and in combination with a paper file folder, and a digital system based on Evernote, I was able to change the way I work for the better. And David is right, it frees up your mind for other activities like reading or real thinking...I did not give a 5 star rating as the book is structured a little awkward for first time readers. The basic organizing structure is only explained in the second half of the book, which makes the first half difficult to read.

I was impressed by David Allen's thoroughness in not only HOW ... but WHY people could ... and should ... get themselves more personally organized and prioritized.  He presents a seriously complete system of organization, more than I could keep up with or even follow.  (maybe I'm too disorganized!)I found that reading this book was personally empowering for me ... like being given some good tools, some of which are quite inexpensive or even free, AND being given the Users Manual to actually use them.  And, I found the book to be so absolutely stuffed with information about how to "Get Things Done" that I never got completely through it.  But what I learned and have used have been helpful every day .If you want to learn to organized and prioritize one or two areas of your life, or if you desire a complete "makeover," this is the book for you.

Comment_Title: very good to organize the complex brain

Comment: I've been gradually switching over to the "Getting Things Done" (GTD) system for four months now. I've completely redone my study to work with this system. I had already figured out some of it for myself before I got the book, but there was a great deal more that really made a difference.I quickly became aware that most software that is meant to handle your to-dos is totally inadequate for use with the GTD system, so when I got a new iPod for Christmas, I bought "Toodledo" for my to-do management. Its entire structure is built around the GTD system. WOW! What a difference!I also bought a new front end for the "Calendar" that comes with the iPod. It's called "PocketLife." It enters all its data into the same database that the original Calendar uses, so anything entered with "PocketLife" also appears in "Calendar." It gets backed up the same way.It overcomes a weakness in the original "Calendar." It now allows me to enter events of the type that occur on the fourth Thursday of April, or on the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November (election day).

I don't read a lot of books of this ilk-- but I decided to stop struggling with inventing my own personal organization system (which all failed for a variety of reasons) and just get a thorough view of one system that works for a lot of people (and was supported by the piece of software I was already using).This edition of the book (I understand there are others) was a cost-conscious purchase-- I just wanted something to Kindle and tear through in a few days.Much of the book feels like it was written about a decade-and-a-half ago-- computers exist in the world, but are not as prevalent or as reliable, making much of the practical/literal practice seem woefully out-of-date (and meaning you would have to do your own work to make the system work in the modern world-- fortunately, many people seem to have done a lot of work adapting it).Most useful, however, are the insights gleaned from the experience of getting people organized. How many tiny "truisms" show up in this book are what makes the difference between this being a pointlessly out-of-date user's manual for a dead technology and a timeless insight into the kinds of things that trip human beings up, regardless of the system they use.The thoughtful insights seem to be sprinkled throughout the front two-thirds of the book, and then dumped generously in the back third, in a cohesive view of why these tiny truisms make a difference and the impact they have-- in ways you can either readily understand from your own experience, or can test immediately.If you're interested in a straight-forward guidebook that you would take out to the store (to buy supplies) and then follow to the letter, I would not recommend this book (or this edition of it-- there may be a more modern one).If you're more interested in the "failings" of human beings as they relate to all the stuff they have to remember/do/accomplish and then see how one person solved man of those problems, I would highly recommend it.
Comment_Title: Somewhat dated, but insightful in its understanding of the principles

I challenge all the people who left a bad review to try this program - in its entirety - for two weeks and see what a difference it makes.To address a few complaints posted by other reviewers:Complaint: "It only helps if you're already organized."Counter argument: I'm by nature very organized, and this system has me getting more done, more quickly, with less stress, than I ever imagined possible.Complaint: "It only helps if you AREN'T already organized."Counter argument: If you think you're already organizezd and super productive, you wouldn't have bought this book. I challenge you to TRY the program before you knock it; reading about the program isn't enough basis for judgment. Seriously.Complaint: "It's repetitive."counter argument: IMO the book is repetitive because it mimics sitting down with David Allen and having him walk you through the process as though you were a client and he was sitting in your office coaching you. Some of his ideas are new and run contrary to what we've been told all our lives (e.g. we've been taught by Franklin Covey to do Daily To Do lists -- which never works -- and David explains why). It takes time to write out a cogent argument for why GTD is better in these areas.Complaint: "It doesn't teach you how to prioritize what to do."Counter argument: No book can teach you whether it's more important to call your kids' teacher right now, or to answer a customer service e-mail. Sounds like one of hte excuses I used when I was procrastinating and trying to justify why I wasn't getting things done. Allen puts you in the driver's seat. If you need help figuring out what's most important to do, you need more help than a book can provide.Complaint: "It reads like an advertisement for his consulting services."Counter argument: I've read the book three times, and I really don't get that complaint. He tells you exactly what to do, how to make the program work for you; if he was advertising his services, he'd keep some of his solutions close to the vest.Complaint: "It doesn't motivate you do actually do the things on your list."Counter argument: It doesn't claim to make you WANT to do your commitments. And he has a good discussion in the book of how to only put things you want to do on your list (by evaluating your long-term desires and objectives periodically).My Review:This is a great system that is revolutionary in its simplicity. It's easy to remember, easy to follow on a daily basis, and has fulfilled the goal of its title: Stress-Free Productivity.You might have to read it twice before all the pieces fit together, but isn't a system that can give you peace of mind in your work life worth that investment?

I have been a Getting Things Done enthusiast since I first read the book close to a decade ago.  I was working in a corporate environment and successfully used this system for my work.  Then I stayed home to have kids and I just didn't have enough brain power left to figure out how GTD could work at home; babies are by nature unpredictable!  I did eventually find someone who broke it down for moms and I changed everything.  Now that I'm working from home for ACS, I find that Getting Things Done is finally fully working for me.Getting Things Done is essentially a productivity book.  I've read dozens of productivity books over the years and none of them are like this one.  The biggest difference is that it doesn't JUST tell you how to prioritize, or how to manage your email.  Instead David Allen sets up a decision-making framework for dealing with EVERYTHING that rolls around in your brain.  There is a little bit of organizational detail in dealing with your email and paper, but he describes a whole different way of thinking about your life.In the first section, he speaks to people just like you and I -- people whose responsibilities are numerous and flow over the boundaries of "work" and "home" since both can happen at anytime.  He shares an overview of both his system for all the items that we have to process in a day and his system for working on projects that require more than one step.The second part is the gem of the book.  Once he's explained an overview of the system, then he gets down to the nuts and bolts of how it works.  First, he shares how to set up your time, space and tools.  It does require some work, I won't lie.  But it is SOOOOOOOO worth the effort.  And once you set it up and get used to how it works, if you fall off the wagon it's not as big a deal.  It doesn't require quite so much time to set back up because it totally changes how you think about things-even if you are not fully utilizing it, I bet some of your processes will stay set up that way.  Ask me how I know. Ahem.  Then he shares how to corral all your stuff (collection), processing it all, and organizing it efficiently.  These are the sections that tell you how to deal with your mail, email, phone calls, etc.He goes on to talk about reviewing your system, which is a huge component that lets you keep all those balls you juggle in the air.  No other book I've ever read has talked about the importance of this.  He also talks about making the best choices (Doing) and a little more about projects.  In the last section, he discusses the importance of the collection, next-action and outcome focusing habit.  It's kind of a high-level overview of how and perhaps more importantly, WHY, you are doing all the processes he outlines in section two.Long story short, I highly recommend this book.  If you frequently find yourself forgetting things or not getting to things you want to do or even are having trouble balancing "work" and "home," this book could change your life.  It's not just an organization, "here's how to set up your filing system" kind of a book.  It's more of a here's how to live life and do as much of the good stuff (Quadrant 1  for the FC fans) as possible kind of a book.  Really, really fabulous and essential for business owners who are trying to run a business, manage employees, raise kids, work on committees and just do as much as possible in a day.  Getting Things Done is the book for you!- See more at:[...]

Comment: Being a procrastinator, I was looking for something to help me get stuff done. For me there was a lot of stress involved with procrastinating. Now I have some tools to help me get stuff done.

There are so many books out there that purport to make you more efficient, waste less time, get better results, etc.  The majority of them vastly oversell themselves.  "Getting Things Done" is not one of those.  This book is a quick read, with some extremely easy to follow steps, and has improved my work and personal life immeasurably.Prior to reading this book I had a massive problem, like many people, with procrastinating at work and forgetting things to do at home.  Having read this book, taken the steps onboard, and used Evernote to manage my various lists, I am getting the things done at home that used to drive the Mrs crazy when I'd forget, and I am getting so much more done during office hours at work, that I don't know how I wasn't fired from previous jobs before reading this book!I cannot recommend this book highly enough.  I've bought multiple copies of "Getting Things Done" since I read it to give to family members, and everyone that reports to me at work.  I've yet to hear of anyone who read this and didn't come away with some actionable steps to take in their life to cut down on procrastinating and inefficient to-do lists, etc.A great book.Total read time: about 3 hours.

"Getting Things Done" by David Allen is a guide to enhancing the workflow management process - those actions that are undertaken to collect, process, organize, review, and act upon open commitments that enter our lives. Many of the things that he discusses are things we already do everyday, like recording a time sensitive action into a calendar for example, but he deeply explores every aspect of a whole system that it is nearly impossible to not walk away from reading this book without identifying flaws and improving upon our own systems. He warns that a flawed system taxes our mental energies by using it for lower level thinking. "I suggest that you use your mind to think about things, rather than think of them. You want to be adding value as you think about projects and people, not simply remind yourself they exist. To fully realize that more productive place, you will need to capture it all." (233)The collection phase is how we capture all the "stuff" that we have some sense to act upon someday. Allen recommends a complete physical audit of our surroundings and mental mind sweep looking for things that are out of place or represent an open commitment that you've made to yourself. "You need to collect and gather together placeholders for or representations of all the things you consider incomplete in your world--that is, anything personal or professional, big or little, of urgent or minor importance, that you think ought to be different than it currently is and that you have any level of internal commitment to changing." (26)  These open commitments are agreements that we have made with ourselves at one point or another.  "But what are all those things in your in-basket? Agreements you've made with yourself. Your negative feelings are simply the result of breaking those agreements-- they're the symptoms of disintegrated self-trust." (227)Processing is the act of thinking about what the item is and determining whether it is an action or non-action item.  Depending on whether it is an action item or a non-action item, your left with several options as to how to later organize it. Some key rules for processing include doing the top item first, processing only one item at a time, and not allowing anything to go back into the inbox. "When you're in processing mode, you must get into the habit of starting at one end and just cranking through items one at a time, in order. As soon as you break that rule, and process only what you feel like processing, and in whatever order, you'll invariably begin to leave things unprocessed. Then you will no longer have a functioning funnel, and it will back up all over your desk and office."(122)The organization phase is where you place an action or non-action item within the system. "For non-actionable items, the possible categories are trash, incubation tools, and reference storage. If no action is needed on something, you toss it, "tickle" it for later reassessment, or file it so you can find the material if you need to refer to it at another time. To manage actionable things, you will need a list of projects, storage or files for project plans and materials, a calendar, a list of reminders of next actions, and a list of reminders of things you're waiting for." (Pp 35)In the review phase, it is important to cultivate a habit of reviewing your calendar and next actions list daily and doing at least a weekly review of everything else.The purpose of this workflow is to facilitate decisions that will make you more productive by doing.  Allen provides several models for making decisions about our actions. These models put our actions into context of priorities in life. "At the end of the day, in order to feel good about what you didn't get done, you must have made some conscious decisions about your responsibilities, goals, and values. That process invariably includes an often complex interplay with the goals, values, and directions of your organization and of the other significant people in your life, and with the importance of those relationships to you." (195)Everything discussed here so far is referred to by Allen as "horizontal" thinking which is the primary thrust of "Getting Things Done".  There were a few chapters dedicated to "vertical" thinking where he discusses the importance of project planning and provides some useful exercises for more introspection on life and purpose. "Choose one project that is new or stuck or that could simply use some improvement. Think of your purpose. Think of what a successful outcome would look like: where would you be physically, financially, in terms of reputation, or whatever? Brainstorm potential steps. Organize your ideas. Decide on the next actions. Are you any clearer about where you want to go and how to get there?" (59)"Getting Things Done" is a systematic approach to handling that daily minutia that occupies our minds. The system allows you to capture everything and review it on your own terms rather than allowing it to command your attention.  Overall, it is about installing "tricks" in one's life to be highly productive.  "To a great degree, the highest performing people I know are those who have installed the best tricks in their lives. I know that's true of me. The smart part of us sets up things for us to do that the not-so-smart part responds to almost automatically, creating behavior that produces high-performance results. We trick ourselves into doing what we ought to be doing."(85)
Seriously?  The advise here appear to be - in my opinion, "make a list, review the list, do whats on the list."  Um, yeah, I got that part.
Comment_Title: Well, if you dont know what a list is

Comment: GTD has revolutioned my life after being buried in 6000 unread mails I have recovered control by applying the GTD simple method! Recommended!
Great book. Practical insights. I review parts of it for reminders. It has improved my office mess and reduced stress factors.

Very helpful, glad I purchased it. The process can be applied to virtually any field, from home life to career. Nice flow charts. A little slow to get into the actual application steps, but worth the read.

Great book. Immediately applicable.Good and practical information and tips. Useful.The only negative comment is that he did not bring it into the digital age. Now a lot of tools exist to apply GTD in practice.

Watching peers at work incorporate these techniques inspired me to give the book go.  I am confident this system is going to change my thinking about what I want to accomplish and how to take action to get there: I have just begun practicing what I have learned and I am seeing positive results.  Excitingly, in the depth of my thoughts as much as the efficiency of my day to day.

I love this book and putting the David Allen processes and ideas into practice. I already had a hardcopy of the book but found that I wanted another (an eBook) so that I can have a copy with me all the time to reference anytime.
Good gift for hubby.  Bought after hearing about it on radio show. Decent price..worth the cash.  Good tips and advice.

Following the suggestions outlined in this book has helped me to organize a previously overwhelming stack of paperwork.  After a year of reading it and referring to it I find that I am living a life that is much more organized.

It has changed my of working and, hopefully, will lead me to the promised land of organised, well prepared work.I have cleared my work email inbox, something I never thought would happen. In fact, I thought my work email inbox would eventually reduce me to a mumbling incompetent.
Comment_Title: It has changed my way of working
