Comment: ideas are good, I am trying it... we shall see how i do at the end of the year.  But the writing is a bit roundabout, compared to the very clear processes Mr. Allen was putting forth in how to clean up your act.

Definitely helped me with managing stress by externalizing a lot of my to-do's. However, he takes a massively long and tedious approach to explaining anything and everything, and after a while, I just wish I'd gotten an abridged version.
Comment_Title: Good Points in overly long format

Comment: I have read and reviewed this book too many times to count. Diagnosed with ADD, this book and the methods contained within have helped me avoid some of the painful pitfalls of my "disorder". This review alone never would have happened without having been captured into my system. If you are here it is likely because you know there are improvements that could be made to your system too. Do yourself a favor and read it, it could make a huge difference in your life as it has in mine.

The core principles in the book are good  & useful. But most of this seems to be written just so it could become a book and make money. Everything that's useful in this could be told in 20 pages... or 10.
Comment_Title: Good principles, but un-necessary waste of paper.

Comment: In this age of over scheduling, over commitment and multi-tasking, Allen offers a completely practical and simple way to bring order to one's work, office and peace of mind. In it's way, this is the ultimate self-help book. The downside is that his writing, although witty and erodite, is sometimes difficult to apprehend. His theoretical explanation prior to getting down to the nuts and bolts of what to do is almost too long. On the other hand, his explication and examples of the actual system are very clear. They produce a sense of hope in readers who need help getting organized.
Comment_Title: Why isn't this still a best seller

Comment: I didn't realize that this book had been in print for more than a decade. Wish I had known about it then. Helps challenge you to think about tasks and organization in a completely different way. I now use Evernote on my iPhone for my Next Actions List and other lists, etc., and my email inbox is much more quickly managed (albeit, my personal email!). A bit lengthy of a read but worth it.
Comment_Title: Wish I'd found this book years ago

Comment: This book gave me the framework to be able to manage all the intricacies of a new job that not only had demanding deadlines, but a boss who had no concept of time management.  Without this book I would have been a wreck with ulcers because of all of the tasks I had to keep track of.If you're looking to help yourself get a handle on your work and life, read the book.  I recommend reading it all the way through once, then going back and working through it.  It sure helped me.

This book should be assigned to every college grad before they begin their first office (or academic) job.  It concisely explains the procedures for "getting things done," and holds up amazingly well.  Many of Mr. Allen's observation from the early 2000's were spot on, and his system was developed accordingly.
Comment_Title: Required reading for modern office work

Comment: I've just finished reading it and am eager to try the author's techniques.  I like that I don't need to be a high tech person to implement this book.
Comment_Title: I think this book just may transform my life!

Comment: One of the worst I've ever been through in the self-help genre. Most of the book is spent detailing a fantastically complex filing system. Remarkably lacking in helpful advice. Allen spends a lot of time bragging about the executive clients he has worked with. I can only say I pity anyone so unfortunate as to attempt to improve his life by meeting with Allen. Don't waste your money on this turkey.
If you want a modern version of this text, check out anything that Lifehacker has written. This book is very dated.

If you are reading this, it is likely that you are trying to find ways to better manage your life by being organized.  This book will get you there, without doubt.  What you are less likely to have thought about (I know that I hadn't) is how fundamentally life-altering the change in front of you might be.I am an information worker whose project list topped 250 items when I first inventoried them all.  I falsely believed that I could make up for a lack of organization with intelligence.  I was stressed and unfocused, and working at less than ten percent of my potential.  I would frequently escape work into web-browsing or other distraction just because of how unmanageable the meta-data of my work had become.Thanks to the systems that David presents in this book, I can spend just a few minutes a day managing 'what I should do' against 'what I want to do' and the rest of the time I can spend actually DOING things - or not doing things without being overwhelmingly stressed about it.  Thanks to these systems, nothing that I want to remember is ever more than a few seconds away.This book is liberating, and I hope that everyone reads and implements it fully.

A friend recommended this book and she was right.  The principles Allen develops are easy to understand and apply no matter what your position in life, from high-powered executive to retiree (like me).  I found that I already do a lot of what he talks about already, and as a result of reading this book, my apartment is tidier and my projects are getting done.  A lot of the more complex stuff doesn't apply to my situation, so just skip over those bits.  I now know what I want to do and how much I am willing to take on.
I loved this book.  I highlighted and tabbed plenty of pages.  I bought several copiues for people in my office.  It is very good for high shool and college students as well.

I used to find myself overplanning, only to have things change and finding myself re-planning out everything (which was very time consuming). David Allen's system is great for flexibility, and it really gives you peace of mind. I didn't follow the whole system, but I follow most of it and as a college student it has significantly freed up time.I would recommend reading through Getting Things Done, then listening to 5by5's "Back to Work" podcast, which supplements the book very well (only a few episodes are on GTD, check late-90s). Additionally, I would recommend getting OmniFocus as a more modern-day alternative to some of David Allen's approaches (as this book is pretty outdated technology-wise).

I've been using GTD (Getting Things Done) for many years now.  I've given this book as a gift and read it occasionally myself to remind myself of the principles.  I've seen some reviews that talk about a dearth of content.  I could not disagree more.  People learn differently and some will get the point quickly while others need more repetition and/or clarification.This is probably the most important methodology change I've made in my work and personal life.  You can do this on paper with no technology investment.  Pair it with tools like Evernote or Outlook and it's dynamite.  (I love Evernote!).

This book has proven to be invaluable to me.... it is priceless... I never thought that I would be so motivated to process everything around me...  This book has not only changed and improved my work productivity but it has also found it's way into my home life as well... the Clutter is gone!... everything has a place and everything is in it.  ;)  You can't afford not to get this book!  You will read it once and then want to read it again.... I am now one of David Allen's Biggest Fans...
Comment_Title: OMG!  This Book Has Changed My LiFE!!!!

Comment: GTD is a an excellent system for personal organizing - your time, your priorities, your life!  I've personally really embraced this system of Getting Things Done.  Well written, covers the highest level down to the very tactical aspects of life!

David Allen has written a treatise on how to get the million ideas out of your head, onto paper/computer, catagorized, and a methodology for getting to YOUR to-do list. Take notes, cogitate on how it will work for you, implement it, then review the material later to better get a handle on his system. Recommend using the "ToodleDo" app so you can carry your list on your iPhone as well as have it on your computer.
Comment_Title: Finally a book that makes sense

Comment: Although it's a book of 10 year, it's in good condition. No missing pages, no scratches, no tears. A good choice.
Comment_Title: The book is in good condition

Comment: I had the paperback and just bought the kindle version, so I can easily reread it where ever I am. I like most of his techniques for staying organized and on track Though, I am not usually into lists and  had a hard time using written to-do tracking, I  find David Allen's approach very useful and thus motivating. I use every day (almost).
This is my second copy of GTD in 2 years.  It's been a huge help in getting control of all the "stuff" I have to do and it's even better the second time around.

One of those books that changes your life, especially if you're Type A, a procrastinator, or a worrier. The methods described in the book are a bit outdated, especially for the younger crowd, but the principles are solid gold.Being a hardcore productivity nerd, I've found this to be the best book on the subject. In short, the GTD philosophy is this: your brain is a terrible place to keep things you need to do. If you remember them at all, you'll remember them in the wrong place. For example, you remember that the flashlight needs new batteries when you pick up the dead flashlight, not when you're at Walmart and could buy them. Your brain becomes very stressed out by knowing you have things to do, so it's actively trying to remember all of them all the time, not just when you need the information. (Why this philosophy is great for people who worry or are anxious!) The idea is that you need to get everything out of your head and written down in a system you trust; one you will review regularly and be able to trust it won't lose the information (or make it hard to find). That's it.Personally, I implement the system with a physical inbox at home and at work, Remember the Milk for lists accessible on all my devices, and Google Calendar for appointments. I'm currently experimenting with using Wunderlist to gather my "keep in mind" lists, such as a bucket list and writing topics. The initial purge of information from my brain was one of the best feelings ever. I sat down and just wrote pages and pages of things that needed to be done.Read reviews of GTD methods and see what you think would work best for you, then try a couple of them. For ideas on how to implement GTD, the blog Lifehacker is a great resource, both for reviews of tools for the system (such as RTM, Producteev, Orchestra, Wunderlist, etc) and little things to make those tasks easier. (Best blog EVER.)
Comment_Title: Changed my life - Great for Type As, procrastinators, worriers, and the anxious

Comment: I decided to purchase this book after seeing references to it by users of Evernote. I find it to be very relateable and informative.

It was an interesting book. I agree with many of the ideas in the book. Still, I feel it is based for executives working in a cooperate office. I think it would be nice to have something similar geared toward people working in smaller businesses or just for getting things done at home.

This book is full of filler content instead of actual useful content. It spends a lot of time talking about how people usually handle a situation or how someone normally plans out a project. I would rather the book spend more time talking about the right way to plan a project and give examples, or include more examples on how to organize a list of things.I could also do without the first chapter which just discusses why the author wrote the book. I'd rather the author just get down to the facts, I don't have time to read through all the frivolous content, I want just the facts when I read a book like this.
Comment_Title: Spends too much time discussing what people do

Comment: The book can easily be skimmed at a quick pace, and one need not finish it in it's entirety before benefits start kicking in!
Have not implemented this system as I'm still reading the book but I'm eager to give it a try. It's a solid system!

"Mind like water." Yeah, that's what I'm going for. I've never been organized in all aspects of my life and David Allen's process of Getting Things Done has put me on that path. So much stuff that I kept in my "psychic RAM" is now downloaded and in an external system--oh, and everything else in my open-loops too. This frees my mind to be more zen-like and creative. "What's the next action?" If you read this book, you'll always have the answer close at hand.

I bought this for my husband who is a fan of these type of management/leadership/productivity books.His review:  Hands down, worst book ever, absolutely worthless.  A significant portion of the book is about the author's philosophy.  The suggestions made were obvious to the point of being silly.
This is a great book, it truly helped me become more productive. The read was a little slow at first, but I found I could implement certain tips and come back and read more later.

this book is full of valuable advice about getting organised that you may intuitively know are true but gave not been able to implement. I would recommend this book to all people working in an office environment.
My whole office uses this book - great gift for colleagues or young professionals. I use this as a reference book rather than reading it from cover to cover, but lots of useful tips.

I got the audio book and continue to listen to certain sections over and over to drum them into my head.  using a lot of the strategies to clear my desk and mind and reduce anxiety.  Especially like the tip that if you have having trouble filling in action steps it might be that you haven't developed your plan enough - time to go back to brainstorming.
Comment_Title: Very helpful if you have a hankering for productivity

Comment: This book is good if you need to get organized in your life, be it at home or at work.
help me a lot and I start to be organizedrecommend young people read this excellent bookgood luck with it
I am quite organized but still found useful recommendations to implement and make my work and life easier to manage.
I am only on page 35 and I have gleaned an amazing amount of helps.  I am working hard at reorganizing my office.

I am a diagnosed ADD/OCD.  I've tried a lot of things to get through life.  A few things work, that is, to some extent.  I'm not a big fan of self help books, but when I saw this book mentioned in the Atlantic by James Fallows, a respected writer, I thought I'd take a look.  To describe this system of Getting Things done in a few words, I'd say it's system to get all the things you must worry about, think about, plan for, etc., out of your mind, conscious and subconscious, and get them written down in an orderly manner so they will be dealt with on time and in an orderly manner (and so that you will not forget them).  The big secret is this:  if everything is organized and recorded safely so you need not worry about overlooking or forgetting something, you don't worry about anything other than what's in front of you, and you get that done.  Tall order, but it works, and I'd say for a lot, if not most, people.  It's well worth trying even if you ony partially implement it.The clincher for me was that, out the outset, he described my mind to a T, always crammed with must do's, like to do's, and surprises.  And I found, to my surprise, that I have used some of his techniques myself in trying to cope wiht ADD and trying to keep sane.  I came up with them on my own trying to deal with my ADD.  I was so impressed with the book that I'm trying to implement the entire system, and it seems to be working.If you've got more than you can handle, and if you can't focus on one thing because you're worrying about 20 others, give this book a read.  It's an easy read, but he's a little repetitive and verbose at times.  Nonetheless, worth your time.

This is such a good book, some months later I am using many of the principles in this book.  Will probably read at regular intervals to catch up.  Took a note to check out a website so I can get any updated info.

Though I know most of the principles behind good organization I found I don't have a good approach to STAYING organized.  That is where Getting Things Done shone for me.  It is well written, concise and not only inspired me to make some changes but showed me how to start.  I'm finding the methods quite useful and not overly complicated to pull together.  Highly recommend!

This book is very well written and talks about organization and how we as people function on a basic level with multiple tasks.  He writes this book from personal experiences and working with hundreds of individuals.  Some people found his references antagonistic but I felt they were all worth wile and aided in the explanation.  If you are looking for a book that can help you organize and become more stress free then this is it!
Comment_Title: Great Book For People Who Have To Much To Do

Comment: How can the Kindle version possibly cost more than the paper version. You have all of the same costs minus printing, shipping, and storage. This is a glaring ripoff.

If I had money to buy only one book, I would buy this one. It's a real treasure, and I think everybody should read it. I regret I didn't know all those priceless tips when I was 18.Thank you very much, David!

This book is a must-have. David Allen really nailed it down on how to get organized. It is a fantastic tool if you are like me, trying to get things done, hoping you don't forget something important and somehow try to have an overwiew of your work and personal life. Try it. Nothing to lose.
Comment_Title: Solution for the Stressed and Overwhelmed

Comment: I have read this book twice, in paperback format, but somehow lost it somewhere.  I bought a digital version for my Kindle to share with my husband after reading Ready for Anything and Making It All Work.  Getting Things Done is a good start to get organized and to try out different systems until you find something that works for you.  Making It All Work is the one that made me finally get it!

First, let me say that implementing the GTD system has made a profound impact on my professional and personal life. Seriously, while much of this book seems almost common sense, having it illustrated in this way will help you to see the light. You've got more going on than you realize.Now, why is the book repetative? I, like many of the 1-star reviewers here noticed this right away -- the flowchart is in three different places, and many of the points are repeated...over and over and over again. This put me off at first, but after going through it, and reading it a second time, and a third, I believe I may have found the reasoning:He's drilling it into you. The thing with this system, the fundamental chunk is that you need to be absolutely and completely confident in the system. It begins to fall apart (as he mentions) if it's implementation is half-assed or the user is not completely confident in its purpose. He repeats things so that you will remember them. It makes for a boring read, but read it again, see the style, accept it for what it is, and give it a go.As an Art Director, I juggle a ton of projects all the time. Personally, I prefer notes on paper; and while I've already configured Outlook to be as GTD-friendly as it gets, I'm working on personal, custom (and I like to think aesthetically pleasing) GTD-optimized Arc/Circa pages. I'm hoping to bypass many of the details memorization and learn by doing -- by having cheat sheets and optimal formatting on my own planning pages.Bottom line, you'll benefit from this book in ways that your standard-issue high school planner simply and utterly failed to do. As an aside, they really should really be doing a unit on this book and the GTD system in 7th grade.

I searched for this book because I was in a situation of stress and low productivity. Before knowing about GTD, I started to write down little to-do's lists to help me focus and organize my life (basically related to day job and my master dissertation). It created a kind of "light-at the-end-of-the-tunnel-feeling", but I still couldn't decide what to do first, and I still didn't have a full grasp of everything. Reading David Allen's formula for productivity changed my way of thinking and  handling all life activities.The book is very descriptive, a true step-by-step guide that we can immediately apply. It's detailed, with examples and great discussions.Highly recommended for anyone who wish to have a upgrade of life organization and productivity!

This book has been a real influencer for me.  Allen presents a great system for getting both work and personal affairs in excellent order, which could transform any area of work or life which features discretionary time.  Its popularity is not surprising, and it should not just be considered for business executives.The best thing about Allen's system is that it does not oversimplify the problem.  Advice to schedule work has lost applicability for most of us, simply because we are getting such a huge number of options about how best to spend our minutes and hours.  The increased complication does not jive well with set schedules.  Even so, people need to be able to act rationally, easily and rapidly with any amount of time they happen to have at hand.  That is what Allen is working to address, and he deserves tremendous credit for his effort.While I'm giving the book five stars, as a homemaker I think I have a good opportunity to write a bit about how the book does, and does not, apply to my situation.  Most of my day is not taken up by novel projects, but by repeating tasks that I know very well how to do.  I don't have to think them through very much.  Even so, set schedules don't work well for me since housekeeping needs are just as variable as office tasks.  I adapt Allen's system by putting my familiar tasks on index cards and dealing out the jobs I need to do at the start of the day.Now Allen is not keen on to-do lists because they are easily upended by the rapid pace of life.  He has a point, but this doesn't take into account the motivating force of a good daily list.  I have five small kids who are quite distracting, yet I still find that a list of items, kept realistic for the day's circumstances, is helpful in getting more done in my life.The book generally implies that it is normal to have a massive list of things to do, with new jobs being added consistently.  I have not seen the concrete situations Allen is talking about, but it seems important to consider, if only briefly, the reality of overwork.  Excessive work is going to stress anyone, even with a great system.  Tasks that go beyond a person's reasonable load need to be either delegated or clearly possible to drop with acceptable consequences.  The "defer" category works great for future possibilities, but is trickier to use with still-open loops, especially where responsibilities have been accepted.Allen's "50 thousand foot" perspective is largely relativistic.  There is another way to think about that level of living, and that is the Christian idea of vocation.  Allen doesn't really contradict this, but neither does he fully acknowledge it as a discrete means of thinking about life at this level.  The thinking he describes is more about "personal choices", "clarified values" and "lifestyle".  Vocation-oriented thinking focuses more on universal moral principles and the will of God for one's individual life.  Allen doesn't need to advocate this idea of vocation, but to acknowledge it would make the book more helpful and complete.Just considering the issue that Allen addresses, that of systemizing all the ideas, needs and physical items of life, makes me reflect (as does the author himself) that the book is really about life at its core.  It's not just about being neat or working well at the office, it's about getting ones self into a place where any change, task or project can be addressed in a more successful way.  So I would recommend it to anyone as a fundamental preliminary support for the events of life, from weight loss to finding a spouse.  Extremely worthwhile.
Comment_Title: It's about the fundamentals of life

Comment: Great Book but, i think it needs to be updated for technology. However i have started using the core pricipals and i believe its fundamentally made me much more confident and in control
Comment_Title: great fundamental concepts slightly outdated mechanichs

Comment: Read it for the great tips and tricks. But you will be blown away by the system as you consider it's effects over time.I'm a huge Stephen Covey fan but this book compliments it and surpasses it on the day to day how to.Do it for yourself. You deserve it.
This books was not worth purchasing because I did not read any new information. I would not recommend;in fact, after reading the majority of the book, I stopped....KOE
This book is great!  It's helped me to get organized and I continue to gain new insights from it. Highly recommend!!

In my treatment of adults diagnosed with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, use of "psychoeducation" is a powerful tool. Adult ADHD brings both "gifts" and "challenges". Charming, gregarious, multitasking, creative, enthusiastic adults sabotage their careers by not remaining organized, misplacing important materials, impulsively blurting out comments, and missing deadlines.Medication alone is insufficient for successful treatment. Skills-training and creating systems for getting things done prevent or revive career derailing. David Allen is one of my "required reading" recommendations for my clients [...].
Comment_Title: An Excellent Resource for Executives & Business Owners with Adult ADHD

Comment: I think it's fair to say that I'm a pretty busy guy most of the time. That is why I picked up this book, to find some ways in which I could maybe find a few things to tweak my currently existing productivity plans.  I was somewhat distraught when I found out, that in order to follow David Allen's plan, I would have to throw away the other ways that I do things.In part, I think this is why David Allen's system gains so many followers, it is a fairly simple way for people to experience the disruption of their current methods of productivity and adopt new ones.  As has been shown in other places, the simple act of adjusting to a new system often maximizes some dormant energy that has been lurking around in your old method.Looking at the tools suggested for use in Allen's system, paper notes to yourself, physical inboxes, file folders - you can see that Allen's system is heavy on the "feel good" of seeing immediate gratification from your work, i.e. throwing a note to self about a task in the trash.All in all, I was able to gain some helpful ideas from Allen's book here and there, and will be considering if I can adopt Allen's system in toto, or if that's even the best move for me.  Lastly, although the book is short and is a relatively quick read - it's not an entirely enjoyable read, filled by conjecture and hypotheticals.  I did however find the "aw shucks" psychology intriguing as I many times found myself saying "well, that makes sense to the way that I think about work..."I'd recommend this book to someone who is looking for a completely new system or method of productivity, especially someone whose work is largely based around new projects (not necessarily recurring projects).
Comment_Title: Ok if you need a brand new system or methodology

Comment: David Allen provides sensible recommendations on creating an effective system to manage all your projects, both personal and professional. Yes you could figure all this out on your own, but you're too mired in "to do" lists, so get the book.My additional piece of advice is to follow some of the instructions with a martini in one hand. For instance, the book isn't a scintillating read, but it's much better with a martini in one hand.And you're not going to sit down and review all your projects, resources, and action lists EVERY week without a martini in one hand; I guarantee it.Brainstorming is another a wonderful task recommended by Mr. Allen to do on a regular basis. But I find the results are more fun, open ended, and creative if I have a martini in one hand -- just one. I'm trying to clear my head, not fog it all up.I give this book four stars and one martini!
Comment_Title: With a martini in one hand

Comment: Reading the first few chapters was quite confusing but then again I notice that almost in every chapter the same diagram show each time to show the simple formula yet effective to do.I tried the first phase and it really works for getting me doing more fast and efficient organizing.I just feel so alive again at work, because my current work now demand many of my time if I do not have the proper organizing technique I would be stress out  everyday. Now I'm not.It really helps me a lot just understand and follow the diagram and the rule of two minutes. Thank you Allen your book is very easy to understand and straight to the point.
Comment_Title: Getting Things Done:The Art of Stress -Free Productivity

Comment: I was pleased with this purchased.  Reasons why? Quick delivery!..Adequate condition...Loving the book! I am glad I purchase it! I would recommended this book and the sender to others!

Imagine the most organized person you know.  They don't lose important information, they turn their work in on time (or early) and they get the right things done on a day in and day out basis.  Now imagine that person learned all these habits from one person.  That one person would be David Allen.In Getting Things Done David Allen has devised a full-proof system that will organize all the information in your life, help you put it in the right "bucket", get the right things done at the right time and make sure that the process is self-sustaining and reinforcing.  All in 259 pages.If you struggle with getting things done, keeping track of wave after wave of information crossing your desk or completing projects on time and don't see an end in sight, this book can change your life.The beauty of Getting Things Done is the system makes intuitive sense and if you really want to change, if you've reached the point where keeping on top of tasks, to-do lists and projects is like drinking water out of a fire hydrant this book can help.  It can make all the difference, but you have to change first.I first started reading the book in 2008, but I wasn't ready to change.  I picked it up again last year and what I had thought dry and boring before spoke to me in a new clear and instructive way.  In my case I was finally ready.  If you think you might want to change I would discourage you from reading this book.  If you know you are ready to change your organization habits I urge you to read this book ASAP.My Top Three Takeaways:Get everything in one place"Anything you consider unfinished in any way must be captured in a trusted system outside your mind, or what I call a collection bucket, that you know you'll come back to regularly and sort through."  For me this was the most important lesson from the book.  Only when we are sure that everything is in the right bucket can we relax and let go of that nagging fear that something somewhere has been lost or forgotten.  Once we do that we can let the system and the steps that make up the system do their thing and we can focus on the business of getting those things done.Next-ActionsAllen makes clear that there are separate steps for material that is not actionable, but if something is actionable and isn't part of an ongoing project you can "Do It" (if it will take less than 2 minutes), you can "Delegate It" or you can "Defer It".How much more could you get done if you made this process part of your DNA?  Try it for a day and see how it feels.  I think you'll see how powerful this is.Two Don'ts - no "to file" folders and no tasks on calendar that won't get doneFirst, Allen says don't ever have a "to-file" folder.  For that matter I would argue don't have a "to-read" folder.  Neither will happen.  Deep down inside you know it's true, so don't do it.Second, if it goes on your calendar Allen says the only reason it doesn't get done is if it was an appointment that got moved or canceled.  Other than that if it is on your calendar you must complete it that day.  These habits not only build trust with others that you get things done, but more importantly it builds trust with yourself that you can set goals and do them.ConclusionI can't emphasize enough that Allen's system will work.  However, you have to change your behavior and live the systems he lays out.  And for all the great ideas and tips that he describes they will all be useless unless you commit to making the first change.There is quote that says a man who doesn't read has no advantages over a man who can't read.  In the case of Getting Things Done the person who reads it and doesn't want to change has no advantage over someone who never even heard of the book.  Don't be that person.
Comment_Title: You Can Be Organized...If You Read this Book

Comment: There are so many systems - GTD is just one. But no matter what system you use, you will benefit from getting to know David Allen. When he's through, you will understand how, but more importantly why you would enjoy getting your act together. It's all hard work, anyway. Getting a grip on things is actually less work.But, most important: He is really good on the audio, great guy. Much fun. Gave me the goosebumps, realized so much.
Comment_Title: So many systems - this was exciting and fun

Comment: I'm so glad I've found this book. I had been struggling with procrastination and getting things done for a long time. This book's helped me getting more organized and getting more things done than ever. The system that David Allen teaches seems to be very hard to grasp as first but if you take note and start doing the exercises, applying what you have read into your life, you will see amazing results. I would highly recommend this book to anyone who is struggling with productivity.

"Getting Things Done" is a book that really made a difference to me.  It made me realize some of the areas where I have not been in control of my own life as I should.  There is a section that I especially liked about not feeling guilty when you aren't getting something done.  The author made me realize that I was only hurting myself and not helping my productivity at all with worry and regret over what "could have" or "should have" been accomplished.  After gaining so much from this book, I also read Time Control - Taking Control and Achieving Goals (Creating Lifestyle) written by Martin Gover.  It is also a great book and explains well how to manage your lifestyle to be successful.  Overall, I would recommend both of these reads to anyone struggling with reaching their goals and managing their life better.
Comment_Title: Everyone needs to read this book!

Comment: I bought this book after hearing Mr. Allen on NPR.  I liked what he was saying about getting my ways of dealing with all the things to be done organized into a big workflow.  I intuitively grasped where he was leading me and wanted to get the full descriptions by reading the book.  Unfortunately his written descriptions are pretty bad.  The layout of the book is ok, but the structure of the writing is bad.  If I had not heard the radio descriptions from him I am not sure I would have grasped why his method is the way it is.  I may have grasped the method, but with just that I am just a trained monkey.  I  am engineer and I could have communicated the same info in about half to three quarters of the pages, so the book is a disappointment.
Comment_Title: Great Concept Murdered by the Writing

Comment: Read this book right through and do exactly what it says. Your life will be much easier.It immediately felt like a weight was lifted from my shoulders when I read this book. I did change up the process a bit for myself but overall I follow it pretty closely and it has made me much more productive and cleared a lot of the clutter from the back of my head.
Comment_Title: Follow the principles and your life will be much easier.

Comment: While some of the things are bit outdated (pagers, PDA's) the overall ideas are still very relevant and good.  If you need to get organized this is the book. If you are pressed for time, skip the first section and go right to section 2.

This is the most overrated book I've ever read.  The problem is not the model, nor the concepts, it's that the book essentially 280 pages of common sense.All of the core concepts in the book could have been easily compressed into a 2 page flyer with a picture of the model and some basic `Getting-Things-Done' tips.I must be missing something, but I got to page 210 and couldn't keep going - it was just dry, repetitive and repetitious.

Heard about this book listening to Howard Stern so I ordered a copy.  As suspected it reinforced methods I have developed for myself over the last 40 years that use to seem like just a case of OCD.  Also, interesting is how the martial arts aspect fits into this equation.
Comment_Title: I thought it was my OCD!

Comment: If you breath air and live you should buy this book. It helps with organization of LIFE not just business.Fantastic! It has saved me hours at work already. I have only implemented a few items. I enjoy the "if it takes less than 2 minutes just do it now!"Awesome.Sincerely,Nicholas D. Marts[...]

Fantastic.  David Allen is a god.  I was pretty organized, but not quite able to "nail it."  Still too many things floating around my brain.  This book really explains that all to me, and for peole like me, who can't quite relax if I have things to do (and I always have about 100 things to do, it seems, and when the important ones are done, have 100's more) -- this book tells me how to get it all out of my brain so i can have "brain like water."  REALLY HELPFUL.  THANK YOU DAVID ALLEN.

It's true, I haven't finished this book yet, but already I feel duped by the delusion that reading a book will solve my procrastination issue. This just feels like another diversion from really doing things.So far it feels very redundant and obvious.
Comment_Title: why do I keep falling for these things?

Comment: If you think the printed version is bad just wait until you have to listen to the audio version.  Total bore fest and too much info for an audio.  The ideas mentioned are super basic.  I'm wondering if the 5 star reviews read a different book.

Read this book if you want to be more productive. I've been using GTD + OmniFocus since September, and I can't say enough good things about it. GTD makes it possible for me to support myself as a freelancer while taking a full load of courses. No way I'd be able to handle the workload without it.
Comment_Title: Simple principles for greater productivity and peace of mind

Comment: I work from a home office and have to juggle a laundry list of projects across several companies. I felt really overwhelmed at one point and bought this book. Thank god I did. This book helped me realize how much time I was wasting on my poor organizational skills -- and I thought I was really organized! I never lost documents or blew deadlines, but the stress of keeping up was killing me.David Allen's book is well written and worth its weight in gold. The system it describes works. It's as simple as that.I'd recommend this book to any high-octane professional who needs to step up his output without stepping up his stress level.

After reading the book, in the last few weeks, I got more things done than in my last year.I only have one problem: Allen, why didn't you appear earlier in my life?My life could have been so much different if I met you earlier!

Within only the first chapter, I was able to knock out like 40% of my tasks! If you're a Hall of Fame Procrastinator as myself, this book absolutely must be read. Or if you are constantly unorganized, read this asap. I can't say enough about it. Buy the book; just get it done.

Book was recommended by a mentor who is a highly successful business consultant. Implementing the system is incredibly helpful. I had to read a few sections several times for all the information to sink in, and I did have to do some translation from business to my non profit world. Liked it so much immediately bought more to give to colleagues.

With almost 500 reviews I'll keep it short and sweet. David Allen has a great process for getting organized across the board. Even if you don't implement his entire process you will almost undoubtably use at least a few bits and pieces of the information he provides in this book. Almost anyone who reads this will find it worth while and its a pretty easy read as well. That's my 2 cents.
Comment_Title: Filled in a lot of the holes in my organization process

Comment: I just started to get into the GTD world this past weekend. I have heard about GTD but never really looked into it. I was recently promoted to a manager role and found my head was just filled with non-stop thoughts. I dropped several tasks and had a hard time remembering where projects were at, when it was just me I could manage it in my head. It was hard but doable. Now I have a team of 4 people plus myself I'm responsible for so my old system which barely worked, now isn't working. I decided GTD is a worldwide phenomenon  there has to be something to it, so I ran down to my local book store (who know they still existed) and bought the only copy of this book they had. I sat down at noon and 2 hours later I was half way through the book. I was so into it that I stopped when I got to the "here's what you need to get started" and drove to the office supply store and bought the items recommended, a labeler, desktop in boxes, etc. I headed home and finished the book. I immediately started doing the dump first emptying my work bag of all notes, I started writing everything I "had to do" that I was keeping track of in my head and once I had it out I felt good. It was a sigh of relief knowing I now had lists of what i needed to do and at any time I could look to see what I could work on depending on where I was (context) and how much time I had.Is GTD a end all solution to stress? I'm not sure. For me there is a little bit of stress introducing a system into my life. But seeing how I had no real system before I figure it's worth a shot.So I went to work this morning with my supplies and setup my desk, built the tickler folder system and started filing things laying around (after loading up my in box.). I emptied my drawers and eliminated over 200 feet of network cables I was hoarding, cables, power strips, blank DVDs (and I no longer even have a dvd burner go figure.). I left the office today with stuff still in my in box but my desk is clean and tomorrow my goal is to finish running through the inbox process.This is a good book, the system seems to be simple although parts seem to be overly complex. I had to re-read a few sections a few times to really understand them but once I did it made sense to me.I would recommend if you were like me and had no system but a head full of "stuff" then you get this. You have nothing to lose by trying this. I'll try to update you with how this works for me but so far I do feel a bit of relief in knowing what I need to do and not having to worry about things because every task is being written down and logged for me to do when and where I can get it done.
Comment_Title: Trying to jump on the GTD Band Wagon, So far it feels pretty good

Comment: David Allen is widely respected for his experience in the world of productivity. GTD is a clear system that accounts for all the day to day issues a knowledgeable person encounters. He presents a wide range of solutions to each problem, but they're all a bit dated as the book was written back in 2002..How To Get Things Done: Living Stress Free While Still Being Productive!was a little more practical and timely for my money.

This is the bible when it comes to organizing yourself.After reading this book, I find myself with a clean desk, a pieceful mind and in control of the things that really matter. The nice thing about the method is that it does not rely on high-tech software and gadgets, though they can help. Good writing gear and a pile of paper, and a few plain manila folders is all you need to get started. You can tailor it to your own setting and to the tools you like (e.g., I like emacs and org-mode).The book is a bit lengthy, but well structured, so that you get the gist of the presented methodology after a few tens of pages. The rest is elaboration of all aspects of the method. It reads without effort.I tend to reread sections in the book from time to time, just to check if there still is room for improvement in my organization.
Comment_Title: A bit lengthy, but well structured and simple to apply

Comment: Why is this book much more expensive in ebook format than paperback?  The publishers are greedy.  It might be a great book, but I will not buy the ebook format until they lower the price.

I am halfway on reading the book. Enjoy it very much up to now! It's not creating a new complicated planing system. Instead, it helps you to utilize nature planing system in your own mind which is more efficient.

David Allen offers a strikingly simple, yet powerful, method for staying on top of life. Defining productivity as the intersection between action and vision, he offers a set of practical methods to reach that intersecting point:1. Trust an external system to make you think about the activities only when you need to (calendar, action piles, and to-do lists or tickler files)2. Maintain the discipline to keep the external tool accurate or else you will not rely on it3. Regularly review your activities (weekly review)4. Make decisions about every action (do the work now, defer the work, or evaluate work)5. Do work that is most suited to the moment given the following factors: time, energy, location, and priority6. Always evaluate work within its broader perspective. An individual task should map roughly to a project, goal, and ultimately, life objective7. As "what's the next action?" to everything that you must manage8. Think positively about your ability and encourage that in othersOverall, Allen's method promotes and encourages a high degree of focus in all of life, both professionally and personally.My only complaint with "Getting Things Done" is its verbosity. Allen is highly repetitive, often devoting later chapters to topics he covered in earlier chapters. For those not interested in meandering through Allen's model, I recommend reading his "Getting Things Done Summary" instead.

Excellent book about how to close the loops in your life.  Application for both personal and professional productivity.  Getting things Done will make the undoable to do list manageable and will take the constant weight off your mind of things that you still need to address.  Highly reccommend.
I've had a hard copy for several years and bought a Kindle version recently. Great book and methodology - if you are willing to develop the habits needed to make it work. It's worth the effort.

The first read of this book, I was a little confused as the processes were almost so simple it was confusing. However, upon the second read, the light bulb came on in associating these methods with my work environment. This may seem corny, but I am truly less stressed and more efficient. Great book with great techniques!

Although I'd used as much free info about GTD online as possible before ordering the book, it was still a good purchase because it contains the whole process and has aided me in sharing the methodology with others. I never did do the paper thing, as paper stresses me out, but I make heavy use of Evernote, at first using [...] to get started, then modifying it for my own purposes ([...]), namely to do team sharing. The system is well-tested and by following it I have been able to get all my plates in the air and spinning - all the while remaining calm and focused. No more overwhelming paralysis.

I never got things done.  In fact, it took me several years to get done the task of finishing this book!  But each time I read more and more, I began integrating the principles more and more until I became a GTD advocate to everyone I know.It IS repetitious, but to some degree for the disorganized it's necessary to really ingrain the principles being espoused.  Worth the read, worth taking the time to do full integration.  Takes a few days, weeks, even...but it's worth it.  My personal system uses Gmail, Google Calendar, Remember the Milk, and Evernote!

Day 2 of following this book and my house is already so much more organized. Its no wonder that I was sluggish before in my work - I didn't know where anything was! And I didn't know what to do next. Thank you David Allen!
Comment_Title: My house is already looking better!

Comment: Reading this book brought me contradictory feelings. Although it does tell you one interesting thing here and there that will be of help in your daily routine, most of it is composed by useless, obvious and systematically repeated ideas that bring you to the point of irritation. Most of the times, I felt like the book should be retitled to "Getting Things Said and Repeated: The Art of 'Stress-Full' Book Writing".A few concepts in the book indeed helped me, even though some of them are incomplete or inadequate in certain situations. The 2-minute rule is surely helpful. However, not putting it in a priority context can be misleading. Compound the effect of 15 to 20 "2-minutes-tasks" (something very common to any busy working person) and you'll have lost 30 minutes of your day, instead of spending them in projects that are indeed more urgent and important.The other concepts that are somewhat useful are the focus on the outcome and next action for each task, although David Allen is definitely not the 1st person to write about it. The 4-factor model to choosing activities is also useful, but kind of obvious to anyone who already has a pretty busy agenda. Still, the way David Allen formalizes it is nice.Now let's go to the bad things.First, the author repeats and repeats himsef, over and over again. And it's more than that usual mistake of such books, which simply repeat stuff in different ways. Actually, while most readers don't enjoy such approach, I usually find it useful, as typically I'm reading the book along a few different days and repetition helps me to fix the most important ideas in long-term memory. But David Allen is not repeating himself in different ways, he repeats WHOLE SENTENCES throughout the book. I mean it!Secondly, some of his descriptions are much more detailed than they should. He spends a long time writing about things like useless details about how your file drawer should be. Come on.In addition, and most important, his system as a whole is too complex and time-consuming. It gets me stressed only by reading about it, let alone implementing it. The author itself admits how many hours per week the maintenance of the system consumes, and how it's easy to fall trap to habits that will make the system get wrecked. I guess that if the person has the organization qualities to implement this stuff, probably he already has a system of his own that works fine. People who are reading this book are probably doing so because they're searching for a simple way to put their work and personal life on foot. And this method definitely doesn't deliver it.Despite the terrible title and cover (especially the cover!), I bought the book because of all the rave reviews on Amazon and Goodreads. But I must say I felt cheated. It feels like there's a lot of hype about this book, more than it should. Overall, I'm not giving it a 1-star rating because of the 3 useful things I mentioned above. So maybe those or others can be of help to you too. But if you decide to read the book, beware. It can be a "stress-full" experience.

1. GATHER: Walk around your office or home starting at your desk and gather any undone thing (or a note of that undone thing) and put in your in box. EVERYTHING. Business cards, get toilet paper, dinner reservations.2. SORT: Put each item in a category> HOME (think 'do this when I'm home tinkering'), PHONE, ERRANDS, COMPUTER, READ, PEOPLE (think 'the next time I talk to this person I want to remember to tell them this') WAITING (think 'well I called that person or delegated this thing and now I'm waiting to hear back from them so here is a note to not forget about that thing out there) and then add whatever categories you think you need.3. ACT NATURAL: Whenever you are running errands, look at your ERRANDS and you wont forget batteries for the smoke detector or to pick up that thing from the post office when you drove right past it. When you are waiting for your oil change you can pull out that thing you've been meaning to read or look over because you can pull out your READ.4. THINK STOP AND DROP: Next time you think of something undone jot it down and stick it in your inbox to be sorted later into the categories (yes it seems like you are costantly doing this but it's worth the energy). Sort once a day. Review all once a week.P.S. If something undone is multi-steps, it's a PROJECT. Keep a list of all of your projects so you can think 'What's next in this project?' and then jot that ONE task down and put in your inbox.P.P.S There is an iphone app called Omni Focus, it's pricey but magical.

This book is pretty outdated.  Lots of talk about post-it notes & Palm PDAs (I suppose you could think of that as today's iPhone).  This book teaches a paper & file-folder system of getting organized.  It does not teach us how to utilize today's digital technology to organize our information and our schedules.  It can still work, but I feel like with today's technology, there are WAY better ways of "getting things done".  There are a few suggestions that I will use, but overall, I was a little disappointed in this book.  Review written - March 2012

Very interesting set of ideas. The most useful analogy is to your computer RAM, the active front burner memory whose unoccupied space dictates how well and fast you are able to process and manipulate information. The author contends that a clean RAM is best for being able to do your best work. How do you get a clean RAM? You must have a system to catalogue all of the "stuff" that comes at you like drinking from a firehose. The author goes to great detail describing a complex method that creates a system to capture and catalogue everything you can think of or even image. I think the basic premise "ie a clean RAM" is a very useful idea that until you work with it you do not appreciate the power contained in this simple concept. The book does make you a bit dizzy at times by the details of the "system" but is well worth the effort to put the ideas into use.
David Allen's "Getting Things Done" fits into the category of life changing.  Practically written, this book contains ta treasure trove of valuable insights into the area of life management!

Getting Things Done presents a very effective system for personal productivity as long as you're willing to implement it. If you like to do things a certain way and aren't looking for new methods to follow to increase your productivity (getting tasks done and putting them behind you) then you might struggle with this one. It's a detailed system and works best when you follow it wholeheartedly. Great book.

I thought this book was easy to read. The steps are repeated throughout the different chapters but I will definitely have to re read it and implement his suggestions as they go along. It was hard to retain what the suggestions were without doing the actual foot work. I am excited to get things done.

I am a recovering workaholic - it turns out that being addicted to work-ahol is just as detrimental and horrible as being addicted to actual substances. Anyway, part of my self-imposed and managed "rehab" is dealing with the piles and messes that my inability to say "no" has created in my office. I first got this book on audible and listened to it on a few long drives I had to do for work. I was floored from the first five minutes I listened to it - some reviewers mention that the book is repetitive or otherwise fluffed, but I really benefited from all of it. I kept thinking it was crazy that the author was talking to me about me, and related to it all too well.The solutions are simple - almost so simple you feel like an idiot for not just knowing these things. But it has been a life saver for me. I spent about a week putting these techniques into practice (just the simple concept of making a decision with everything you touch from your "In" basket was novel to me - I'm a chronic piler and re-piler, which is very self-defeating and inefficient, it turns out). I have to say, everyone at work just about has a heart attack every time they walk by my office and see the sparkling organization system, or when I have a meeting with someone and have all the items I need to give them easily accessible in my (oh so easy and obvious) filing system - and when I get them a piece of information I've been sitting on for months because I didn't know where something was or it wasn't an emergency thing with a hard deadline.Yeah, so you should get this book. I am so glad I did. I got the paperback after listening to the audible version about 3 times (and have listened to it again several more times while driving around town). I hear and read new things every time I go through it and it is truly invaluable to me. I am so glad I got it. Most of my coworkers want to get it now too since they've seen such a huge change for me. It's the best!!! I'm so glad I found it.
Comment_Title: If you want to get things done, this will help!

Comment: Simply superb! I frankly think this guy truely understand the power of our intuition, imagination (magication) and meaning of life.  This book incorporates budhism, taoism, vedanta and abrahamic religion into one diagram.  Just amazing how simple meaning of life  can be if one dares to find out.

you know, in this economy we are always deeply stressed out, and we need to rethink our time in order to be a least a little bit more stress free. Great book to reach this goal! i also advise this bookAdd to Cart: How To Create Online Sales Success

If you happen to already be a Type A obsessive "achiever"you might like this book.  I have rarely read a bookthat used the words "must" "have to" "need to" anda myriad of other judgmental comments if you don'thappen to be the person he is describing.

If I wanted to know what a file folder or a paperclip was for this would be a very useful book. Defining them in length was a way to add words to this book.  Having people go out and spend money on file folders and unnecessary billboards when we live in an age of technology seems silly.The whole concept of being a vertical thinker is limiting. It is a narrow minded approach to allow lemmings to feel good about what they are doing.  It places too much emphasis on thinking in one direction rather that stopping evaluating and seeing the entire picture of a situation.The only thing that was useful were three lines.  Do it,Delegate it, or dump it.  And this is only if you want to cast off things that could very well prove useful elsewhere.  Sure simplifying to the extreme reduces a persons stress, because they will never take on anything that could actually make them grow as a person.As a history book for how things were done in the past.  Go for it.

Keywords: Organization; Time management; Prioritization; Task managementThis book is built around a few key ideas for organizing one's thoughts and a simple system for organizing one's papers and tasks.One key idea states that the effort needed to remember and prioritize our task lists takes away from our ability to perform those tasks. Therefore, Mr. Allen recommends writing down everything so as to clear our minds for focused concentration. Of course, other authors have recommended keeping notes, but he makes it clear why this action is vital to success.Unlike other books on this subject that are full of "drink the Kool-Aid" jargon and are designed to sell a product line, Mr. Allen's system can be created and used by anyone without any special tools.Getting Things Done: The Art of Stress-Free Productivity

I ordered it due to so many recommendations but was badly dissapointed.Well I must admit there are good concepts in the book, but. It seems the author is an administrator more than a trainer. The content is just copied times and times. There is one process diagram and it repeats 4! times most amazingly in the beginning after just two pages it is honestly the exactly same diagram! I thought how can one sell such a book!Facts:------1.) Really lots of repeating content!(Actually I think this is a no go for such a book, because if I like to read things twice or three times I can go back to the point where I started, but ... to eaches own)2.) It's hard to read(lot's of random stories and esoteric assumptions which do not help at all to what so ever workflow)3.) There is no red line and no completely new content in it and I think it addresses to simple and linear thinking people that might get the ideas in that book on their on, if they think a little logically.I am absolutely disappointed and hope that the author does better work as a coach.

The David Allen training is a total joke. What a waste of time. Do yourself a favor and maybe buy the cd's but definitely DO NOT go to the training. Now THAT is a waste of time and money. Better yet, go to the 43 Folders site and since they pretty much STOLE all of that system and claimed it as their own, you can get it for FREE there. And if you are unfortunate enough to get  duped into one of their $750 training, DO NOT buy any of their crap they are selling! First of all, their trainers were not very good, boring, and if I heard "Turn to your neighbor next to you" one more time as an "Activity" I was going to get up and leave. Within one hour of this garbage, ALL of the people around me were mocking "the system" and the boring trainer who was trying hard to sell it as something worthwile. What a joke. Then they tried to sell a bunch of David Allen crap to us that was just as much over priced garbage as their training. I am NOT KIDDING when I tell you that I saw the EXACT SAME bag at BIG LOTS for ONE DOLLAR as they were trying to schlep on us for $19.95. REALLY? By the time the long day was over, I was so mad about spending the money and getting nothing for it as well as seeing a big advertisement for me to buy more of their crap. David Allen, you should be ashamed of yourself trying to sell yourself as as real "system" that won't work for 95% of the working population, and then try selling YOUR NAME on crap. Anyone who has had the misfortune of sitting through your horrible training should not only get their money back, but also get paid for their time they wasted sitting in front of your horrible trainers. The best I would suspect from the small crappy company you have is to receive a gift certificate for a FREE bag to put MORE of my worthless David Allen crap into. Thanks for nothing.

Great ideas, some common sense that we do not put into practice but others are really a great way to look at things and overcoming the plate we all carry that overflows!! Applications of this stress free activity can apply to home, work, church, activities & more! Great to listen than share with your Stress-Out friends!! :)
Comment_Title: Don't Stress... Refresh by listening to this

Comment: There are some good gems throughout the manuscript however, sometimes some similar concepts could be grouped as one idea.  Instead Mr. Allen reinterates the point "until that dog just won't hunt anymore."  Overall though, I would recommend to those people organizationally challenged.
this is a must read for anyone with a  busy life! This book has helped me be better organized and more productive in every area of my life!

I needed something.  The first chapter described my life.  I followed the plan and it has been an enormous help.  I would like to say I could have done this on my own but I never have.  Now things are getting done on a whole new scale.

I feel weird raving about a business book. In fact, the business-ese (e.g. "deliverables") and business context of most of the examples deters me from giving it five stars.That said, I think David Allen completely nailed the psychology of how I deal with "stuff" in my life. While I probably will use his principles/processes/systems (See what I mean about "business-ese"?), I'm really looking forward to how I imagine it will help me deal with all the literal and metaphorical clutter in my life. I've starting implementing it and do feel the greater ease of being less preoccupied by all the things I feel are "un-done."Check back in with me in six months. That's when it'll be really clear whether the book is one to rave about...

A group of 10 of us at work are studying this book, keeping a daily log of our work habits and changes. We'll turn our log in next month and assess our progress. A volunteer non-co-worker is "teaching" the priciples of GTD. It is super benficial, practical and a general way to strengthen the work force so far. We began our class by sharing answers to two questions: What are our strengths? What is not working and where do we fall short? We are reading GTD independently/daily and sharing tips with each othere as we go through the book.
Comment_Title: small group book study at work

Comment: This book might live up to the hype for what it can do for managers of teams, busy executives and supervisors but if you work at home, particularly by yourself, there is not much here. There is a helpful chart early on in the book which can help one decide how to handle paper and the suggestions for setting up filing system are universal but I was not looking for tips on productive brainstorming sessions with a group of people. Many times he mentions homemakers and soccer schedules but application of his methods is lacking.
Comment_Title: Not helpful if you are a homemaker or work from home...

Comment: The IBM Competitive Edge Book Club, open to all Sales, Marketing, and Communication professionals at IBM, voted and selected "Getting Things Done" as the Q4 2011 book selection. Overall feedback from the members was very good. In the feedback from the members, we ask them the question - "What will you do differently in your job since your study of this book?" Some of the replies directly from the members included:- "It has given me renewed enthusiasm to re-establish my use of GTD concepts."- "Apply and revisit GTD best practices consistently."- "Evaluating my time management techniques to be more effective in 2012!"- "Better organize my in-box and track my activities/goals via the electronic calendar."- "Remind myself of what is the outcome of each action."I would like to personally thank David for being apart of the IBM Competitive Edge Book Club experience and for "Getting Us Organized" for 2012!Best Regards,Brien ConveryIBM Business Operations Leader and Competitive Edge Book Club Leader
Comment_Title: IBM Competitive Edge Book Club Selects Book in Q4 2011

Comment: I really enjoyed reading this book. I have 'self' implementing a system of organization for a few years now. I was happy to see Allen's system mirror mine in a few ways (notably email @Action and @Waiting for). What I really gained from this book is a realization that my system had some major gaps in it and Allen offered solutions to fix them. I titled this 'let's see' since I'm going to (and already have) implement some of these into my life and test the results.Good, quick and useful read. I will recommend it to my friends.
Love this book. Helping me keep my insane work schedule in check. I would highly recommend this book to anyone with many responsibilities who needs to learn to keep his or her life in balance.

The author has done a great job of laying out timeless principles that can apply to any life style. That having been said, it did feel a little dated. An updated version would, at this point, be appropriate. The proposed systems and work flows make great sense to me and I intend to review the book again in 6 to 9 months!

Very helpful book and it forces you into thinking about your priorities for projects. It describes an excellent way to clearly organize tasks and projects into different "buckets". The philosophy behind it, the idea of storing as much information about a task in one place and making it easy to reference anything related to that task is a simple idea but it is hardly done!My only complaint is that the later parts, about the larger view of things, is weak. It's a great help for organizing the next day, week or month, but after that, you'll need to look outside the box.

Pair this with a program like OmniFocus and you will be set to go.  It will take some time up front to implement David Allen's approach, but it works great.  His system works the way we do.  Give it a try and then follow through and you will feel in control of your task list (finally!).

Having relied only on a good memory for my whole life (I'm in my 50s), things are just too hectic today and the stress has just piled up.  Within 30 days of opening this book, I am more organized than ever, can find things at a moments notice, and feel more able to handle more tasks than ever in my life.  This is a MUST read for anyone to better their lives.
I just purchased this book from the air port during a flight. It was interesting information, some of it is just stating obvious information, but kept my attention. Buy it if you have nothing else.

The book had some good ideas, some of which are immediately available to try.  Although I may not be able to do everything, it does make you focus on what is important, and try to prioritize and chunk items into doable bits.  I'd recommend it.

I have listened to the audio version from our local library. The most difficult part in applying Mr Allen`s system is the lack of defining a single system that effectively bridges the transition between the last century ( physical memos, mail, papers ... etc) and the recent electronic revolution in communications ( emails, pdf files of scanned letters, smart phone , PDA`s and even computers and the hundreds of organizing software out there).  He mentions all the possible input devices and electronic systems but still has physical tickler files and folders as primary tools of organization.  The major difficulty i face the last 10 years is the mashed worlds of both physical and electronic systems, i can`t get a handle on either or combine both, do I scan every paper that is important for a project and drop it the organizer software folder? or i print it and insert it in the tickler file ? If i utilize the physical and electronic, the system will fail, surely it will confilc with basic principle of organization ( have one system).  I still don`t have a single system that works in both.  Unfortunately Mr Allen didn`t answer this question and may have even made it more complicated by giving you the options to use either and showing you how to use only one or part of it, in the real world, we don`t have that option. I know the book was written in 2002, but this should have been addressed then and better in the newer editions.
Comment_Title: Great system for the first few years of the last decade... unfortunately not for now

Comment: One of the most overrated books I've wasted my time reading since I can remember. Struggled getting through it since the author seems to be used to getting paid to state the obvious with the twice the amount of words necessary to get his basic point across. I'll save anyone else that got fooled into buying this book their time and do what the author couldn't seem to spell out in a single sentence. "Find a system that works for you, i.e. sticky notes, filing cabinet, outlook, computer, etc. to manage your time and stick with it." The author doesn't really go into much detail on any of these recommendations and purposely keeps the rest of the book vague since he says that even if you do come up with a system it's keep changing over time anyways!Only thing I found useful was his flowchart which I came across on the internet before I bought the book and was one of the reasons I got the book.And his 2 minute rule is a joke because really how many things these days can really be done in 2 minutes or less?Anyways, didn't learn anything new about getting things done since there really is no secret to getting things done and this is a whole book on stating the obvious.Then again I've been doing the pencil and paper method described in the book since I can remember so maybe it's mean for the clueless with no system at all?
Comment_Title: stating the obvious with 2x the words

Comment: This is a good book on how to prioritise your tasks by keeping the list and deadlines.Somehow he talks about in-files and out-files - but that is a minor distraction in this e-age.

Great book that has alot of nuggets on efficiency improvement.  Recommending reading once to learn the concepts, then going back through the implementation chapters when you set up the system.  Highly recommended.  I bought a couple other efficiency/time management books and none came even close to this for tips I actually use on a daily basis.

This book is quite useful for those of us who deal with lots of disparate sources of information on a regular basis. It provides a framework to manage and control information overload in all aspects of life.Is this book for you? If you are not interested in optimizing workflow or feel content with your current mental state on a regular basis, probably not. But if you are interested in managing the stresses of life into a very rigid system I would give this a try.This GTD system will give you what you put into it.

I was looking for some nice process approach to the method - GTD. But the book has nothing by talk talk talk about some scenarios that I can hardly connect.There are few diagrams in the book, but again they are not concretely explained either self explanatory.If you spot the book, just flip though few pages of the book, spot some diagrams, and try to apply your style of work to it. This is completely waste of your time and thought process.

David Allen's methods are key to plan and unstick projects. I am getting excellent strategies for better organize even my personal plans with efficiency, and creative results. I also would like to thanks Amazon.com for its exceptional service. I live in Brazil and I had some problems receiving the book because of the clearance in Brazil. But Amazon was great doing me a favor that guaranteed that I receive the book anyway. Thank you for all!
Comment_Title: Excelent source for everything you have to do in your job and in life.

Comment: I've always been organized, both at home and at work.  But over the last 18 months or so a certain malaise had crept into my productivity which drained my energy and left me feeling overwhelmed and very ineffective.  I came across David Allen through the Amex/Fedex site, liked his down-to-earth recommendations, and decided to see if this book could help me update my workstyle to better manage and utilize the technology that is part of the work environment now (versus back when I started, when dinosaurs roamed the earth).This book really freshened my perspective on daily tasks and workflow but more importantly how I manage and track tasks and the projects they feed into.  Many of the suggestions seem basic and in fact, are, but sometimes you get into a mode where you can't see the forest for the trees; this book can help.  I have so much more mental space free now that it's my organization system remembering everything and not my actual brain.  I'm now taking on more than ever with less stress.The only complaints I have about this book are:  he needs to write an updated version.  Many of the "high-tech" items in the book are de rigueur now so it seems a little strange to not be giving them their full due (example: receiving email on a cell phone).  Second, there was quite a bit of repetition in the book.  I think his points and the book would have been better served if, instead of just repetition between sections, he could have used each section to build on the parallels and larger more universal points of organization.  But other that that, I think it was a useful read.

I found this book a decent strategy for improving your efficiency in normal daily tasks.  I am not sure any book can really get people up of the couch and get them to accomplish a major goal or life dream. But this books has a good theory on training yourself to knock out the clutter and build some efficiency rules in your life.  Decent book.
Comment_Title: Good set of principles and strategy on efficiency

Comment: A waste and an insult. The author spends thousands of words stating the obvious: that people are maxed out.This laborious introduction is a complete insult to busy readers who don't have the time to slog through lots of excess verbiage.Note to Mr. Allen:GET TO THE POINT!LEARN HOW TO WRITE!STOP WASTING OUR TIME!I wouldn't pay this guy a nickel to consult at my company.He obviously has no respect for people's time.This book is a farce
Comment_Title: save your time and money: don't buy this book

Comment: This is a very good book! It brings a paradigm shift and helps you to overcome the innumerable hindrances in life-namely the myriad little things that that you need to do, which otherwise clutters your life, reduce your efficiency and choke your output! Worthy reading and applying the principles and details taught.
Book came as described- slight wear, but nothing too bad. Prompt service. I'm learning how to be productive now. Thank you!

This book is a must buy for any professional!  Finally an organizational system which encompasses both your personal and professional life!  The book has changed my life for the better, and we read it weekly in our office.

I think this book is amazing if you really utilize the principles taught in it. I really feel like they should teach it in schools and that it would make young people so much more better prepared to handle their adult lives better and more efficiently. This book really gives you the tools to be organized in your personal and the professional world.

This book reads more like a sales pitch than a guide to getting organized.  Online resources actually explain Allen's concept far better than he does, because he's too busy trying to be cute and clever, to express his ideas succinctly.  One gets the distinct feeling that his concept could have been explained in a booklet, but he felt the need to pad it out into a full-length book, just to land a book contract.Worse, his method often involves handling paperwork over and over again.
