For example, during the initial purging of unnecessary papers, he suggests creating an inbox in which to keep the remaining papers, until they can be processed again, and filed in the appropriate folders.  It would make more sense just to file those papers during the first sorting, rather than handling the same papers twice!  This is just one of his many truly stupid ideas that waste valuable time.Organizing systems like 43 folders are far more sensible.  If you're going to pay for something, Maria Gracia's "Finally Organized, Finally Free" is far better.  I'm glad I bought "Getting Things Done" at a garage sale, because it would have been a colossal waste of money to buy it new.
Comment_Title: Save your money and use "43 Folders" instead

Comment: The book arrived my home not in the best conditions I expected, but quite OK. The information about it was more or less accurate in the web. What was really amazing was that the time spent in the shipoping was so fast, at least for Europe!

GTD or 'Getting Things Done' is all about personal productivity, gaining control over your life and reducing stress.It's NO classical time management. It's NO project management and it does not tell you HOW to optimally achieve a goal.Whereas classical time and project management is all about PLANNING, GTD is about ADAPTING. Therefore, it is well suited for managing everyday tasks and duties.The key principles:1. Get everything OUT of your head and into an EXTERNAL MEMORY2. Register information in ACTIONABLE form3. Organize your tasks by the limiting factor and let the decision on which task to perform next, FIRST depend on CONTEXT (NOT on priority!). In other words: you work in blocks of time and during each block, you do similar things.Important side effects of GTD:- You are more PRESENT in the moment- TRUST and COOPERATION within groups improvesGTD distinguish 5 stages: collect, process, organize, review, do.I think GTD is helpful. However, do also read Covey's 7 Habits. Whereas Allen is the expert in productivity, Covey is the expert in effectiveness. One needs both in life. Allen will help you to have more time left for the tasks around which effective people organize their lives i.e. those important, non urgent things in life like relationships, training, etc.
Comment_Title: More time left for the important things in life. Combine this one with Covey's 7 Habits

Comment: David Allen is widely respected for his experience in the world of productivity.  GTD is a clear system that accounts for all the day to day issues a knowledge worker encounters.  He presents a wide range of solutions to each problem, but they're all a bit dated as the book was written back in 2002.  You'll likely come up with some novel approaches to some of the problems he identifies, but there's no question that he provides the framework you need to improve your personal productivity.  If you're interested in this topic, you couldn't pick a better place to start.  The book is a bit repetitive, but it continuously builds upon itself, culminating in an all-inclusive system that you deeply understand.
Comment_Title: Words of wisdom from the man who started it all

Comment: This whole book really could have been summarized in ten pages. The rest is just fluff, mindless personal commentary on how to organize stuff without any reason on why Allen's way is better than other ways he criticizes in the opening. Allen pats himself on the back constantly saying "executives" use his method and how he sets up conferences. It's a really really bad book and a waste of time. Great title though-- made me buy the book.

This book will lay out a great theory on getting things done, but David keeps on suggesting using.a paper system which of no one can really use..Sorely missing implementation on how to implement this theory with some practical digital tools. I would still buy this book, as it can convince you to get the house in order. But you should know that you will have to buy some other book to actually get use out of it.

I was very excited to get this book and start becoming more productive.Although I do agree with his explinations for why we are so unproductive and how things will weigh on us and cause us not to act, I was not impressed with his methods for managing these issues.  It seems that the end result of following this method is you have a very well organized collection of items to do - but you spend a majority of the time writing things down and not actually doing them.I gave the method a chance for a few months and was very gung ho at the beginning but quickly realized I wasn't getting more things done, I was just recording everything I wasn't getting done.  I would rather spend more time doing and less time planning (at least not overplanning).Two books that I think provide a more practical approach are Zen To Done and Do It Tomorrow and Other Secrets of Time Management.  I would give them a try if this doesn't seem like it's for you.
The cd's were easy to listen to in the car, and offered an interesting system to be more proactive about being productive.

Very quaint, reading about how we are expected to use specific tools like little cards, and pens and notepads, and filing cabinets to help us keep a handle on our responsibilities when things have moved on so far. But it's very solid general advice.In fact I found the general processes described very useful, and personally found the best value in the absolute lowest form of tracking described.... I've noticed that the better I maintain my todo lists (Gtasks woohoo!) in terms of just what the next tasks are for big projects, and update them as I complete each step, the more I benefit from having a system of organisation.So - If you're finding yourself swamped with more things to do that time to do them, letalone remember them all, then this book could be a big help. It was for me.

This book was a series of epiphanies for me, from the first chapter to the last page.I may be able to reconcile the reviews that Ho-hum the book with the five-star reviews.  I am a very experienced manager, computer guy and recently a law school grad. I think we old dogs, in our 40s and beyond, are locked into trying to make the "Time and Your Life" system work, and the youngsters have had to adopt some of Allen's principles just to survive puberty. Further, the ethic has changed tremendously, and more youngsters don't place as much weight on commitments as we older dogs do (I didn't say all).  The result for me was a series of understandings:  why I had trouble finding starting points; why I was always reactive and not proactive, and why I was always overcommitted.Two months ago, I was finally frustrated enough with my A B C priority system that I started looking around for better software. I began to see references to GTD and as I researched further it sounded as though David Allen had the solution. It is the kind of read I expected a life-changing book to be.  Looking back, I agree that there are only a few dozen main points to come away with, but Allen introduces them directly and reinforces them anecdotally, metaphorically and with memorable quotes and quips.  My sole complaint is that the kindle version has several formatting issues, but the resulting non sequiturs forced me to reread some very important subjects. Finally, having read Laikin's "Time And Your Life" book in the '80s, Allen fit many pieces together for me.If you're serious about getting the upper hand over the steady stream of stuff flooding your desk from every direction, invest the time into reading this book properly. This means delaying your pending work by a few days, but you'll find that the time comes back with interest..
This is a good book that helps with what it says... getting things done.  It's not one of those "create your life plan" books.  It's just great at managing the chaos.

OK, so when an associate of mine told me that this was the most influential book he'd ever read on organisational skills and that the book, and the system, had changed his life, I was reluctant to believe him.  I decided, just to prove him wrong, that I'd grab a copy and see what all the fuss was about.I read it in 2 sittings, commenced implementing it immediately, and after a week I realised that I too had found the best organisational system that I'd ever come across - and that is saying something!  I've been in the business community for more than 20 years, have worked for international consulting firms, been to more training courses on the use of management systems, owned every PDA, manual time system and document tracking system known to man, bought every Ipad App available, but this one system has without doubt, absolutely and totally changed my life.  And for life it is!There is a massive adjustment.  I worked out that my supposed "Stress free" paperless office was in fact causing me more stress than I had ever realised.  I can now locate any document that I need literally within seconds and my staff think I'm taking some super drug because my office now looks like something out of an IKEA magazine and what's best, this all came for the very small price of the book along with a few dollars for the accompanying iPhone App.  The Outlook App too is less than $100 but it works best for me on my phone.  Everyone will use it differently, but the use of it is what is SO enjoyable.It isn't a system, it's a life choice......for everyone from receptionists to super execs and everyone in between, if you follow David's rules, you too will reduce your stress enormously and be the super organised person you always dreamt of!  I just wish I'd invented the system and been using it for the past 20 years!Without doubt, anyone who reads this book will have implemented bits and pieces of David's super wisdom in their lives - it's the combination and then the reviews of these systems that create the power behind what he writes.I love it - I never thought I'd love an organisational system, but I do and if I met him, I'd tell David I love him too!Don't miss up the opportunity to give it a go and feel the LOVE!
Comment_Title: DO NOT PASS UP THIS BOOK AT ANY COST!

Comment: It seems a lot of people have benefited from this book, but for me, I didn't find the book very appealing. I'm still trying to make sense of the program, though I admit I did skim the last 100 pages. It was much, MUCH longer than it needed to be, imo, and it was scattered and fragmented in so many different sections and topics, my head was spinning. The core program could have been described in a few pages, but then again, that wouldn't be a very marketable book.
Have only read about the first 100 pages but it is very good so far. Some of it looks to be a little repetitive but other than that its great.

One way that I judge a book is by how much impact it really has on my career and life after I finish reading it.  In this case, this book had and still has a huge impact in my life everyday.First of all, I recommend purchasing the audio version of this book so that you can listen to it while you implement David's organizational system in your office and home.  This way you can listen to certain sections multiple times at your pace.A few major impacts that this book had on my career include:- I implemented David's filing system for "loose" papers and now my office desk is clean (most of the time)- My to-do list is much more effective based on David's recommendations of how to layout your list- I now manage my e-mails rather than letting them manage me (this is a big one)Most importantly all of these items allow me to lead a less stressful life.Thank You David!I highly recommend this book to anyone who is looking to not only get organized but to reduce stress and improve their time management skills.
Comment_Title: This Book Will Help You Get Organized and Reduce Stress in A Big Way

Comment: “Getting Things Done” is an excellent selfmanagement book, written by David Allen, a wellknown productivity expert and thinker, who takes in this book the productivity to another level.The author, also known as “the productivity guru”, describes throughout the book a structured process for managing time and work effectively and efficiently. The reader is guided on how to capture, process and carry out open loops, TODOs, project tasks etc., in a productive and stressfree manner.The entire book is framed around the five stages on managing workflow:- Collecting information, TODOs and work items- Processing the collected items- Organizing the items in actionable and noactionable items, setting up project lists, etc.- Reviewing the items regularly- Doing the actual work by carrying out the collected itemsIn a nutshell the general message of the book is to empty our head of information, by writing down TODOs, ideas and thoughts, which we plan to address sometime in the future. Once we’ve captured these open loops we sort them out, make them actionable (where applicable), decide on the next actions and ultimately get the things done.Personally I liked and already applied several times the “2 minutes” rule. According to this rule, when we organize and process our workflow, the items that take less than 2 minutes we’ll do them right away. The items that take longer than 2 minutes we’ll defer for later or delegate. By following this rule I can get rid quite fast of those items which are piling up and unnecessarily waiting for me or threatening me to allocate time and attention for them.Another thing I found really useful is the power of the “nextaction” decision, which in fact is an active approach that I personally use since years. Making things actionable and ensuring that no decision is left suspended without a concrete nextaction, is something that brings traction and pushes things ahead.Although “Getting Things Done” was written many years ago, the productivity guidelines are still well applicable today. On the other hand, the collecting tools described in the book, such as file folders, paper trays etc. can be replaced nowadays with “electronic” collecting systems, such as client, web or mobile workflow management apps.
Comment_Title: Boost your productivity with Getting Things Done

Comment: I think it is worth a read and has some classical approaches that are still relevant today but I'd like to see an updated version that better encompased modern tools and technology.All in all worth the money for the ideas I got from it.
Comment_Title: Getting a little out of date

Comment: Despite reading many books on organization, time-management, etc., I had yet to find a methodology that really worked for a scatterbrain like myself. Franklin Covey's 7 Habits was overbearing, and required too much "stuff." The concept that I had to plan my day down to the minute was crazy, and have not met anyone who does this effectively. Other books, such as Time Management for Dummies, First Things First, and The Four Hour Workweek all required simultaneous habit changes in order to be effective. Being a scatterbrain, requiring more than one habit change at a time was simply asking way too much -- it was downright absurd. Furthermore, some of the suggestions made in these books were wishful thinking, as in the case of The Four Hour Workweek which advised hiring a secretary in India to do most of your work for you (HA! Do they do homework too?). Even more implausible, the author suggested starting an online business to automate revenue, which sounds good in theory; too bad his example was selling french style striped T-shirts.I had given up on these self-help books years ago, and rightly so IMHO. Then things started happening which forced me analyze how I manage my to-do lists (or rather, did not manage them). School was getting harder, chores were neglected, phone calls were missed, and I was always exhausted. To boot, we're looking to move out of the country, sell our house and everything in it, planning a going away party, planning trips to see family, and I'm trying to study for the MCATs. So, I broke down and bought Getting Things Done by David Allen.Finally I discovered a book which not only "get's it," but also understands how to, no pun intended, get things done! Instead of fighting my habits, this book is showing me how to benefit from them. GTD doesn't require anyone to change their entire life in order to become more organized like so many other books -- which claim anyone can be more organized by simply changing everything about themselves. GTD is not full of the same suggestions over and over, such as breaking bigger projects into smaller pieces (duh), or incentivizing (when you finish this task, you can have a whole gallon of ice cream!). Rather, GTD outlines a method which is completely compatible for those of us who really need a book on organization, time-management, and completing the items on an ever growing to-do list. GTD understands it's readership and offers valuable tips and tricks which, almost magically, make someone more organized. As the author puts it, "we trick ourselves everyday, like putting important documents next to the door the night before we need to take them with us." The strategies suggested in this book are so simple, even I can do them (which is saying a lot).Suffice to say, GTD is the best book on organization I have ever read (and I've read a lot of these types of books!). It's easy to read, easy to implement, and does not make you feel bad about yourself. A great find, a great book, and a great addition to my library. Highly recommended!
Comment_Title: Wish I had found this book sooner!

Comment: I found this very helpful and specific, offering an excellent way to get organized and relieve stress.  Lot's of concise explanations.  Important addition to anyone's library who doesn't already have a great working system.

David Allen's book Getting Things Done is one of the most popular books written on Time Management. I had very high expectations when I started reading.Getting things doneIt is a very complicated explanation of a simple and effective system.The system David has created is very effective and I have in fact incorporated it to my own time management system.The problem with it is that it doesn't capture activities you have to do every day, it is build around projects, ideas and unexpected events.InboxThe idea is that you have an inbox to capture everything that comes to you.Every day you should process your inbox and either file the information as reference material, add it to your calendar, put it on a to-do list or just do it at once.The methodology is very simple and efficient.What takes time is building an effective filing system and to make sure you get reminded of all the actions you need to do when you need to do them.3 Parts of the bookDavid has split the book into three distinct parts.The first third of the book is useless; It is an introduction to the system, without really explaining it, which leaves you as a reader, very, very confused.The third part is unnecessary since it discuss goal setting without any details and the value of the system, basically he is just trying to get us to use the information in the middle;which is very useful.The Second part is very goodThe middle of the book covers the system in detail and shares all the information needed to make it efficient.Works great with a weekly planIf you use his system together with a weekly plan and with a Calendar it will capture all your commitments and make you very efficient.Time Management can save you up to 2000 hours/yearBy learning proper time management you can save lots of time, energy and reduce your stress levels. The advice shared by David Allen is worth reading.
Comment_Title: A complicated way of describing a great system

Comment: This book has completely changed my productivity.  It has given me permission to throw away reams of old documents, helped me organize those I wanted to keep, and compelled me to take some sort of action on everything that comes across my plate.  Can't recommend this book highly enough for anyone who feels a bit overwhelmed by the volume of work to be done and the lack of time to do it.
I recommend for those whose jobs keep them away from their desk yet still have to answer to 90+ emails daily!  Might help you sleep better at night.
This book is amazing. I have found it so useful. Getting everything out of my head and into something I trust has reduced by stress and anxiety to almost nothing. Don't wait, get this book now!

I am always looking for ways to better organize my life. I already had several techniques I used. An although they helped, I never got the feeling they were all inclusive. David Allen's put together in one place all I needed to organize my to do lists, appointments, filing etc.... I have only started the process but I already have seen my productivity go up and my stress go down. I would recommend this book to anyone looking to getting things done.Jim

The book puts forth some decent ideas for getting a handle on your to do list - but is way too granular.  For example, at one point the author gets into a discussion of whether you are better off using hanging folders or not.  It appears to me that much of the content was developed to justify being published as a book.

Getting Things Done by David Allen is perhaps the most left-brained book I've ever read. List making and to-do tracking doesn't exactly make for a thrilling read. And yet, this is an important and forever practical book IF you put into practice the core of what Allen is saying. I'm a daily list maker and I live by my calendar. I never read a book on personal organization though I've invested much of my adult life in it.Here are the most important points of the book, in my opinion: (1) Get all your to-do's (All. Of. Them.) out of your head and write them down. This will free your mind from having to think about them incessantly. (2) Give all of your immediate to-do's a next action. (For example, "get a dental check-up" should instead be "call and make a dental appointment.") If you can't do the next action at any given time, then transfer it to a separate list to be reviewed sometime later. (3) Don't worry about the what tools to use to organize your life. Start simple with a paper, pen and perhaps a folder and grow from there. Most complex organizational tools are probably too specifically customized for what you need anyway. And (4), every single one of your to-do's is an arranged agreement with yourself. If you put it off or forget about it, you feel the guilt in your mind consciously or not. Having them written down helps your meet your own commitments as well as saying no to commitments you now know you can't keep.There's many more steps to keeping your personal organization optimized than the above points (for example, defining separate lists such as the "tickler" and the "someday/maybe"), but those I feel are the most crucial. Doing boring stuff like what Getting Things Done advocates would seem soul-sucking to a more right-brained type, but I firmly believe creativity is at its best when it is organized.
Comment_Title: Worth reading, but not an easy read

Comment: As the title indicates this is a book about re-gaining control of one's life through high-performance workflow management. There are two key objectives upon which this is based: "(1) capture all the things that need to get done - now, later, someday, big, little, or in between - into a logical and trusted system outside of your head and off your mind; and (2) disciplining yourself to make front-end decisions about all of the "inputs" you let into your life that you will always have a plan for "next actions" that you can implement or renegotiate at any moment."The author then goes one to describe the five stages of mastering workflow:(1) "collect things that command our attention"(2) "processs what they mean and what to do about them"(3)"organize the results, which we"(4)"review as options for what we choose to"(5)"do"The above seems rather straightforward and we all perform the above steps in some way shape or form. The key here is to perform all these steps consistently and with the same standard. After all the workflow is only as efficient as the weakest of the steps. David then goes on to describe each stage in detail to help the reader better understand it, and help her to implement techniques and tools to make her more efficient within it. Besides discussing individual tasks, the author spends significant time discussing projects - which require multiple tasks to be completed in order to bring them to close. He goes on to describe how these can be managed using the same framework. This enables handling tasks, regardless of size, scope and/or complexity in a standard manner. One thing that sets this book apart is it's focus just as equally on the "not to do" than on the "to do" - which are fundamentally two sides of the same coin.Below are some excerpts that I personally found to be very enlightening:a) "You need no new skills to increase your productivity - just a new set of behaviors about when and where to apply them."b) "the sense of anxiety and guilt doesn't come from having too much to do; it's the automatic result of breaking agreements with yourself."c) "Organizations must create a culture in which it is acceptable that everyone has more to do than he or she can do, and in which it is sage to renegotiate agreements about what everyone is not doing."d) "Real "togetherness" of a group is reflected by the responsibility that all take for defining the real things to do and the specific people assigned to do them, so everyone is freed of the angst of still-undecided actions."e) "Getting things going of your own accord, before you're forced to by external pressure and internal stress, builds a firm foundation of self-worth that will spread into every aspect of your life. You are the captain of your own ship; the more you act from that perspective, the better thing will go for you."A very highly recommended read in the area of personal productivity. The advice given in the book is very practical and pragmatic. I have personally adopted the workflow described and have already noticed significant improvement in my personal productivity.

Without hesitation, I can tell you that this is the greatest time management book I have ever read. In addition it may be one of the best business books I have ever read. Here's why: I've become better organized, more efficient, more valuable, while increasing my performance at every step of the way.So, what's in the book? A simple system clearly explained in everyday language. David Allen writes as if he was talking to you. The book gets straight to the point and you can get straight to work. To be honest, when I first read the book I realized the great advice inside but did nothing. A couple months later I reread the book and started taking action. Almost immediately my inbox was reduced from an average of 80 to 90 e-mails to zero. Zero! Over a year later, my inbox is still at zero. My quality of work is improving as well. I'm taking more action, procrastinating less, and I am literally getting things done. I now have more quality time at work and at home thanks to this text and a little effort and persistence on my part.This is the first book I can ever remember truly sharing with friends and colleagues. I have already handed out more than six copies and plan to hand out more as time goes on. As an accounting professional about to return to an MBA program, I have every faith that the time management skills I learned from this book will play an enormous role in my future endeavors.As an Amazon prime member, and one that has purchased dozens of items every month for the last five years let me be clear that this is THE highest impact item I have ever purchased for my business and personal life. Get this for yourself, get it for a friend. But make the effort and realize the rewards.If you found this review helpful, please leave positive feedback or a comment.(This review was completed using Dragon speak software without edits.)
Comment_Title: The best book I've ever purchased.

Comment: This book actually has all the answers to all the problems in your life. You just have to follow it. I did it for a week my career hit a new trajectory I was able to manage a very complicated project and bring on board 4 more senior staff to work FOR me. My personal life hit a new levels I called people when I had to, paid bills on time, cleaned my house.And then I got lazy again and started to leave papers around the house. Not answer emails within 2 minutes. And it all feel apart and I'm back to normal now. But if you have discipline go for it!And 4 stars cos it is out of date now. There are so many efficiency enhancing tools available now.

I bought this book to, uh, get things done.  LOL  I read the reviews and thought it would help me organize my life and get more done in my day.  Not so.  David wrote this book specifically for business people.  All the examples and recommendations are for business people.  I'm a homemaker (domestic goddess) right now and none of his options translated well into my real life.

I really like the book, it focus on getting things done on time so you don't have to stress about it later. It is very true. Most people don't get things done on time as a result, they end up getting stress out. Make sure you get things done on time.
Comment_Title: It is always good to do things on time

Comment: I'll start by saying that a lot of the overall ideas in GTD are useful. I don't have a problem with the system itself. What I have a problem with is the book. David Allen is a productivity consultant, not a writer; and this book shows that.The first chapter is completely useless. It amounts to a lot of chest beating and promoting a book that you've already bought and a system you're already going to try. To summarize the beginning of the book can be done in a single paragraph:"This system will instill in you a continual sense of relaxed control. No seriously, you will be relaxed, while in control. You know I teach this to people who pay me money, and afterwards they are in relaxed control and love it. It is, in essence, the best system ever. Once you know about it's amazing aspects, you will be amazed. In short, this system is great."It uses a lot of words to say very little. I sort of wonder if he was just going on and on just to increase his word count. The actual implementation and details of what the system IS doesn't get covered until significantly later.Another issue with this book is that the ordering isn't very useful. For the first several chapters he mentions placing things into a "Tickler" file, but doesn't tell you what a tickler file actually is. It's not until Chapter 7 (page 173) that the tickler system is actually explained. And it's a neat system. I can see how it would be really handy. Unfortunately now I feel like I'll have to read those first 173 pages to remember where he was talking about using a tickler file. There was no context on what that file was to really ground the thought with the reader. It's problems like this that make me feel like this book could have done with a stronger editor that would have been willing to rearrange the book to logically build upon itself. That same editor should have also removed roughly half of the useless pages that merely sound like ego boosting of the author on how his system is great.In essence, the ideas of this book are good. The writing is terrible. If someone were to write a second book that was maybe 100 pages total and distilled the system to it's essence, that would be a good book. As it stands, this one almost wastes as much time as the system would save you.
Comment_Title: Useful info that should be condensed

Comment: This book was recommended by a close friend I trust.  It truly is timeless information that is very good reading, sensible, practical, simple, and very doable.  It's a book I highly recommend for stress-free productivity in all areas of our busy life.  Get your copy today!

---Summary---Getting Things Done has become a best seller and is today the most important reference in the "getting things done" topic. This is not by chance!The book starts by saying that nowadays, we have more and more demands and insufficient resources to fulfill them. The goal is thus to capture anything you consider unfinished out of your mind in a trusted system. Then, the idea is to first define the problem, the success, and the next action toward success. Finally, you do and follow up.---Model/concepts---The goal is not to manage your "stuff", but to manage your actions needed to bring your "stuff" to success:  1.  Collect - In the system out of the head; Few collection buckets; Empty buckets regularly.  2.  Process - Actionable?No, then set it  as trash, maybe later, or potentially useful;Yes, then define action, do if < 2min, delegate, or defer & track.  3.  Organize - Actions on calendar, next action by context (calls, computer, office, etc.), and waiting for.  4.  Review - Weekly gather & process new "stuff", review calendar, update action lists.  5.  Do - Choose by context (where am I?), time available, energy available, priority.---Impact---Huge, really!There are two key points in Allen's approach that are highly powerful: - Get "stuff" out of your head in a trusted system. - Think and act in term of actions toward success not in term of problems.The book gives all the necessary material to do that, and it works. Once you have no stuff in your head, and you know that with your system you can correctly handle it, your life is much easier. Additionally, the concept of action thinking/acting is extremely powerfull to face problems in a positive and simple way.This has played an important role in my working life when my company has moved from the "few friends" start-up phase to the "leader & team" structure. Before, I was still involved in some development, and I had quite long slots to perform relatively few different tasks. As leader of a small team, I had to perform more and more small tasks, and there David's model has been very helpful.---Rating---- rating Amazon - 4.4/5.0 (641 reviews)- my rating - 4.5/5.0- fun factor - 4.0/5.0- simplicity - 4.0/5.0- impact - 5.0/5.0
Comment_Title: A masterpiece for personal productivity in the modern working environment

Comment: The crucial thing about David Allen's method is that it aligns on several levels with how the brain works.  Allen devotes most of his book to reinforcing how his system goes with how the human brain works.  Unlike many of the other reviewers, I place more importance in understanding what the system is supposed to do than in the system specifications.  That's because once you understand how the system mimics the way a brain would optimally think, the organization of it can evolve naturally.Allen is often credited with making or at least advancing a more realistic method than just maintaining a list of A, B and C priority task items.  He identified our main problem as loading the mind with stressful noise, those seemingly infinite loops when we keep thinking of hundreds of things we intend to do.  This creates mental clutter, and that kills both creativity and productivity.  Mental clutter and clutter in general harms the quality of life.The Getting Things Done method (GTD) is very specific.  You can and will improvise, but the basics seem to be established simply by the nature of how our brains function.  We have an alpha system for our main projects, but there are so many other things going on.  Separately, we should maintain an area for things we intend to read.  Another subsystem is perhaps just one or maybe more hanging files are for those things that can only be classified as "someday maybe."  We'll need a tickler file - the subsystem I've never been able to keep up with for long.  These systems can all be represented in one graph.There is an art to using GTD.  It's ok if we don't all do it the same way.  One concern, for example, is to find the best way to store a subsystem.  You don't necessarily want it all in eyesight, but you want easy access and you don't want to be able to forget about it.  That is just one example where you have to creatively discover what works for you.  I recommend GTD, and especially to understand the logic and reasons for the system.
Comment_Title: Logical system that's designed for how our brains function

Comment: Just as an accountant now days would not use an Abacus,one should not rely on this material to aid in organizing your activities.This is very outdated.  Unless you are still using Post-It pads to keep track of your day this has no use.
Comment_Title: Antique Road Show, here we come.

Comment: Forget about old systems that don't work. This is the best approach to productivity I've found. It's totally worth learning this method and fine-tuning it to your life and needs. Plus there is tons of blogging about it, and apps based on it. Community support as well as official support is plenty. 100% recommended.

different people have different styles that work for them as they get organized. This books offers the most common sense, down to earth ways to approach organizing a home or office or life. Highly recommend it.
Comment_Title: bought this on a recommendation and it is worth it

Comment: For the others, this book presents quite a few valuable elements that can be borrowed to increase efficiency, so overall I consider it a very worthwhile read. However messy and impulsive you are, this book will definitely make you rethink some of your methods and improve quite a bit - I think 20% to 30% of time saved (while getting the same things done) is a reasonable expectation for most readers.But I do think that no sane person will follow this system as-is with no shortcuts - it is simply too formal. The trick is not to try and see if it works, but to borrow the right elements to make your work more effective.
Comment_Title: A great method for those with OCD

Comment: Excellent book. Must be a first read for anyone who wants to work on improving their productivity or organizing themselves. Take what you need and build the rest yourselves.

For people who are wondering if a $15-20 book can really make a big difference - I'm a strong believer that it can.  I am a successful VP of a medium sized corporation, and I am by nature a very organized person.  I was doing 80% or more of the things in this book correctly, but I was never taught some of the most important principals of organization before.  How to manage lists properly, the difference between a task and a project, how to have an effective filing system, how important doing a daily / weekly review is and how to have not open loops in my life.  If you feel like you ever think about all the things you need to get done while at work, or after work, which I believe would be 98% of the population, you need to buy, read and study this book.  I also bought some of his CD sets which were helpful.  It is David Allen and his staff reviewing the different components of the book with real life examples of how certain clients organized themselves.  Highly recommend to anyone, not just business professionals!
Comment_Title: Wish I would have bought this a long time ago!

Comment: This book really helped me stay organized in my last year at high school. It kept me organized by use of a calendar, a to do list and I always knew what had to be done next in order to be ready for the exams.

I can't recommend this book enough.  After years of feeling scattered, I am finally in control of my life!  I set the system up to be ready to go for this academic year and after only the first week, it has benefited me in ways I never thought possible.  Stress free productivity...truer words were never written.

I'm going through this book again, using it as a coaching manual for my personal paper caskets. I agree with how David Allen manages his paper flow...love his system. Must read if you are struggling with haystacks of paper and piles of books, DVDs, CDs, magazines, clippings, conference brochures, etc. Suggestion: read 10 pages a week with a friend, discuss it, and implement each system as you go along. Having a telephone Clutter Buddy or face to face Clutter Buddy helps enormously, especially for the start-up process.
Comment_Title: Read @10 pages/week and IMPLEMENT ASAP! Best system ever!

Comment: While I haven't been able to fully implement this entire system, just using the "runway level" system for dealing with every day things and organizing all of my projects and individual steps of them has been hugely helpful.  Getting things off your mind by writing them down and putting them in a system you trust relieves a lot of stress.  I've also been able to keep my desk consistently clean for the first time ever, which is a very nice feeling.  A messy desk, though I lived with one for many years, seems like a big deterrent to actually sitting down and getting things done, even if what you're doing has nothing to do with the piles of things on your desk.Bottom line, I highly recommend this book.

GTD sounds appealing - in a nutshell, write everything down in a super organized system; then rely on this system to keep track of small, actionable next steps. Forget the big picture and forget priorities, just pick one small actionable task, focus on it exclusively until it is done, and then pick another. Decide on the fly what you should do next.  Viola - "stress free productivity."Practically speaking, though, it was a flop. Without priorities, I had no idea what was important and what was ephemera.  I had no plan to keep me on track, to keep from checking email, returning the easy call and so on. I also couldn't say, "although my to do list is two miles long, all I really have to do to stay on top and keep things moving are these 20 things today."  Instead, I was looking a hundred things or more, from many projects, all jumbled up. Does that sound stress free?
Comment_Title: Best for organized people with independent projects

Comment: Simply ported to kindle without including hyperlinks when referring to page numbers and figures. Amazon should have a tighter quality control wrt these issues.

I really enjoyed reading this book. I'm still implementing it (currently in the initial Processing phase of the 5 steps) and it's a lot of work and already rewarding. I'm getting a better sense of all the commitments I've made with myself and others, and I'm able to whittle down my full Inbox and it's great. This book is worth the time to read and to decide how to implement. All hail, GTD. :-)
Comment_Title: Great insights in Getting Things Done!

Comment: Nothing comes easy, right?  The plan is sound and I'm starting by jumping in with one foot....  (I haven't fully digested everything to the point that I can jump in with both feet).  Some of my delay is figuring our how I will execute the techniques in my particular office environment.  I have found some great information at the author's web site, including some technology suggestions and some docs on how to use GTD with Blackberry, Lotus Notes and other systems.  Much information is free, but the aforementioned "tech guides" are $10 and include some high-level basics about GTD before the detailed "set-up".  I agree with one of the other reviewers that the book has a lot of examples, maybe too many, but they were much like my situation and they actually encouraged me to proceed with the system.  I suspect that I'll commit over the next week or two and then feel really good about the plan.  The book is an easy read and Amazon had a great paperback price (<$7).

I think this is a must read book for leaders. I wish he would have organized the structure of the book a little more. I felt when I was reading as I was covering more tracks than necessary going backward and forward in the text to understand the context of the material he was explaining.Content of the book was incredible though.
Comment_Title: Getting Things Done - needs some organizing

Comment: Unlike typical books on time management, David Allen takes a unique approach to organizing one's life which is centered around keeping lists.  The problem is that he has no clue how to efficiently explain his ideas.This is a 267 page book on To Do Lists that wanders all over the place and does not cover any topic completely in one section.  It took me an excruciating 2 months to read.  To be fair, I have found David Allen's ideas to be sound, but the mechanism in which he delivers them is poor.The author presents a flow chart but instead of starting with one box and explaining it fully before moving on, he only scratches the surface and then immediately shifts to the next box and the next box.  Then he starts over and sprinkles more info about each box, and he does this again and again for the full 267 pages.  The book must be read in order, you cannot skip around.  Now that I have finished the book, it is not really possible to go back and review anything because if I have a question about one of the boxes in the flow chart, I can't go to one place in the book and learn all about it.A better way to disseminate this information would have been to provide a poster-sized flow chart (with summaries of each box in the margins around the perimeter) and an hour-long DVD.  If it has to be explained in book format, David Allen should have kept the book under 50 pages.  I still would have paid the same price.I am rating this book with 3 stars because the information is useful, it is just presented in a way that utterly frustrated me before it enlightened me.  A great alternative book on time management that I can bounce around and read a fragment here, a chapter there, in any order is "How to Have a 48-Hour Day" by Don Aslett.
Comment_Title: 267 Pages?  If You Need This Book You Won't Have Time to Read It!

Comment: It is a great first start into organizational skills, it teaches you how the brain works and this set has made me organize my whole house, some things I have started to organize, some I will be getting to shortly and then there is some I put a 2 year plan on just to set my mind free so that I can start to be more productive in my life in which I learned in freeing your mind through this process and the importance of it, I definently recomend this program to anyone just because alot of us are not automatically inclined to think more profeshional and organized and have to be tought, my parents were not so organized and in fact a complete mess and I chose to stop that cycle for me and my children, hope this review helps, love and blessings xoxo :-)
This is a great book to anyone who feels overwhelmed due to the amount of work they many currently have.  It keeps one focused and it is a great tool to have.

If you have trouble focusing or following things in a linear path, I don't recommend this book. I'm OCD and very much Type A in personality and I struggled through this book. This whole system was very confusing and maybe in a year or two I'll be able to focus on it a bit better. But I'm also impatient. Give me solutions that I can apply now so I can start to see results. This book is not built that way. I recommend this book instead: Zen To Done: The Ultimate Simple Productivity System

The book's cover says "The Art of Stress-Free Productivity" and I have to say it delivered on that right away.  Here's what helped me most:Get it out of your headProbably the biggest thing that helped was the concept of "getting it out of your head".  My head was filled with things I needed to keep track of.  The problem was I would remind myself of what those things were constantly - mostly in the middle of the night.  GTD recommends you write out each thought, idea, etc. on a separate piece of paper.  I used to make lists, but then I would see a laundry list of things to do and become drained.  It makes sense to write down each thing on its own page because you can't process all the things you need to do at the same time.  We usually do things one item at a time.  This in of itself was a huge benefit.  If an idea pops into my head, I write it down.  Once I do (and of course make sure it goes into a system that will guarantee my next action) then it's released from my head, freeing me up.Two minute ruleThis is about going through your inbox and doing whatever is in there that can be done in two minutes or less.  Sounds simple because it is!  And it's amazing how quickly I can reduce my inbox.  The thinking behind this is that sometimes it takes longer to store and track something than just to do it!Grouping like activitiesMake all your calls one after the other - whether they're related or not.  Take a block of time and send your emails out.  If you have magazines stacked up - read the cover story of each - that's the most important.Is it actionable?Whatever you're trying to manage either has a next step or doesn't.  GTD teaches you how to categorize things so that you always know what to do with them.  This was especially true with projects.  The book points out that you really never do a project, you do the next actionable thing towards getting that project done.GTD has increased my productivity and reduced my stress.  I no longer miss appointments, or wake up in the middle of the night wondering if I finished something.  The book is very intuitive and I would highly recommend it.  FYI - it does take a while to incorporate the whole system.  If you make a commitment to doing so, you will benefit tremendously.And if you have a goal you've been putting off - read "Goal your 30 day game plan for Business and Career Success"Goal!: Your 30-Day Game Plan for Business and Career Success It was recommended to me and I achieved a goal I had put off for years.  It's a quick read and has you taking action right away.
I haven't read the book yet, but how could the Kindle digital edition cost SIGNIFICANTLY more than the paperback?  What a ripoff.  The publisher and author should be embarrassed.  Enough said.
Comment_Title: Kindle edition costs more than paperback?

Comment: Have this book in physical form and audiobook. I wanted it on my kindle, but at almost TWICE the physical book price? That is just ridiculous!
Comment_Title: Love the book, not the price

Comment: This book was written in 2001 before there was any software made that took advantage of David Allen's ideas therefore it does not talk about all the great software that has brought his ideas to a whole new level. Doing GTD with out paper solutions doesn't allow for you to filter your tasks by certain criteria or set reminders for when things are due (David says that you should use a separate calender, in my own experience I have found it far better to do this with in the GTD program itself.) The book says that you should get everything out of your in box and into projects. He then goes on to make an exception saying that you can leave your email in box alone. Now that there are great GTD programs out there I think it makes sense to get those tasks out of your in box as well. Many of these programs have quick entry windows that make a breeze to sort things like emails.In the book he tells about how people complain when he tells them to keep buying more filing cabinets to store all the paper that these solutions require! Now days that we have not only computers but handheld as well as with the rising popularity of tablets like the iPad those old style solutions make no sense. I really have to wonder the reason to why David hasn't updated the book it's not like he is unaware of what is happening with the new technology. After all he is an OmniFocus user like I am (probably the best program out there by the way.)  You would think that any author would relish the idea of everyone going out and buying an updated version of his book. Also you would think that any reader would like to read about an even better way to do things.

I've read quite a few time management books lately, all in hopes of finding my sweet spot, a system that would work for me to help me balance my time in a more efficient manner.I can safely say that this book, "Getting Things Done", describes precisely the system that works for me. I read through the book slowly, and took time to implement the processes described in the book as I went along. The only feeling that comes to mind when describing how the book effected me is relief. I felt an enormous amount of relief while implementing the system, and it has really helped me to clear my mind, and regain my focus.The system works as follows (in a very rough, quick description):1. Write down *everything* on your mind. Put it into a list somewhere.2. Go through your list, and determine the next 'action step' for each item. For example, if you want to "clean your garage", the next step may be "sweep the floor".3. Any list items that take less than 2 minutes to complete, do them, and cross them off.4. Now go through your list again, and begin working on actions, crossing them off as you go.The idea behind the 'Getting Things Done' system is to simplify all of your tasks, problems, and thoughts, by breaking them down into smaller, simpler steps.What I like most about this system, is that it is extremely logical. Being a programmer, I often use the same system for breaking down software into small simple problems, then tackling them one at a time. However, I never considered doing the same to my life (both personal and professional).The "Getting Things Done" system is fabulous. If you're a logical person, who likes seeing results, you owe it to yourself to read this book, and give it a try.
Comment_Title: A Simple Approach to Managing Your Productivity

Comment: GTD, The Art Of Stress Free Productivity provides you with both a detailed and most importantly, an overall view of the GTD system.Frankly, the system is not much of a new invention as much as it is a reinvention. The book serves as a great way (for those who already employ a similar system, even an intuitive one like mine) to assess your current status and detect any failures in your own system and help fix & enhance these failures positively thus increasing your efficiency, productivity & ultimately  your energy. I say this because the GTD system itself is not something new (at least not for me), but rather a collection of "common sense" -as David Allen puts it-, logical and semi-straightforward (ranges from one process to another) techniques that are easy & logical enough for anyone to think off and employ them.The system might be new to many, especially those who never have experienced or felt the sense of being overloaded or exhausted of the astronomical input of everyday life & the lack of a good organizing & processing system to handle them; but is obvious enough and very needed for those who did experience that.The book may be considered as a good reboot (in a "transition" sense rather than the regular reboot meaning) of your current system into a new efficient one or a refreshing tool to those who already have a similar system. I personally have found it to be a refreshing tool as I have discovered that my own "intuitive-based" system is very similar to GTD's. While reading the book, I crossed off around 90% of the basic tools needed to implement the system because I have already been employing.For example, I have already been using paper holding trays (3 as David recommends as the least), filters & labels to automatically organize my email inbox & processing incoming emails as described in the book (automatic filtering & labeling is not mentioned though), using To Do lists (which after reading has been changed to multiple bulleted lists and "action lists" which I found to be much more comfortable). Some of these tools I already had, have been used inefficiently, like, as an example, the stacks of reading & reviewing material lying on my desk or near my bed.Just very recently, I have bought "file folders" for my desk drawer which are to be employed very soon, something I didn't have previously or even thought it could be helpful, but the explanations in the book raised my attention to its potentials especially when it comes to projects files, referencing & archiving material.Finally, I have high expectations regarding this development of my system (which I can now call it by the GTD system), but I will give it a 12 months period to make sure that my expectations are in the right place & during which this period I will further develop & master the GTD's system techniques.Good Luck in yours.
Comment_Title: Not a New invention but a system that's common sense & worth it

Comment: I have bought this for 3 other people since i read it.  While geared toward business, his advice is helpful for everyday life too- that overwhelming feeling that you are losing the battle- his methods can be used for everyday deadlines and reminders.  It's an easy read with short enough chapters to read just a little bit at a time and not get lost.
Comment_Title: helpful in business and personal life

Comment: Getting Things Done: The Art of Stress-Free Productivity is touted as the common sense approach to organizing your life. It is based on the idea that putting all your commitments on paper instead of keeping them in your head will make you more productive. By keeping an evolving file of tasks and "to-dos" at hand, you are able to focus on the most important or current ones without forgetting the rest.Fans of Getting Things Done, or "GTD," stand by the system as a complete method for keeping yourself organized and productive. The "Two-Minute Rule" is worth noting: If you have a task that you can finish in two minutes or less right now, then do it. It frees you up to move on to another quick task or tackle a longer one. The system does require some willpower to get going. Procrastinators will want to put off the quick tasks out of hand. But if you really want to put some structure in your life, it is worth taking a look at this book. The accompanying website ([...]) has forums, podcasts, articles, and a blog to help you stay on track and get advice from other GTD users.Fast Company Magazine has called author David Allen the "personal productivity guru," a reputation his clients will back up. Allen is a management consultant and executive coach for businesses and individuals. Getting Things Done is like a condensed course of his knowledge and expertise using the most beneficial exercises and tools of his trade and provides a solid commonsense approach to personal efficiency.
Comment_Title: Common Sense Approach to Organizing Your Life

Comment: David Allen clearly articulates the challenges we face as "knowledge workers" the ever growing list of intangible tasks and the growing confusion on what i should do and when i should be doing what. Before reading this book i used to be overwhelmed with tasks and never satisfied with the outcomes for the day. But by clearing my mind and listing things out I am now under much less stress and much more productive. My energies are now focused on attracting all things good and important to my life rather than being wasted on the mundane tasks.
Comment_Title: Must read for all Knowledge Workers

Comment: Core Idea: You can gain control of your life by following a five-stage process: 1) Collect 2) Process 3) Organize 4) Review and 5) Do.We have too many things on our minds. Unfinished tasks and unfulfilled commitments create stress and pressure. There is no way to achieve relaxed control if we keep everything only in our minds. "Managing actions" means deciding what to do at any point in time. Almost always the problem is not lack of time but the clarity about what to do next.1) Collect all the things in a trusted system so that your mind can let go.2) Process your list by asking "What is it?" and "Is it actionable?" If it is actionable decide what the next action is.3) Organize the outcomes of your process in a trusted system.4) Weekly Review your organized system to see what is getting done.5) Doing entails doing pre-defined work, doing work that shows up or defining your work.In the final analysis, deciding and doing really comes down to a matter of trusting our hearts, our minds, our spirits or our guts. This trust cannot be fully defined yet alone captured in any known system to mankind yet. However, David Allen's GTD system gives a better idea and a better foundation for doing so. This reason alone is sufficient to make sure we got a copy of this book in my humble opinion.
This book fills in the gaps that I have found missing in the past.  It has a specific "how to" to implement the process into my life.  Great book!
Comment_Title: Getting Things Done: The Art of Stress-Free Productivity

Comment: David sets out a great system to really get your arms around all that is currently buzzing around in your head. Still it all requires discipline, unfortunately not something you can get from a book.
Comment_Title: Makes being on top of it all seem possible

Comment: Other reviews have sung the praises of this book, so I'll just add that the key for me in accessing the material was actually throwing away the half that I didn't need.  Allen's designed his system to have interlocking parts, but the basic ideas work well separately as well.  His folder structure and the way he configures his lists is super helpful.  His 10K, 20K etc. review plan and such, not so much.  Great book, though, and I recommend it to everyone.

Environmental Cleanup Coalition and The Gyre Cleanup Project would like to thank David for his amazing insight and concise way of expressing in print. This will dove tail nicely into our philosophy of getting the oceans cleaned up and restored back to optimal health. [...]Our deepest gratitude,Aloha Richard Sundance Owen

Without a shadow of a doubt the best productivity system available. Been using it for over a year now and I can tell you its more than just getting things done (which in the busy life we live is still pretty cool). I think the bigger picture is how it takes away your stress, quietens your busy mind, and puts you in the moment and back in control of your LIFE.Its also very simple system ONCE you get your head around this new way of thinking. Thats a promise. I turned this book down about 3 years ago dismissing it as too complicated. I was wrong. So just bear that in mind.What I would say though there is one addition area to enhancing the benefits stated above and thats basically the "process of elimination" and structuring a "simplistic lifestyle". So I would point readers here: http://www.amazon.com/Simple-Guide-Minimalist-Life/dp/1449556825/ref=pd_sim_b_3  and here http://www.amazon.com/Power-Less-Limiting-Yourself-Essential/dp/1401309704/ref=pd_sim_b_2so GTD is about getting all your stuff done, but its also important to not have so much stuff in the first place. The above recommendations will help you there.

I haven't quite finished it yet but I am using more and more of the lessons every day.  Although I had used some components of the method, some I had picked up and some were intuitive to me.  But I had never seen how it could all work together.  I am getting a great deal of benefit in my business and personal life from it.  The first time I emptied my "IN" basket, I lifted a great weight off my shoulders.  I am now starting to feel I can juggle all the balls more effectively.

This system is simpler than most I've tried and easy to understand. The blogger on SimpleDollar uses this system, and that's how I hear about it.In the book, the author talks about how Things To Do lists don't work and why. Makes a lot of sense.

I was in the middle of 14 hour workdays, 200 emails a day and an incredible amount of stress. Reading this book (required reading for management in my company), and implementing the system - got me to a 10 hour day and a clear email inbox at the end of every day and a whole lot less stress at work. Applying the system at home, has made my home paperwork and desk so tidy and organized. I feel a sense of control over life and work, and feel relaxed to really focus on whatever it is I want to focus on. A truly transformational and life-changing book.

I had a clutter problem - in general.  So I got a book on clutter ("It's All Too Much" which is a good read btw).  It worked!  ...on everything except my relationship with papers.  They are (soon to be 'were') everywhere: messing up my home office, the table where I eat, on the night stand, even on the floor.  I mean, it looked like clutter so why didn't it work?  Well, because my paper issue was some else entirely - an organization puzzle, not an extra-stuff puzzle.This is where David Allen's book really comes in handy.  It's especially good for everyday people whose lives are getting more multifaceted and whose personal and/or professional projects are getting bigger.  The logic is impeccable.  And the tools ought to be adjusted to your style.  Plus there are tons of GTD fan videos online that can help you modify and personalize what he suggests in the book.  Papers begone!  It's working for me.  If you have a monster of an inbox, certainly give Getting Things Done a try.

This guy is the best. I "went dark" one long weekend to get his personal organization system implemented at home, it actually took longer, but it is totally do-able and you are going to want to do it YESTERDAY once you read the book. In fact, you won't get through the whole book, you will start once you have read halfway, but finish reading the book eventually because the last part is terrific too. Of all the books that claim to be life-changing, this one delivered on the promise. All the mundane stuff that bedeviled my mind for decades is now in the system and I can't begin to tell you how that has upped my game in every quarter of life.

After years of struggling to organize my chaotic life, I am embarrassed to admit how many "systems" I have tried... This book has some simple suggestions that have helped me stay on track both professionally and in my personal life. Like alphabetical filing... duh...

The Good:David Allen presents quite a bit of helpful information in this book.  GTD is a very valuable read if you find your email gets out of sorts or your desk becomes cluttered with papers more frequently than you would like.  One quite useful idea Allen presents is that of "Stuff".  "Stuff" for Allen is "Anything you have allowed into your psychological or physical world that doesn't belong where it is, but for which you haven't yet determined the desired outcome and the next action step."  Allen suggests the presence of "Stuff" makes work difficult; it engenders internal resistance to work.  Cutting down on "stuff" is the basis of Allen's system and becoming more productive.Allen suggests creating inboxes to place your "Stuff" in order to get them out of your mental RAM.  One common example (albeit maybe old-fashioned) is the physical inbox on a desk.  Allen suggests creating such an inbox and placing all cluttered papers and "Stuff" on your desk in it.  This frees up your mental RAM a bit as the "Stuff" is out of sight and out of mind.  When the inbox is first created it will be quite full, but once that initial hill of  "Stuff" is processed, the inbox should stay fairly empty as its owner should be frequently processing it.  Allen provides a workflow diagram for processing "Stuff" and suggests doing so at least weekly.Using this workflow, it is easy to cut through an inbox.  This really helps one get a handle on their work and getting things done!  I can attest to this as I've organized my email according to this methodology, and it works quite well.  In Outlook I now have four main folders: inbox, next actions, waiting, and reference.  Reference contains most of my previous folders; its where I store materials I might need to reference at some point.  Waiting contains items I'm waiting on deliverables/dependencies from others before I can proceed.  Next actions contains the next things I need to do that will take more than 2 minutes (if less than 2 minutes, I do them on the spot as per the diagram above).  And my inbox is nearly at zero (always).  That has probably been the biggest gift the book offered me.  I review emails daily and file them according to the workflow system and am able to maintain a near zero inbox.  This really catalyzes my productivity.So, the good from GTD:  "Stuff" principle, a physical inbox, the workflow, and (at least) weekly reviews of inboxes.Another less but still beneficial principle Allen suggests is practicing "ubiquitous capture".  Ubiquitous means ever-present or constant; the principle Allen suggests is to make a habit of constantly capturing your ideas.  Never be without a pen and paper (or a PDA for some).  This way you are able to capture ideas regardless of when they occur, and more importantly, your mental capacity is freed up from having to try to remember ideas.  Jot your idea down on a 3x5 card and drop it in your inbox and forget about it.  Focus on what is at hand and process it in your weekly review.The Bad:Yes, there is bad in GTD.  First, the view of technology is antiquated.  For example, Allen states that before implementing his system a person will need to purchase:  paper-holding trays (at least 3), a stack of plain letter-size paper, post-its (3x3s), paper clips, binder clips, a stapler, scotch tape, rubber bands, an automatic labeler, and file folders.  Any system that requires all of the preceding is simply not making effective use of technology.  Furthermore GTD is overly reliant on paper and physical filing.  It would be quite difficult to fully implement GTD electronically, and this is a major drawback given the growing movement to more and more electronic organization of work.  Also, Allen's system is not flexible enough to handle diverse environments.  If you Google GTD, you find many adaptations to his system people have needed to make in order to fit it to their specific situations.What to Keep:So what will GTD mean to me?  Well, I now keep a physical inbox on my desk, I've reorganized my email (and have a tiny inbox!), complete a bi-weekly review, and utilize a simplified version of the workflow (the diagram above).  I find that this frees up my mental capacity to work more effectively and be more productive.  GTD is not a complete solution, and is certainly not perfect, but the basic ideas have proven helpful.* Last, I should qualify my review here.  I am leaving out vast segments of the GTD system for brevity's sake.  Also, I did not read the latest edition of the book (I read the 2001 version), and the newer edition might make more effective use of technology.
Comment_Title: GTD: The Good, the Bad, and What to Keep

Comment: I have long been frustrated because I am one of the millions out there who has too much to do and I never seem to get anything done. Enter this book. The most important thing I got from this book is the concept of collecting, processing, organizing, deciding what steps to take, and acting on it. Such a straightforward and simple process completely organizes your tasks so you can tackle each one with ease. Another important thing I learned is that keeping your mind clear (by organizing and listing down every task that needed to be done) clears up your mind so you can focus on the task at hand. The philosophy is so simple, I wonder why a lot of people never thought about it. No more wasted moments staring at the wall and thinking where to start! Buy it!

As the first book of my _Five_Book_Challenge_ (see more at [...]) I have been fighting with the yin and yang -- productive and un/counter-productive -- sides of myself since I was in my teens.  It has been a never ending struggle for me to organize my thoughts, actions, responsibilities, and so on in order to streamline the way in which I deal with things.  Enter _Getting_Things_Done_.  I was skeptical at first; I have read tens of books on this topic, and some have been helpful, but none has been a magic bullet.  Mr. Allen's information is somewhat dated, dealing with the limited technology available in the early 2000s, when this book was written.  Nevertheless, his overarching strategy can be timeless.  He goes through ever step of the system multiple times to make sure the reader understands.  His language is direct but not abrasive, and he has a way of cutting through self-created nonsense to help us...well...get things done.  Allen is quick to stay away from any philosophical implications as well as any goal setting.  This is my only gripe.  I would have like to have at least seen some sort of an epilogue with how to handle these things best.  He glances on the "altitudes" of goal setting, but I just felt like there could have been some expansion here.  His system involves a lot of things I already unconsciously do or things I have thought were good ideas but never acted on them; rather than being redundant, though, this helped to solidify the system further for me.  At times, audio books can lose something in the translation, so to speak, but not the case here.  It would be nice to be able to jot _some_ things down, but I listened to the entire thing in my car, and I am satisfied.  I have seen mixed reviews about David Allen's newest book Making It All Work: Winning at the Game of Work and the Business of Life, but I am happy enough with this system that I may give it a shot soon.  Happy reading!
Comment_Title: A complete closed system for dealing with the day-to-day

Comment: This book creates a comfortable zone of sophistication with an abundant and abounding proliferation of buzzwords and jargon, designed to facilitate the reader's engagement with the material.Stripped of the jargon, the book says "figure out what stuff you want to solve, make lists of how to solve them, prioritize those lists, and write things down to free up your brain space."  There is the entire work, deprived of jargon and endorsements, in 28 words.For some crazy reason, the Kindle version costs more than the paperback.  For sake of not empowering such modalities of information transference pricing strategies, I procured a cover-deprived volume at a purveyor of previously owned printed works.
Comment_Title: Leverage the paradigm to create opportunities of buzzwords

Comment: This book really helps put things into perspective and offers wonderful suggestions on getting your act together! I'm still working on it and will need to peruse the book from time to time to remember all the insights. The initial set up of files is great and the concepts for all of it are solid. I highly recommend it!
Comment_Title: Great book for organizing and managing your business and even home!

Comment: I have read most of the time management books out there in an effort to help my executive coaching clients and this one tops the list. David Allen really understands today's busy businessperson and using his system truly revolutionizes your approach to time and productivity. The book is useful at any level and it takes time to implement some things--it's a process if you really want to make change. Great stuff!
Comment_Title: The best business book since 7 habits!

Comment: This is a great book with a lot of nice ideas.  I feel that visualizing your success and developing what your criteria for that success is helps tremdously.I especially relate to the commentary about how we often remember things that we need to take care of when we can't do anything about them.  A few tips and tricks for helping yourself remember things at key moments can get you from To-do to Done! a lot faster and ease your mind.I don't always do the things in this book, but I find most of the suggestions helpful enough that I feel encouraged to keep trying them.
Comment_Title: Now if it only came with something that made you do it!

Comment: This book is key to increasing efficiency and productivity in a world where we all have too much to do. The methods David Allan describes really work to simplify the way we manage both personal and work tasks, projects, and time.If this advice is implemented peace of mind, creativity, and personal free time will increase dramatically. Important things will not fall through the cracks.Using these methods provides a great opportunity to get control of your inbox, your time,and your life.
Comment_Title: Getting Things Done: The Art of Stress Free Productivity

Comment: I have ADD. It's fashionable to have ADD. In my CEO development group, everyone jokes that they have it. But I really do. Diagnosed and medicated. I don't have it bad, but I have it.Like lots of people with ADD, I can focus. The danger is when I turn from one thing to the next. When I do, things get dropped, misplaced, forgotten. There is too much to do; we all have that problem. But there is always so much going on in my head, that what another person might luckily recall doesn't occur to me.  Out of sight is truly out of mind.So, I've always struggled with getting the important things done. That's why David's book is such a gift. It describes principles for keeping things organized. The brain, my brain anyhow, cannot be relied upon to keep track of what needs to be done. There are companies and web sites devoted to exploring and elaborating on Allan's principles, so I won't try to enumerate them all here. Let me instead highlight what is so valuable about Allen's approach.Much of the value is that he is not advocating a specific system. The principles can be applied to whatever method works for you. It can be paper or electronic, PC or Mac. As long as you get ideas out of your head, keep tasks separated by stage (like don't file things in your inbox), review all your commitments each week, and apply the other principles to whatever system works for you, you'll get the results.While my discipline is not perfect, Allan's guidelines have helped me immeasurably. This can be a life changing book.  It has been for me.

After just finishing this book I felt I a bit confused. This book should have had some great ideas that just bounced off the pages but it was disjointed, scattered and difficult. Not the concepts, they were quite basic and intuitive, but the way the book was written just feels extremely heavy. I had a hard time focusing on what the author's points were and lost interest quickly. I was looking forward to this book but left very disappointed.
Comment_Title: I'm sorry, I just didn't get why everyone else likes this book

Comment: If you're feeling overwhelmed by today's frenetic pace of life and all that it brings--then get a new perspective on how to see it and live it. I found this book in the business section but it really should be in the "Life" category. This is a book that really shows you how to organize your LIFE, so you can free up all the clogs in your mind and live life the way you're REALLY wanting to live it and not the way old dysfunctional patterns you've developed over the years are handcuffing you presently. I also highly recommend the two sequels to this book which are equally enlightening.

Not quite finished with the book yet but appreciate the over-all system and am working to implement it. It's a good read for anyone interested in taking a look at his or her personal system of organization (or lack thereof) and at least making a few improvements or even whole-hearted change.

Although one may not have th epersonality type to appreciate this approach to getting things done, I have found that it works really well for me.  Regardless, David Allen really thought this book through and delivered a really effective means to becoming productive.
