Comment: I was really looking forward to getting this book before I set up my home-based business. I was told it was great for time-management stragglers like myself. I found it not easy to navigate through, if you want to get to the pointers right away. Lots of too-obvious preaching which is a time waster in itself. Point form, do this and don't do that sort of advice would have been more my style. There is good info in there--so I've been told--but right now its on my shelf for a time when I have the time....

Not a fad "diet" that you break within a few days.  This system is simple, elegant, logical and really a pleasure both to implement and maintain.  A gem of a book.  I can't thank David Allen enough for writing this.

I mean, of course it's not a great book in the sense of oh, say, The Poisonwood Bible or The Man Who Fell In Love With The Moon.  There is no great plot to getting organized. But really, this book is simple and motivating and it works.

David Allen's work is simple to understand and profound in its' application to all facets of living life.  I have found a source of wisdom to help guide me through my day to day activities while being able to keep my focus on what's most important to me in the bigger picture.  I strongly recommend this book to anyone looking to get out in front of the activities that make their life what it is.  This work will put you in control of your personal and professional life.  I can also see this being a valuable tool for students.

I've struggled my entire life with organization. I've gone ahead with projects and have great ideas, but my lack of skill in this area has made it a struggle sometimes and always has kept me on edge because I know I am forgetting something or letting something slip while I move with little focus. Using the tools Mr. Allen gave in his book has improved my business and personal life quite a bit, and keeps me focused on what I need to be getting done and when. For the first time in awhile I have some peace of mind and can relax instead of constantly reminding myself of things I forgot to do earlier. If you have problems with focus and organization, this book is a god-send!
Comment_Title: The best organizational tool I've ever used

Comment: I prefer not to use big words, but I liked this book because of the way it made me feel: progress in my work became tangible and I psychologically liked that. And I got more things done. I personally liked the good feeling more than the productivity increase (which for me is just a side effect) while my manager noticed the latter - win-win situation!I got inspired to read this book after I attended a workshop about GTD held by my employer - one of David's guys was the trainer. During that time I felt that I could take control of what modern IT life throws at me. The book only strengthened that feeling. David's style is a bit dry at times, but overall it is very easy to read. Most of what he says (or all) is just common sense, but he puts it all together, explaining and encouraging changes.I'll start with the end, more philosophical chapter, and add some ideas of mine. In life there are two major problems:1) we don't know what we want to do2) we don't know how to do something that we want.As he puts it, it's like yin yang from Chinese Taoism - two complementary aspects of the same things. The solutions are:1) make things up2) make things happenEasy! Problem is that most people don't do either of them too well, and feel unhappy most of the time. David is trying to help with these issues as they show up in the life of a modern IT worker.Obviously, he cannot tell you what to want - but he emphasizes Mind Sweep, which is putting all your thoughts on a material support (paper or computer). The book helps mostly - and obviously - with the second part: the making things happen.The mind is for us to master and use, but unless we use it properly it could harm us rather than help. The mind always reminds us of what we need to do. For example, when you see a flashlight in your home your mind tells you "hey, the batteries inside are drained, let's get buy new ones", and so on each time you go by the flashlight. The mind is trying to help - indeed batteries are needed. But, what can you do at home? Nothing! It would be nice if the mind would remind you about batteries only when you drive by some store and only at that time - that is only when you can do something about getting batteries. Unfortunately, the mind doesn't work like that. Every time something needs to be changed or done, a part of your mind is tracking that all the time, reminding you about it, consuming a part of your psychic energy. And, as David puts it, most people have around 300 things in their heads that need to be tracked - no wonder that consumes a lot of energy. If you have even two thoughts to track, then the efficiency goes down a lot, let alone when you have 300. What is his solution? The GTD system!And what is the GTD system? It is David's way of getting the mind clear of thoughts, "mind like water" as he says inspired by Eastern books, when you get into a state called "the zone" by athletes, where focusing is easy and doing things - and getting them done -  comes naturally.As he says, "you shouldn't have the same thought twice, unless you like that thought". He emphasizes that you should handle both your work and personal life - any kind of tracking thought needs to get out of the mind.His system has more phases - collect, process, organize, review and do. I won't get into too many details - his book does that and also there are many Internet resources set by GTD enthusiasts. Collect happens at every moment - as you have a thought you put it on a list in your in-basket (physical or a computer list), same if your boss enters your office and tells you about a new work item. Processing happens regularly - twice a day, every two hours, etc. - he doesn't set hard limits. Processing means asking "what is this actually? Does it have an outcome?".If the answer is no outcome, it was just a random thought or thing that came at you. The next question - is it actionable? If no, you can trash it, or file it (he explains more systems of filing).David emphasizes actions a lot - the mind will keep quiet only if you get to define an action for that item. If you don't, you will still get reminded like for the batteries case. So, if an action is needed, decide that action (call Joe, email Mary, write report, talk to wife, etc.). "I need to fix car" is an item that comes to mind. "Call repair shop at 555-1234" is not an item any more, it's an action. Processing and organizing means getting from "stuff" to actions. An action could be delegated to someone (an employee, spouse, kids, etc.), deferred (set into a calendar), etc.Some thoughts turn into a project - like house remodeling. Projects are just a set of actions. At any moment you ask - what is the next actions? GTD is a about determining actions and doing them.I will only add the review part - David suggests reviewing all the projects and actions lists weekly and update them accordingly. To quote him, "that's the time to be creative, to dare". Do no periodic review and GTD will fail.The system teaches how to handle details, how to do things. GTD starts at the bottom, "at the runway" (per the book), it doesn't make you ask yourself what your purpose in your job, career, family and life in general - there are other books for that. David Allen beliefs that once you know how to do things you will automatically gain confidence and ask yourself those higher questions, but it doesn't work the other way around like other similar books suggest.All in all, if in your life there are many events that change things often (e.g. you work in IT, etc.) then this is a highly recommended book. Even if you don't it is still worth reading it - everyone has personal projects that need to get done better. Last but not least, getting things done will make you feel good, and nothing can beat that - what can you ask more from a book?

I'm only semi-organized by nature.  I'm one who can find most things, most of the time.  I don't miss many deadlines.  However, when it happens that I can't find something, can't remember a task that is right on the fringe of my conscious brain or realize that something I should have done was overlooked, I have to ask myself what I'm doing wrong.  Well, this book answered my questions.David Allen has shown me the error of my ways.  He reveals that not being in control by way of an organized system is stressful and destructive.  If your mind isn't free of all the "need-to-do" items in your life, you become stressed and you also waste energy better used on the task at hand.  After he explained it, it seemed like such a "well.. duh!" concept.  Why didn't I think of that?  In essence, I have been sabotaging myself and my goals.His next step is to guide you through the process of setting up a very useful and very workable system.  Finally, he teaches you how to use the system.  Getting through the initial steps (putting things in order) can seem to be fair amount of work but will vary depending on how organized you are already.  In my case, it's going to be a lot of work unfortunately.I've recently started using his system.  Getting through "in", buying a label printer and setting up folders, etc.  (By the way, his suggestion for purchasing a label printer may seem silly to some, but it's the best purchase I've made in a long time.  What a difference it makes.  I purchased the Brother 2700/2710 and love it.)My journey is by no means complete.  My email inbox is still a disaster but will soon be conquered.  And, I get lost on occasion and have to return to his book and re-read a short section.  I'm getting it down though and am happily witnessing results.I plan to read the entire book again since the first time through has been so helpful for me.  It really is all about training (or re-training) yourself and developing a little discipline.  It's NOT complex, just different.  Bottom line... it works.As a final note, I'll confess to completely ignoring one of David's suggestions.  He advocates the absence of hanging file folders.  I use manila folders just as he prescribes but then stuff them into, yes.... hanging folders.  I won't give them up.  Sorry David.
Comment_Title: VERY useful information.  VERY positive impact on my life.

Comment: I've been wondering for years how to get rid of the anxious feeling I have about keeping up with my everyday tasks. This book has pinpointed the problem & given me a solution.Trying to keep a to do list wasn't working for me at all.His suggestions for collecting all ideas so there's never anything waffling around in my mind is FANTASTIC. On day one of reading his book I got everything off my mind and immediately felt relaxed. I knew that as long as I keep up with the other steps, which are all very simple, I can rely on the whole system.Amazing!!! I feel like a whole new person!!! Relaxed and yet accomplishing things better than before.Thank you!!!!!
Comment_Title: The answer I've been looking for!

Comment: This is a very, very good book and if you're looking for something to really help make a difference in your life, this is probably a very good place to start.First, there is no substitute for self-discipline if you want to change your life. Too many self-help books fail to acknowledge this point. There are plenty of "systems" that work, if you have the self-discipline to follow through. Most self-help books and motivational speakers will get you "juiced up", but then it's up to you. But... those self-help books never addressed the self-discipline problem, did they?This book focuses on specific elements of self-discipline, although you still need to be disciplined to follow through.On the down-side, I believe this book is far too long and detailed. A tough editor could eliminate a third to a half of it in my view. David Allen, while an exceptionally helpful and positively intentioned human being, is clearly quite a left-brain dominant character, and some of his right-brain discussions are so layered with left-brain detail that they become fuzzy. Don't fuss yourself when it gets fuzzy - just read on.On the up-side, Allen separates himself from so many productivity and motivational gurus specifically because there is a lifetime's worth of practical, one-to-one, this-is-what-actually-happens-in-the-trenches knowledge in this book.This book is not perfect. But in my view it's more likely to be directly helpful to more people than the vast, vast majority of "do this to improve your life" titles on the market.Be prepared to put aside a full week about four to six weeks from the day you buy this book. Then buy this book and read it once through. Then, just before you get to the full week that you've put aside, start again at the start and go for it.You'll still need your own self-discipline. But instead of sending you onto the street pumped, this book will have shown you how to stay in the middle of all your mess and get that sorted. Good luck with it.
Comment_Title: One of the best self-help books on the market

Comment: Allen's book delivers what it promises, without wasting your time!His methods is surprisingly simple (almost common sense) but Allen gathers it all and organize them all for you, pack and put it on a shelf, right there just to pick and use.No more excuses to procrastinate your obligations.
Comment_Title: A light in the middle of a swarm of promises

Comment: As far as I'm concerned, the author hit a home run with this book.  I could easily relate to what he was saying.  It fit my situation and helped me get things done where other techniques such as time management did not.

I was given this book by my business partner, whose wife recommended it to him.  After having tried Franklin planners and Day Timers over the years I was a bit skeptical, especially since I wasn't looking for a new productivity system.  Boy was I wrong!  This is the most productive system I've ever used.  I also bought the white paper from his website showing in detail how to implement this in Outlook.  He teaches practical processes that work.  I've been using GTD for about six months now and I love it.  I am much more productive than I've ever been and things don't fall through the cracks.  One of the things I love about this process is that it can be implemented with a variety of tools - not just proprietary tools like those from Franklin.  Franklin sells overpriced appointment calendars.  I've taken their courses but found the implementation of their process impractical.  The basic premise of GTD - that you need to track everything and must be able to respond to changes immediately - works for the reality of my business environment.  If you've tried and failed with other productivity programs I encourage you to try this for yourself.  The investment of buying the book to try it out is far less than other systems.
Comment_Title: This process works better than others

Comment: Getting Things Done could have been much shorter, upon the completion of which, one could cross the task off one's project list and then move on, having satisfactorily lessened one's cognitive load.  It is repeats itself, is full of ridiculously obvious advice, seems patently obvious, and yet ... and yet ... the pure weight of repetition is of great value.  Why?  It takes time for any idea to sink in, and in, and in, and ... Allen is trying to change the way the reader behaves, and will behave and how easy, dear reader, do you think that is, or will be, with you or me?  Constructing a system to live by, one that provides the basis for a well-thought-out, balanced life, Stoic in intent, an Epictetan system for life and business: what can I suggest but that you buy it and try it?  I am still digesting the work, my copy is highlighted where appropriate, and probably where not, and I plan to buy copies for family and staff, as appropriate.  So why not more stars?Because, I am shamefaced to admit, I don't know if it will work, I don't know if it will reduce stress, and I am suspicious of the power of any such system to change the way we live.  But I have hopes, so maybe I'll come back in a few months and change the rating!

This is the bible of productivity books, but the best thing about it is that just by *reading* it you will walk away with a better life (IMHO).You can go as far down the rabbit hole of tuning your productivity systems as far as you want, but just knowing the basic premise that *writing down* every little task you need to do as soon as you identify it will automatically make you more productive and, more importantly, *reduce your stressing about things*.The first time I read this book months ago, I started using simple todo lists more when my schedule got hectic - thats all. But when I had a contract project finishing up days after my wedding, I returned to the audiobook to refresh myself and realized how much I had actually adopted from the book, and tuned it to get through a really stressful and busy period in my life with relative ease.If you are unsure or a lazy reader (like me), I would recommend the abridged audiobook. Its a fast, easy and passive way to get started.For me, I bit the bullet and got a hosted exchange server with outlook 2007 - now my laptop, my desktop, and my blackberry are always 100% synced instantly with my contacts, *tasks*, email (whose inbox I always keep *empty!*), and calendar.For me, this solution is perfect and managing my time is now a non-issue.
Comment_Title: Everyone should read this book (or audiobook at least)

Comment: I read the book cover to cover and implemented his strategy. I think it is well written and very useful. Basically the system uses lists and simple filing to organize all of your incoming "stuff". The most interesting aspect was the psychological relief you get from knowing all your thoughts and incoming data are captured and filed away for action later on. It actually makes me want to come up with more things to do!!! I found once I organized everything, I had free time and could take on more without worrying about forgetting something or letting things get out of control.
Comment_Title: Very helpful if you are logical and serious about getting organized

Comment: Though every detail may not be for everyone, David Allen's common sense approach to managing your life has something in it for everyone.  This isn't about what to do - it's about how to organize what you do so that you can avoid the "out-of-control" feeling that has become such a normal part of life in the modern world.

I typically write only good reviews.  I investigate before I commit to reading something, so I typically like it, and thus, good reviews.  This guy's book/system is beyond good.  It's simple to understand, it doesn't take a lot of discipline to incorporate, and it works so flawlessly.1. Get ALL the stuff out of your head;2. Process it in a system that you trust;3. Do the things that yield return, with the preface that you can only do single "next actionable items," not projects.  Projects are a sequence of next-actionable items (Big difference).They should probably tag this with ADD and ADHD; I have a few friends who suffer from this affliction who would probably have life-changing experiences with this system.
Comment_Title: Wow, I wish someone would have told me sooner!

Comment: I feel as if this author is right inside my head and standing at my desk.  His comprehension of how we live our incredibly complex and busy lives, and the challenges that come with it is totally contemporary and right on. His suggestions are perfect and I will be leading a much better and much more productive life as a result of this book. Thank you, thank you, thank you David Allen!!
Comment_Title: Best book I've read on getting organized.

Comment: David Allen's methods (in conjunction with Merlin Mann's Inbox Zero series) have changed how I handle my work, for both my personal and professional life.I am getting more done, and my stress level is drastically diminished. An empty inbox makes me happy.  : - )

Read GTD one time through. Hard to put down. Read it again to outline and make the knowledge my own. I'm like a born-again GTD evangelist. Like a true holy-roller I started doing as much as I could, as fast as I could because I have seen the light!Projects that have been languishing on the back burner are now active and moving forward. Multiple stacks of piled paper are now neatly organized in a new lateral file cabinet. I didn't really have an inbox. Now I not only have an inbox, I'm spouting profound truths like, "there is no vision without an inbox."Using my pda is no longer painful. I know right where my planning notes are. I can make notes that transform into clear thinking, then projects, then actions by context.Save yourself, brother. GTD. This is the way.
Comment_Title: get SAVED now with simple, direct organizing techniques

Comment: Allen's approach to managing yourself and your world is very good advice on how to be more productive and satisfied. This book is filled with practical, hands-on ideas, tips, tools, and techniques for more effective self-management. Many of us feel overwhelmed and out of control in today's fast-paced world. This book and the book Understanding: Train of Thought are great ways to get a handle on all that "stuff" in our lives and figure out how to better manage the flow of information that never seems to stop. Five stars all the way!

#1 if you are not already naturally organized, then I can only expect you will toss this book in the rubbish bin because his process would be excruciating torture to you. It is an in-depth, deep clean.If you are already naturally organized and yet feel you are not truly maximizing the effort you are putting into it, then this is well worth the time to read.I easily related to this book and took away a few productive processes. It is over all a helpful book on organizing beyond the ubiquitous to do list. He has clear steps to get stalled projects moving forward. Hammering the point that the frustrations you face in getting things done are in actuality your lack of dealing with the hard question of what is the next physical action I need to take with this to deal with it. That may very well be toss it in the rubbish or Make a phone call...Unfortunately, more often than not his example of the next action step is make a call... I started to cringe half way through the book whenever he wrote "Finally, when it's time to actually do an action, LIKE MAKING A CALL..." Towards the end of the book I was saying out loud and laughing "What is our next action step... Oh, of course make a call!"That one criticism aside, I am trying his tickler file concept and do find it useful. I have implemented his mind sweep to organizing myself before the week so as to be prepared to face all of the inevitable interruptions and schedule changes with ease while accomplishing my weekly objectives. Although, in my case frequently the next action step is "turn off the phone, IM and email" so that I can work.
Comment_Title: If you are not already naturally organized, then his process would be excruciating torture to you.

Comment: David Allen's concise and useful guide is built largely on the idea that, while people "think" in terms of entire projects, human action can only be practically applied to one aspect of a project at any one time.In order to be effective, and work intelligently,we must first diligently construct our catalog of things that "need" doing and then proceed to priortize them in terms of their relative importance. This is only list making, however the act of breaking each project down, in order of importance, into discrete action steps is a more complex intellectual process, and is where we often fail. It is not a complex concept, but even the very intelligent lose sight of it under the pressures of life and work.I found it interesting that many of the key points emphasized by Allen were articulated by Earl Nightingale, a famous radio commentator, decades ago. They are no less true today. The difficulty is forming and maintaining the habit structure that enables us to be masters of work, rather than slaves to unfinished business.Bob MoffitRetired Executive & Industry Consultant
Comment_Title: It's That Next Step that Matters...

Comment: I have an associate who can't meet deadlines. I give him a deadline and set it two weeks before the project is needed. Doesn't matter. He won't make it. So I bought him this book. "No more projects until you read this," I told him.He read it. He's not missed a project deadline yet.People who have their own businesses, generally have deadlines and projects. Things have to be done by a certain time. If nothing else, we have to have our income tax in by midnight April 15 in the U.S.But many people put things off and that creates stress. Stress for the person who procrastinates and stress for those who depend on him or her. We all need a time management system.This book will help you to clear out your clutter. It will help you to know how to handle a project, to break it up and work at it in a way that's effective for you.Highly recommended.
Comment_Title: If you have deadlines, you need this book

Comment: While the abridged audio CD version of Getting Things Done makes a perfect refresher tool for those who read the full book originally, too much detail and background is missing for this to be someone's first introduction to the GTD method of time management. Unfortunately, the unabridged audio won't be widely available until 2008.Overall, the GTD system has a lot to offer. It's "open source" and "platform-independent," meaning you can use as much or as little of it as you want and adapt it to whatever organizational system you already like or are forced to use by circumstance--Outlook, FranklinCovey, 3x5s, whatever. Yes, it pretty much comes down to making a to-do list, but GTD's approach adds the subtle differences that make the lists actually effective reminders and trackers, rather than an overwhelming mess o' stuff to get done. If you've ever written something down on a list and then never looked at it again, give GTD a try.
Comment_Title: Read the full version first, use abridged audio for review

Comment: I first bought this book about 6 months ago, and it has improved my life incredibly.  Even if you don't follow every one of his suggestions, or choose not to employ David Allen's GTD system, at the very least you'll gain a much greater understanding of stress-free productivity, effective workplaces, and the bottlenecks that prevent people from achieving their full productive potential.It certainly took longer to set up my system than the "2 days" Allen continuously mentions in the book, but even while you're setting up and fine-tuning your personal system, you begin to get a sense of that "stress-free productivity".  Now, my system is running smoothly, and I've been able to control my numerous projects with greater efficiency and effectiveness.Most importantly, having a system in place will enable you to focus on your greater goals.  I work in two startup companies, but I've always had a dream of being involved in local politics; now I'm also helping coordinate a grassroots political campaign in addition to my  9-5 commitments.  You may want to spend more time with your family or significant other, go golfing, start a new business venture or take up a new hobby.  This book can give you the system and the structure to allow you to pursue whatever life goals you have, and I consider it an invaluable life resource.  I've recommended it to many of my friends and family, and they've experienced similar results.
Comment_Title: This book will change your life

Comment: I like this book, but I particulary loved his second book, "Ready for Anything," which I consider a potentially life-changing book. Actually, read both...more than once!

Allen's methodology works like magic. I finished reading the book a week ago, and I can say it had a great impact on the way I organize my life. This is much more than how to organize your time, It's about a very subtle technique - along with technology support - that helps you manage your ideas or projects and have them executed with much less effort. You would need a PDA and the Microsoft 0utlook add-in for GTD (Getting Things Done) to experience the full benefit.
wow I did not finish reading it and it has already transformed my life!!!

I've read several management books and books on procastination and productivity, but nothing like Getting Things Done. It's not a motiviational book (although it's extremely motivating,) it's just a nuts and bolts, here's step one - here's step two, book with enough uncommon sense wisdom about human nature to clarify what it is about the process that makes it so valuable.Get past the touch-feely opening section with the black belt analogy, and chapters 2 to the end are absolutely chock-filled with the direct, clear, and liberating actions you can take to get your career and your life on track. My work-related stress has gone down by at least 2/3rds since I started practicing the GTD process, and I'm enjoying my career again. I'm extremely impressed with the deep insights David presents about how to manage your own life - why don't they teach this stuff in school?
Comment_Title: Absolutely changed my life. Thank you, David Allen.

Comment: Many people will, after reading this book, say: well, that was obvious. Much of the stuff in this book is simply common sense advice, but for me it completed what I knew was an incomplete way for me to track all the stuff I had to do. David Allen described a watertight step by step plan, that if followed will greatly enhance your productivity. Simply by making sure that you collect everything you need to do, also what's only in your head, processing it, organizing and reviewing it in an efficient way.It's good to note that this book is primarily written for the professional with a busy working and social life. Among the advice is to buy a big filing cabinet and use it to create a reference system. Something that I think wouldn't be appropriate for anyone.Buy this book if you want to make sure you get control over your busy life, don't get this book if you want to be motivated to get work done, there are better books for that.

David does a great job of pointing out the very simplistic method of getting things done and admittedly I was one that made that method way to complicated, so his book/method helped me get back on a highly productive track.I would recommend this book to any one that feels that they can't handle all that they have to do effectively and needs some help with organization.My only criticism is that I felt he could have condensed the book and still delivered those highly effective points in life.  None the less, it is well worth the purchase and read.
Comment_Title: Great material, could be condensed a little

Comment: Here's a suggestion that should help you implement the principles, methods and action points in this book; Keep a note-pad next to you at all times... when you see a Principle, Method or Action Point, write it down. After you're  done reading the book, you'll have a nice quick reference sheet to start getting organized. It's just too time-consuming and cumbersome to go back through pages of highlights and markings while trying to implement a methodology.This is an excellent book. You can follow the instructions to the letter or modify to suite your needs.
Comment_Title: Very Useful & Solid Approach to Personal Organization

Comment: I haven't quite finished reading this book, yet I've implemented a lot of what he suggests. It's a great way to get a better handle on your work and your life.

Getting Things Done has been an incredible help to my work life, and I look forward to implementation at home. It is a comprehensive system which enables you to handle all your tasks, your goals and dreams, without a burdensome recaculation every day on your calendar. I highly recommend this read, but only if your willing to implement the changes and systems that are advised. If you do, you will not regret it, and it will save you 1-2 hours a day, and increase your professionalism.

David Allen's book Getting Things Done is the best time-management system I have come across--and I have learned and used several over a period of well over 30 years, both during a career and now while retired.  This is time-management on steroids.  The writing is clear and enjoyable to read.  Also, Allen gives in his book and audio CDs plenty of examples and analogies that clarify his points.  His system has obviously been perfected over the years of his teaching in seminars as well as practicing it himself.  There are many phrases that capture the essential principles and ideas meaningfully, precisely, and memorably.Allen takes time-management (this title doesn't do it justice, maybe "life-management" would  be closer, or "Life by Design") to a higher level of intelligence and effectiveness.  Even to call this work well-thought-out is an inadequate compliment: For It contains powerful tools that have been refined in the furnace of experience, both the teacher's and his students'.  This is a system of getting things done that will, applied consistently, be effective in any work situation, or at home, or during school.  Yet it is not rigid or oppressive, but flexible and under your control.If you want your life to be more than a meandering, haphazard experience; if you want to do something with your life that counts, that achieves something, that makes a difference; or, if you just want or need to get a lot done without overwhelming yourself and stressing yourself unnecessarily, I highly recommend this book.
This book has some really practical ideas that are easy to implement.  Highly Recommended.

This is a most helpful and uncomplicated book which takes personal/business organising to a new level. The philosophy is explained well before embarking on the step by step journey through the process. Various quotes and overviews help to reinforce particular points along the way. I have suggested to all of my team members that they should purchase a copy as in the future it will form the basis for managing our various projects.
The methods presented in this book are simple and may seem dumb but they really do work.
Comment_Title: Really does help get things done

Comment: David Allen book explain in a simple way an interesting method to edit, organize and *actually do* the things in your to do list. It is a method based on a few easy step, easy to learn and apply. I've been using it for the last 4/5 weeks and it is working pretty good. If you are lost in todo list this is the book to buy. If you are a mac user there is also a software to help you apply this method, it is called iGTD.The other book by David Allen (52 Productivity Principles for Work and Life) it is non as good as this one.
Comment_Title: Simple and effective way to organize your todo list

Comment: We all have too much to do, but most of us could be completing much more if we learned to stop worrying so much about not getting things done. David Allen makes the point that we have all these tasks ("unfinished loops") in our mind that keep us from attacking and completing our work with clarity. We need to identify all of our tasks (yes, every single one), and make sure they are cared for in some way (discarded, scheduled for later, immediately addressed, etc.) by our "system" so we are not burdened by them and can concentrate on the task at hand.Adhering to the "system" that David recommends requires discipline. Those not used to planning will shudder at some of the suggestions, but there is no doubt that if implemented and executed properly, productivity improvement will result.I personally favor Covey's First Things First time management approach which I believe achieves the same freeing effect, while ensuring focus is placed on the most important tasks. However, both methods have many similarities and following either would be beneficial.-- Nick McCormick, Author Lead Well and Prosper: 15 Successful Strategies for Becoming a Good Manager

The book that launched a movement.First, I must confess that I originally read this book in 2001 when it was originally published.  I found that life-changing.  I must also confess that this is a review written by a guy whose personalized car at license tags read, "GTD GUY."With that said, I wanted to revisit the book six years after publication and give it a fresh read to see if it stood up to the passage of time.  I found that it did and offers a highly practical approach to getting more done.  David Allen's approach to capturing all the things that you need to do in your life, processing them, and setting up systems to act upon them is an invaluable template for productivity.  He also strongly advocates the weekly discipline of reviewing all of your projects, next actions, and life goals.Some people may find fault with Allen's advocacy of gadgetry, but this is an adjunct to his discussion.  I believe he is correct that people gravitate toward systems and where they find they are tools congenial, whether those tools are high-tech or low-tech.Others may argue that the focus on getting things done puts the emphasis on things, and devalues people and relationships.  I'm not sure that that is a fair criticism of GTD, which has become more than a book but has morphed into a movement.  (In fact, David Allen himself now occupies somewhat of a cult status among productivity geeks.)Nevertheless, Allen would probably argue that when you get more things done, you are relaxed and stress free and can have more time and energy to devote to cultivating important relationships in your life.  GTD does not purport to be a template for solving every problem in your life.  It is merely a tool for getting things done.  Those with a tendency toward workaholism may use or abuse the techniques in GTD to neglect important relationships.  Is that a flaw in the book or a flaw in the personality makeup of the reader?  Perhaps the answer is evident.Six years after publication, GTD remains a bit of a "Bible" of personal productivity.  Even if you do not adopt the entire system hook, line and sinker, you can graze through it like a buffet, picking and choosing a variety of productivity tips to help you manage the craziness of modern life.
Comment_Title: Turbo-charge your personal and professional productivity.

Comment: While some books talk; this one talks and delivers. It's probably the best book that you can read on basic time management and personal organization. Full of practical tips like another book which I read recently, Eightstorm: 8-Step Brainstorming.

I love this Book. I bought this book and Total Workday Control Using Microsoft Outlook and I am amazed at how much work I get done.  This is the best thing I have done to improve my work flow at the office.  Thanks to these two books, I have become so efficient, it's incredible!
This is an awesome book!  I wish I'd implemented these practices earlier -- instead of so many failed attempts at priority management.

Wow!  This really is one of those books that changed my life.  Chock full of action steps to organize your life so you can, like the title says, get things done!For the person who likes action above all else, this book put my life into hyperdrive, allowing me to manage all projects more efficiently.
Comment_Title: Make Your "To Do" List a "Done" List

Comment: If you are an information worker like myself then you have to check out David Allen's system for handling a high work load in a sane manner.  The audio read of this book is a bit dry but my results are almost life changing.

This book offers practical advice for organizing and managing the "TO DOs" of life.  It changed my life.  I still have the same huge workload, but I now know what it is and can be choices about what to do next.  I recommend this to anyone stressed out about having too much to do.  The method really works.

Getting Things Done action orient method of self-management. by David Allen.Getting things done is an excellent book for increasing productivity by David Allen.He uses the old Japanese adage "mind like water" from Karate to describe how our minds best work with relaxation and efficiency.However, we face a conflict in the day to day grind of so many things to do.  Allen's book lays out a plan for a solution.His theory is that you "get everything out of your head" and into a "trusted system".A trusted system can be a calendar or a planner.But it has to be something that you review on a regular basis.One suggestion which I found immediately useful was the "2-minute rule" meaning that if you have something to do that comes up and it will take you 2 minutes or less then you should complete it immediately.I personally chose this book to get organized, reduce the stress associated with many tasks and also to increase my productivity.Allen recognizes that traditional productivity skills and the plethora of organization tools available today are really sufficient for successfully "getting things done" in a more organized and less stressful manner.While he recognizes the value of these tools...he argues that there is no device which is a magic bullet for organization.Allen states that the most important thing is our "action" and not our thoughts when getting things done.In other words Allen suggests we should do our thinking ahead of time and when getting things done we are action oriented.When we finish one task we have in place a system for simply moving onto the next.Here are a few points from Allen's book'Make decisions about actions required on stuff when it shows up not when it blows up.'Organize reminders of your projects and the next actions on them in appropriate categories.'Keep your system current, complete, and reviewed sufficiently to trust your intuitive choices about what you're doing (and not doing) at any time."*Create a workflow based on context so that you get things done by action and not relying on the mental reminder but instead relying on a "trusted system" of context which leads one to complete the next task at hand with the correct timing. In other words using a system of external support to free your mind of anxiety, worry, and distraction that prevents one from getting things done.* set up a "trusted system" that allows you to do the thinking in advance, generate a series of actions which we can later undertake without any further planning and get rid of the mental "reminder system"* Capture everything that you need to track or remember or act on in what Allen calls a 'bucket': either a physical inbox, email inbox, etc. AllSo why is David Allen so bent on Action?buckets should be processed to empty at least once per week.Why Action is most important' Principles of front end planning that allows a person to  method of categorization and plan of action' Enable the individual to move the "tasks" out of ones mind and frees one's mind to attend to the task at hand.' setting up a system of recording them somewhere else in an organized system that will lead to action' Advocates creating lists that are context specific and not completing things based on priority.Overall I rate this book very highly and would suggest it to anyone who is trying to stay efficient and organized!

I'm only about 25% through this book and it has already helped me.  Allen is right that you should replace your vague worrying about things needing done and put it somewhere.  Mine is on paper (in Word), double sided in eight sections so far, and that's what works for me, can take it anywhere to add and cross off.  Half of the sections are work (next action, projects, long term goals) and the other are personal (next actions, projects, home/garden).  I run my own manufacturing company, am a mom of active kids, soccer coach, school volunteer and boyscout leader, so I could use all the help I can get.  Keep the list on my computer and do the weekly review.At first, when I put down the list of things, I was shocked and dismayed at the amount of things that were there being left undone; however, after getting over the shock, I found that things were getting done much better.  Having the lists organized permits me to work on autopilot and make more headway than I otherwise would have.  I can tell that breaking down projects into actionable items is going to be GREAT!  I found out about the book on Lifehacker Geek to Live, a place for excellent tech tips.  I'm making myself read the book every day (don't usually have time for book reading), and I will get things done.Many thanks to David.
Comment_Title: Will help organize your overwhelming life

Comment: I'm fairly skeptical of what the latest "increase your productivity" fad books that blow through management from time to time.  I've heard about Getting Things Done for a while and I was finally forced by my employer to read it.I would classify this book as useful and pretty no-nonsense.  Essentially the author promotes getting organized so that you don't have background processing going on in your mind about tasks that you haven't delt with yet in some way.  The book is about helping you collect and categorize all these tasks both in your personal and professional life so that they are out of your head and into a system that is external to yourself.  Thus your mind lets go, and if you build your system properly, you can end up getting a lot more done both at work and at home.  I like the books approach of not telling you exactly how to organize your life other then a few concepts that the author has observed working countless times in business environments.  There is a system, but it is loose as long as you focus on a few core concepts (you have to read the book to get those).The book is worth the read and definitely if you have to read some business fad type book, pick this one over others.  There is some very practical wisdom that can be found in its pages.

Do not look to GTD as a quick guide to dealing with your life. The actual information is very good, the longwinded presentation is not. It honestly felt like a term paper with a requirement to meet a minimum number of words.  I could only choke down a chapter a day, but it was worth the effort.

So I ordered GTD from Amazon after reading several websites and blogs and going to the David Allen site as well.  I got the book, opened the cover and saw that the book began on page 15 -- pages 1-14 and all the front matter were missing.  Still the bulk of the information was there, so I began reading it, after contacting Amazon to report the defective book and order a replacement.Amazon, lickety split, sent me a new copy of GTD. This copy was ALSO missing pages before page 15, but also had pages out of order...what?????So here I am getting things done, and reminding myself (a la Fly Lady) that it's progress, not perfection. Meanwhile I'll send this new copy back and try yet again. It gets 4 stars (because the content is transformative), not five because the quality control problem is so surprising in a book on productivity.

Simple, practical advice on achieving stress free productivity. It is  like a workbook. You can use it as a coach who is guiding you step by step to achieve stress free productivity.When you read Getting Things Done, you are doing good to yourself. Thank you David for gifting me such a great book!Abhishek

Being a nerd and more than little obsessive, I find leaving work at work when coming home a difficult challenge. With Allen's methodology I stand a chance when things are hectic and overwhelming at work. I've only been using it for a little while but already I feel less neurotic and more in control. It's simple and that's the beauty of it so give it a go. Even if it isn't for you, it will at least tell you a lot about the clutter that is your life.

GTD (Getting Things Done) is the martial art of personal productivity management. It teaches you a systematic way to keep projects, tasks, wishes, and "stuff" managed in a universal list system, and off your mind. It leaves you free to devote your full attention to the present moment, knowing that everything you "should be" taking care of is tracked and WILL be taken care of in time. It allows you the flexibility to change your plans when necessary without losing track of your SHOULDS.I've been using GTD for over 4 years now, and I keep rediscovering its beauty and applicability to new situations. Whenever I feel stressed, or find myself working at less than stellar productivity rates - I find that it's because I've neglected some aspect of the GTD system.David Allen is an excellent communicator, and his system is bullet proof. If you would only experience the relaxation of a clear mind that GTD offers once, you will swear by this book like I do.

... so many people struggle with systems that promote productivity.  In fact, as a business coach, I teach a program the incorporates some of Allen's ideas.  I love the simplicity of parallel physical and digital systems.  The cd is useful on long drives, although there are many lists.  I strongly encourage you to purchase this book.  Then implement the ideas! Passionate Action: 5 Steps to Extraordinary Success in Life and WorkDoug Gray, PCC, author of Passionate Action; 5 Steps to Creating Extraordinary Success in Life and Work (2007)
Comment_Title: I have purchased gift copies of this book because

Comment: If you're at all interested in increasing your productivity and you're okay with doing some work to get to a "productive" state, then this book can't be beat. Honestly, it's changed the way I work everyday.

I have taken away more from Getting Things Done than any other time management/ life management book I have ever read.  The reason is simple:  This book is written in a practical way and the applications are therefore easy to implement.  The main point of the book is that if you get things out of your head and into paper, it will clear your mind to think more clearly and be more productive.  I have found this premise to be absolutely true.  I first read the book in 2001 and since then my life is a lot more organized.  I have been using the hanging file system with the labeler that Allen recommends since the very first time I read the book.  I'll admit that I  often (very often, unfortunately) "fall of the wagon" and go back to my old habits, but  when I hit the chaos point, I immediately use the system and within a day I have my mind clear to take on my business.  During the years I have recommended this book a number of times and have given away a number of copies.  I have read reviews which indicate that the methods taught by this book have been covered in other books.  However, having read a number of time management and productivity books, I can simply say that this book is a winner.  Buy it, use it and get productive.
Comment_Title: The best productivity book I have ever read.  It has improved my life.

Comment: I didn't learn a single thing from this book.
Comment_Title: I wish I hadn't bough it...

Comment: I feel like I am 50% more productive, have better control of my time. Less stressed.

Are you wondering if this book only applies to corporate types?  I almost dismissed the book for that reason but am glad I did not.I am at home with young children plus work part time from home.  I experienced immediate relief when, after reading a couple of chapters, I sat down and began writing lists.  In less than thirty minutes I had ten project lists and a Next Action list.  I was surprised at the creative thinking this inspired.What is unique about this book is that you choose the format for your lists.  It doesn't require a specific type of organizer or PDA; you use what works for you.  I wanted something small and portable and went to Office Depot and purchased a leather Franklin Covey index card holder for $15.  I put an empty clementine box on the kitchen counter and use that as an in box.I checked out his website and was happy to see that, other than a few overpriced note taker devices, he's not all about selling products and has a number of free resources on his site.I'm not naive.  I know there will probably always be open loops in my thoughts.  But it's a system that is organic, adaptable to change and reflects your own personal style.  Even if you only partially succeed in using his system you will benefit.

This book got me in control.  From e-mails to to-do lists, to my calendar, voicemails, it helped me develop a system to get rid of worry ("oh no, I forgot to do _____ today") and increase my effectiveness.I think this book has applicability well beyond the corporate office (where it obviously shines).
Comment_Title: Will Change Your Views on Managing Workload and Workflow

Comment: Everyone else has said glowing things about this book, so rather than make a detailed review myself, I'll just tell you this; I FEEL better about my life, and I have certainly been able to accomplish much more than I ever have in such a short period. It's not just the small things, I've made progress on a number of enormous projects that have been stuck in neutral with the help of this system. My wife keeps asking "who is this man? It's not MY husband." This book is WELL worth the purchase price and it's a quick and easy read.

For my way of working this book was wonderful.  It lays out in a very easy to follow format (if not a little redundant) what you must do to keep your daily onslaught of activity going. I have benefited from incorporating these ideas into my work and home activities.If you use MS Outlook I advise buying the $10.00 GTD Outlook PDF off the authors website.  It was and is invaluable.
Comment_Title: Organization of Thought is the Key

Comment: the "getting things done" concept could be explained in a page, so reading this entire book felt like overkill. the book was ok, the concept was great.

I finally took the "Next Action" of studying (not scanning) this widely acclaimed book.  The many ideas and systems described by Allen sound great but, in the end, do not generate a coherent system.  Of the dozens I could cite, I give just two examples.1.  On page 170 he admonishes the reader to not use a categorization of "Hold and Review".  One paragraph later he says that anything that one would have put in "Hold/Review" should actually go in "Read/Review"....with no substantive differentiation.2.  The book is replete with instances where Allen creates a proper noun such as "Someday/Maybe" and then overlays it with another word "Incubate"...which sounds an awful lot like "Hold (incubate?) and Review".While I did not attempt to do so, my overwhelming impression is that a systematic reconsideration of the system and a rewriting of the book in which every component fits in a coherent way with the next, could turn this into a useful system.
Comment_Title: Many great ideas, loosely connected, inconsistently explained

Comment: David Allen's excellent book is a must read if you find yourself awash with "Stuff" to do and trying to figure out what and when to do it all.Of primary importance is creating a system, how it's implemented doesn't matter, that you trust to capture all of the stuff that you need to do. Getting it out of your brain and into your system allows you to free yourself for more productive work without the nagging suspicion that one of those thoughts zipping around in your head should be being addressed instead of the task at hand.It's really a simple, basic approach to, well, getting things done.
Comment_Title: Everybody can use a "system" - This one is elegantly simple.

Comment: I get books on tape for two reasons. The second reason is, after a day of working at a computer, my eyes don't want to look at anything. But the first reason is that I listen to books on tape to keep me awake while driving. So I need a good, engaging reader. This is the first time I've ever had to eject a CD while driving. The CD was putting me to sleep. I only go through half of the first CD, so I really don't know about his program. But he reads in a boring monotone that reminds me of lecturers from the 50's. He may be brilliant, but I'll never know.
Comment_Title: Friends don't let friends read their own books

Comment: For the first time I have gained insight in a structured organization of my large work load. This book helps to establish files and folders, to keep track of projects and to reduce stress. This really helped me to overcome my burden. Excellent book.
Comment_Title: To cure work overload and procrastination

Comment: GTD is helping me to organize the way I work and live. Now, I can get a feeling of a better control over the projects I execute in my life (professionally and socially). This will help you build a new mental model of doing things! One observation: the organization of the book could have been done better.

Next to the Bible, this is the most life changing book I've ever read. I find that the back cover of this book (the same description given above) is at best underwhelming and even deceptive. It's deceptive (not on purpose) because it doesn't give enough persuasive information to let you know how fantastic this book is. For the first time in my 19 years of professional life, the top of my desks in both of my offices are clear, there are no stacks of papers and folders on my shelves, things are in order, my mind is clear and I feel a level of optimism and enthusiasm for my (way too many) projects that I've not had in a long time. My colleagues are envious and amazed because I haven't garnered a reputation of being organized, but they see I am.Allen's approach is fairly low tech. While you can use a computer to help you get organized, you can use traditional pencil, paper, folders and file cabinets. He uses the raw materials everyone else uses. But a master artist and I could have the same materials in front of us and he or she will create a work of art while I will create slop. Ordinary office supplies in the hands of Allen's very logical (and easy to maintain) workflow are a work of art. I can't believe how simple this all is, but after 19 years of always trying to get organized, I certainly did not come up with these dynamite workflow habits, so Allen is to be commended.This was the best money I've spent on a book.
Comment_Title: Next to the Bible, this is the most life changing book I've ever read . . .

Comment: Although I am a grown up, so to speak, and have been for a long time, until I followed the directions on this CD, I still kept my office like I kept my room at 15. I am one of those people who is great and reliable in emergencies, and I am what they call "creative" or an "ideas" person. But, facing middle age and the gazillion tasks of daily work and life, I finally reached a breaking point.A client of mine mentioned that his wife had purchased the book version of this CD for him. As he began describing some of the key concepts, my ears perked up. These days, people like me are labeled ADHD. Mr. Allen's system is so seamless and meticulously organized, without seeming tiresome and obsessive, I am convinced it could help anyone.  Although I am not all the way through my reorganizing process, I am 79% there and making progress, not losing ground, every day. Whether you do everything exactly as he suggests or most of it, this cannot fail you.  Although the CD is abridged, it is enough to apply to almost any situation requiring order and a trusted system to maintain it. The systems he offers are dynamic and can be applied to anything from planning domestic activities to participating in global change. Most of us will benefit enormously and all I can say is, it's a huge relief to have some genuine, unbiased and non-judgemental support, advice and instruction. His pleasant voice and even, steady presentation make the CD comfortable to listen to repeatedly. This is a great product and I highly recommend it.

Like many busy professionals whose days are filled with managing ideas, concepts, projects, electronic information, and paper, I've tried for years to find a system for managing the inputs, to-dos, and outputs of my life.  For my physical space (desk, placement of items) I've found that adapting the 5-S principles from Lean Manufacturing works well.  But most of what I do involves non-physical items: thoughts, ideas, information, knowledge, lists, etc.  How does one get handle on all the "stuff" in one's life?While most approaches focus on mostly useless concepts like "prioritization" and "things to do today", David Allen's GTD approach is context-driven.  I do not know if this would work for everyone, but it clearly and irrefutably worked for me.  The other (nearly zen-like) concept of getting things out of one's mind so one can actually think ABOUT them instead of OF them was very eye-opening.  In many ways, GTD takes the 5-S approach to the physical world and translates it to the concepts and constructs that consume our time (i.e. to-dos, projects, next steps, read, file, store, retrieve, appointment, deadlines, etc.)While I am not ever going to be a fanatic, a "GTD geek", or look at Mr. Allen as a guru, I am profoundly in debt to the simple, elegant, yet robust concepts presented in this book and look forward to reading his other works and to investigating his web site.  My daily work life is finally manageable in this sense:  prior to GTD, I was overwhelmed and out of control. Today I'm overwhelmed and in control.  Believe it or not, this is a profound improvement.I highly recommend this book to anyone who is a "knowledge worker" and is able to grasp concepts such as context-sensitivity.  It may be the "to-do" system you've been looking for.
Comment_Title: A to-do system that (at last) works

Comment: David Allen explains in his book how to get all the things that are clogging up your mind out on notes or lists (either paper, computer, note cards, Palms etc) and in your calendar. By doing this your mind  should become "like water" and could focus on one selected task at hand not being distracted by all the other projects looming in the background of the "RAM" in your brain. He proposes an elaborate system to order your "to do's" and to review the lists keeping them updated and checking on what you have to do.To say it upfront: I love lists, use them all the time and for each purpose and I am working happily with 2 calendars (one for work and one for private life) since almost 30 years. I agree that getting things done is one of the most rewarding accomplishments to feel and to be called "effective", and I like many of the ideas from the book like "mind mapping" to calm the water after the brain storm, or generating an effective file system. But some of David Allen's suggestions seem even to me a bit overdone. I am afraid that if I would start so many lists and notes as he recommended, I would think about them all the time to not forget to check them all, so that my mind would probably not be "like water", but rather like a tsunami. I did not quite understand how the author manages to carry those lists with him on travels without making a list, what lists to take for which occasion. What if I am unexpectedly stuck in traffic and would have time to work on my "to call" list, but did not take it with me? My mind is blank (like water) and I would not know how to effectively fill the time.So, while I don't agree that it makes a lot of sense to rely on this "external brain" I agree that it helps tremendously to write things down. Writing lists or project plans structures your thoughts, helps identify gaps and engraves the action steps in your mind rather than deleting them from your memory.

I bought this audio CD about 3 months ago.  I listen to various things on my hour long drive to work.  I still haven't finished this one, nor have I implemented the techniques.He gives a lot of steps to get organized, which makes sense, but dang, its still alot of steps.  This book is best used by people who do a ton of office work, i.e. sending emails, writing memos, filing stuff.Whats weird is that the key and end result of office work is to organize information.  The Office is a funny show by the way.
Comment_Title: Finishiing this book is on my list of things to do

Comment: Basically his theory of getting organized is putting all pertinent info into folders which are labeled.  He also is adamant about making lists and writing down all information from your head so you can feel in control and be able to sleep at night.

I am a physician executive and I serve as a regional director for a large public health operation. I have read many books on this topic - From Alan Lakein to Steven Covey and (too) many in between. Most end up being so rigid and cumbersome that they ultimately don't last. This one is relatively simple, relatively flexible, and absolutely powerful. The only thing I add is a trick from  Jeffrey Gitomer -putting my year and month goal on a post- it -note in the bathroom mirror. I thought I was good, but my productivity using this system is at least 30% better. Best money I have spent in quite awhile.

If the methods taught in this book are adopted wholeheartedly there is no way you won't feel a sense of relief as the number of things on your plate slowly become more manageable.One of the main things I learned through this book is to you feel comfortable with what you AREN'T doing, not necessarily what you are.  You will always have more tasks than time, but if you can understand what you have on your plate -- and how it relates to your place and time -- you can make intelligent decisions about what to do next...or what not to do.Highly recommend this book for anyone with too much on their mind.  You will notice an immediate increase in productivity.

This book is awesome and has really good, practical and easy techniques to handle the task lists and much more. I have read only first few chapters so far and it had already made my life easy .. Highly recommended.
Comment_Title: Awesome book and techniques. very helpful

Comment: I'm not sure about the "emptying the brain" part of this greatly enhancing productivity (maybe because I haven't gotten to that stage yet), but some of the organizational tips do seem much more practical than the "heavyweight" approaches from Franklin-Covey and such. A light read from which you can probably extract a few good time management tips.
Comment_Title: A bit overhyped, but worth a shot

Comment: I've spent most of my life, I'm 58, rather disorganized when it came to getting done what I needed to get done.  I used to carry around a little note pad of To-Do's, but after a while there's be too many papers to constantly be checking, then they'd get old, torn, accidently detached, etc.  Enter GTD.  I now use my Mac and GTD software to stay on top of things.  I no longer have to keep items in my mind or a bunch of pieces of paper, which GTD eliminates.The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because there was so much info in the book to explain the GTD concept.  I simply got tired of reading when I wanted to get to the meat.  However, for the professional person with a lot on their plate, the examples would be very useful.

Very good and useful book. I have started to implement his texhniques and see some improvement already. The book also made me think of buying a PAlM computer. Unfortunately David does not provide with exact set-up of his time management system. This would help to create my own.

GTD is an excellent book and well worth reading by anyone who is interested in personal productivity and personal effectiveness. There are two key points that make this a four-star vs. five-star review:1. The book has a serious layout or design problem: the "inspirational quotations" in the margins often hinder the reading flow as they push into the space occupied by the main text. The quotes distract the reader from the main text due to their intrusion into such and a lack of white space. IMO, there are too many inspirational quotes. Allen should have simply started each chapter with one relevant quote, ala Covey's "7 Habits..." I've noticed that some of the inspirational quotes in GTD are recycled in Allen's other book, "Ready for Anything" (RFA), which suffers even more from this design issue. To see how to place quotes or references in the margins of a book's pages, Allen should review any of Edward Tufte's books, such as "Beautiful Evidence."2. While Allen's focus in GTD is on getting one to clear their mind by better managing their commitments (operational, in-the-trenches, being in the moment), it is very light on "The Vision Thing" -- the big picture, the longer horizon, which is critical to one's life. He does attempt to address this in one of the later chapters, and to some degree in the essays in RFA. Anyone who reads GTD should also read Stephen Covey's "The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People" and "First Things First." Combined with GTD, the knowledge one obtains can make a powerful difference in one's life. Additionally, Peter Drucker's "The Effective Executive" is required reading for anyone interested in GTD and involved in "knowledge work."
Comment_Title: An excellent book despite a somewhat flawed layout

Comment: This is the most practical book I have ever read on productivity. As a single woman who works from home, but has a highly pressured position together with various other commitments, I have always found time management books and tools fall short of real life.This book brings it all together in a way that is easy to manage all you need to do - whether a task in line with your life's purpose or just the mundane of having to mow the lawn! For once I am in control of all my stuff and it is really AMAZING to experience the creativity that has suddenly been unleashed after getting all my stuff from my head to my list.What David Allen says in his book is what really happens. I have only been using the system for a very short while now, but it is intuitive and easy to get 'under your belt'. Just plain 'common sense', but common sense we look past in our frantic, chaotic, pressured lives.

Very practical book for getting organized and increasing your personal productivity.  Easy read - harder to implement - but if you can do it - even approximate it - the system will pay dividends.  Good book for folks who feel like they are drinking from a firehose at work... if they can find the time to read it.

I found this book to be the best organizational book I have ever read.  In fact, I bought several other copies to give to friends and colleagues.  We have implemented this program at our office and are already being to see results in productivity and organization.

Let me say the honest thing, I am not someone who can able to change dramatically just by one book. I am a person who can able to plan the work and identify the priorities very well but often miss when its time to do the thing actually. That was my primary motive to read this book.It helps me a lot in planning the work and also I become more productive at many areas. It divides the task in five distinct categories. Starting from identifying the task to completion. Each category explain very well. But I think personally that its not always possible to put all the items in in-box (as author termed) and it is quite time consuming. May be its more useful at the higher level of corporate world but at lower end its not possible to go in so much detail of each task.I am sure if one follow the steps exactly mentioned by the author, than surely he/she can increase productivity to a great extent but the only open question is....are you able to do that?
Comment_Title: Good one but feel something missing

Comment: Really helped me organize my workplace.  I would recommend this book as an ideal organization companion.  The methods presented in this book can certainly help someone in the business of "knowledge work" get organized.
It is one of most practical personal development books I read in these days. It is easy for us to know, but harder to do. Just do it.
Comment_Title: Good for those busy but not effective people

Comment: What can I say?: Should be required reading in school. The Bible of productivity.

I am a procrastinator by nature. I bought this book thinking that it might help me organize my work, but it has done so much more than that. This book has taught me not only how get things done, but how to approach my work in the first place. It will take you all the way from how to deal with the big things, but also how to deal with those little things that seem to be the very things that cause the most problems! In this book David Allen taught me how to clear the "clutter" out of my mind by properly tracking things so that I could focus on the job at hand. The greatest thing about this book that I didn't expect was the fact that by following Davids advice it reduced my stress level and gave me more time for myself!A must read!

Read pgs 1-54. Loved the information regarding email organization.  I finally have a system in place that helps me tackle things in a logical order.  I had my email folders arranged by subject category but realized I needed to arrange them by immediacy so I now have a "Do Now," "Do Later," "Delegate" and "Maybe/Someday" folders.

It takes a while to adapt the "bad" practices that I had to his system. I really did not have to change myself - just change some behaviors that I had - and suddenly it works. No longer do I forget what I should be doing. My Boss was so impressed that I gave him the book. I have never felt more productive, - but the biggest gain is the ability to do the higher thinking again because the brain is no longer using itself to remember details.It is not EASY though. Make the investment. I have had to read this book three times through to get the whole system down - but it was SO worth it.
The bible for GTD. It's an easy read even if you're just a little curious about it. A must have if you may think you'll develop your own GTD system.

I am appalled that this book is getting so much attention. My company even distributes the book to every employee (bumping out the equally unimpressive "Seven Habits").I couldn't even sit through the whole book at once; I had to drag myself almost paragraph by paragraph just to finish it. A combination of corporate drivel and mindless observation, the "tips" he offers are useless at best, and counterproductive at worst.It is amazing that so many people are screwing their lives up so badly that this book is actually helpful to them.If you want a truly helpful self-help program, try Dale Carnegie.

Two weeks ago I read and immediately implemented the process that David Allen outlined in his book and I'm already reaping the benefits. Before reading the book I actually considered myself fairly organized, but I didn't realize how blind I was to the 'nooks and crannies' of my stuff: stubborn undone tasks, books promised-to-get-read yet never do, things that get piled in a corner waiting for . . . ; you know what I'm talking about. They get lodged and lost in the shuffle. But Allen's book helped me to take off the blinders and 'put everything into IN (the IN box)', literally! He actually recommends getting and using an in box! Believe me, before I didn't have one, but, low and behold, the thing serves a very useful purpose! DUH!I'm a GTD newbie, but a lot of what Allen recommends just makes simple common sense, like his suggestion to contextualize our action items, that is, just make your lists based on where you are (at computer, at phone, at home, at office, etc), not on a perennially overly-optimistic list of things to do TODAY (that then have to be remade again TOMORROW because we seldom get half the things done on our list). Allen says that this self-demoralizing process is a dead end.But Allen's process of gaining a complete inventory has given me a fuller view of what I need to do and has helped me to process whole groups of tasks at a time.The book is long on process and relatively short on specific applications, but is well worth the mind effort that it takes to apply to your own challenges. In other words, the strength of Allen's GTD is demonstrated by the fact that it can work with paper- and computer-based processes. He assumes the lowest common denominator: paper-based, simply because everyone can relate to that. The problem for me was that I use a Palm Tungsten E2 synched to Microsoft Outlook. Thankfully plenty of quality third-party materials can be found on the web that use Allen's GTD. And actually David Allen's own website, [...] has a wealth of free practical knowledge.I give GTD a five-star rating.
Comment_Title: Put this book in your IN BOX:  It's not just another book on time management

Comment: As somebody who was always unorganized and rushed, this book really helped me put things in perspective and my productivity in my business has tripled. This book and "God's Stress Management Plan" have taught me that self-help books are not the hogwash I thought they were.I will definitely read this one over and over ...

A MAGNIFICENT, EASY APPROACH TO THE WHY AND HOW OF GETTING THINGS DONE. AS DAVID ALLEN WRITES, HE IS SPEAKING ABOUT NOT ONLY MY LIFE BUT SO MANY OTHERS.  HE HAS PUT HIS THOUGHTS AND RESOLUTIONS ABOUT FOCUSING SPIRITUALLY, WHICH PHYSICALLY MOTIVATES AND "GETS THINGS DONE"  OUR TRAVEL ON EARTH IS VERY HEAVY WHEN WE ARE SURROUNDED BY DISORGANIZATION.  FEEL FREE TO LET GO AND MOVE FORWARD ON A POSITIVE PATH TO SUCCESS.  SO MANY WILL APPRECIATE DAVID ALLEN AND HIS METHODS.  EASY TO DO, SIMPLE TO COMPREHEND, I GUESS PERHAPS IT JUST WAS NEVER PRESENTED IN THIS WAY.  ALSO A MUST READ!!  YOU WILL FEEL TRUE EMPOWERMENT AFTER THE FIRST CHAPTER, BEST OF LUCK.  I LOVED IT.

It seems to be written mainly for business people - especially the management types. Anyone can benefit from reading it though. Since reading the book, I cleaned out my Gmail inbox containing over 300 messages. I set up a new filing system at home (which works MUCH better). I bought a few extra baskets and changed the way I used my "in basket." I even bought a nice labeler!The problem is that if you don't follow the whole system you can easily get back in a frustrated rut. I'm still figured out how I want to do things. My biggest problem is that I work from two computers and two locations. I have my work office and my home office with a computer for each.There are resolutions for this type of thing, I just need to fully implement them. I would really recommend this book to anyone who feels they don't have enough time to get everything done that they want or need to.
Comment_Title: I'm Starting to Get Things Done

Comment: Received this book for Christmas and after reading it, bought a copy for each of my staff.  Book gets a lot of common sense in one place and into one diagram.
Comment_Title: After reading you'll get it done

Comment: Who would not benefit from being more efficient about everything one has to do? Think about it for a moment. We go to school and learn a standard curriculum. We go to college, and again learn some sort of structured set of subject matter. There are two extremely important subjects that I never learned anything about in a lifetime of formal learning.· How to manage my time· How to manage relationshipsIn both cases, you and I  are on our own.
